Reliable "auto" settings for fast, candid shots of my kids.I handled all of the cameras in Best Buy and ultimately went above my price ceiling to give this one a try.  I love it.Rather than bore you anymore, I will list the pros and cons...just please note, the cons aren't deal breakers for me...I've just become really picky as a consumer and am always thinking of ways that products could be "perfected" (from my perspective).Pros:  small and pocketable, great "auto" setting photos, fun setting "tweaks" (my colors, fish eye lens etc.), manual controls and control ring, great low-light/no flash results.Cons: awkward flash placement...I'm having to learn not to instinctively place my left index finger where the flash pops up, too many "tweaks?"--there are a few superfluous settings you may never need ("miniature" setting for example).  And finally, Price.  I like it...but haven't seen a reason why it needs to be a penny over $349.This is my most valuable tip!  Buy Alexander White's book:  Photographer's Guide To The Canon PowerShot S95.  It serves as a much better resource than Canon's guide and pdf manual.  Trust me, you won't want to print the pdf manual and it's not nearly as useful as White's guide.  Plus White offers something that Canon does not: an opinion.Photographer's Guide to the Canon PowerShot S95: Getting the Most from Canon's Pocketable Digital CameraThe bottom line is, if you're an amateur looking to grow as an artist or a professional looking for an at-the-ready-carry-all-the-time-speedy-camera, this is the model for you.Also, Flickr has a PowerShot s95 group where you can see endless s95 photos.

Reviews.Title: Lens problem
Reviews.Author: braxen
Reviews.Content: Purchased this camera a few months ago, "and only used it a few times. Everything seemed to work fine, except that" some day I received a message lens error and the camera would refuse to operate and automatically switch off.The quality of the picture is outstanding but having out of the blue problems after a few months of light usage is definitely not acceptable. This problem happened to two of my colleagues at the office, one of them being an expert with cameras. He simply gave up on them.Do an internet search for "Canon S95 Lens not coming out". Wait for Canon to fix their junk and release something more reliable. Otherwise, image quality is outstanding (this is my 4th or 5th digital camera) and if it were to work, I'd always use it instead of my D90.Not recommended at this stage.

Reviews.Title: Amazing compact camera
Reviews.Author: D. Freckleton
Reviews.Content: I have been taking outdoor shots for many years. As a travel companion, I could hardly ask for a more applicable, decent little camera then the Canon S95.I actually owned a Canon S90 (previous year's model), which turned out to be my favorite camera for a time. For the curious, check out my site - scenicdesktops.com, just to see the kind of pictures I took with it.The S95 shares everything that made the S90 such a hit, with a few very nice refinements that make it into what I consider to be a close-to-perfect compact camera.The basics which both of these cameras share are:1. Excellent image quality. The sensor in this little camera is roughly twice the size in area of sensors found in most compacts of similar size (meaning pocketable). Combined with a bright lens (f2.0, at it's widest - where I often use it), it produces better highlights (clouds, etc) and shadows over a wide margin then what any of my older compacts could achieve or even get close to.2. Excellent controls. I love canon's approach. The control ring around the lens on the front is likely my favorite feature. Amazingly versitle and simple, it provides fine control over any one setting you choose, such as exposure, white balance, ISO, etc. Selecting the setting is easy, with a ring func button on top, and the control it provides is solid, with smooth operation and nice, audible clicks. A smaller, secondary control ring is placed around the directional pad on the back, which provides further control. A programmable shortcut button on the back simply serves to be assigned whatever function you wish. On the control dial at the top, a custom mode is provided which saves your exact settings to keep you from having to reset everything after turning it off.3. Nice menus. The quick menu (where most of the commonly accessed settings are) is nice, 2-dimensional simplicity, with clear, distinct options, and a layout you won't get lost in. The main "menu-menu", while more traditional, is also clean, and thankfully not riddled with numerous nested menus.4. Truly compact. The main competitors from Panasonic and Olympus, while noteworthy and with comparable specs, simply do not quite fall into the 'pocketable' realm, with their lenses and other features protruding out enough to disqualify each, imo. The S95 really is a pocketable camera, no doubt about it, and with credible specs to boot.Additionally, the S95 improves and adds upon an already excellent package:1. Improves the rear control dial. The S90's dial was loose and spun freely, whereas the S95 features 'clicks' which prevent accidental movement.2. The S90 had a slippery metal body; the S95 features a surface which is tackier and easier to hold.3. The S95 now offers 720p HD video; the S90 did not.4. The S95 now offers stereo sound with left and right michrophones. Even high end cameras generally lack this.5. The S90 only offered a single lanyard-link on the side; the S95 offers two, both at the top corners. This allows for a neck lanyard if desired.6. New modes such as HDR, as well as a greater range of options for the customizable buttons/rings.7. The S95 is slimmer then the S90 by a notable amount.With that said, it's not a camera that can 'do everything' - mostly because it is a compact, after all. It doesn't feature the huge sensors of large cameras that allow selective focus several feet away (for portraits, etc), or hot shoe mounts, pivoting screens, etc. None of these really belong on a compact. There are a couple minor nitpicks that I can point out. You can't control what the rear control dial does, for example - it defaults to whatever mode your in. You also loose most manual control when in a scene mode. I don't find these to be glaring or problematic, others may.As a side note, a company called Lensmate (no affiliation, promise!) provides worthwhile S90 / S95 accessories, such as a tiny 37mm filter holder that can attach to the front (I use a polarizer), as well as a small attachable grip that I think works perfectly, without compromising pocketability.Considering I would have given the excellent S90 a 5 star rating, the S95 gets this and then some. For someone who likes to travel, hike, and shoot with focus across the frame, this camera is one of those rare items that feels someone must have made just for me.

Reviews.Title: Good balance: size, material, quality
Reviews.Author: Rom
Reviews.Content: You know it's a great camera, so I'll skip to the chase.PROS:- SIZE.  This camera's compactness can't be underestimated.  The competitors may have better glass, wider angles, and better ergonomics, but they will be bigger.  A 1/4" in depth and 1/2" in length is a huge differnece in your pocket- CONTROLS: Classic Canon UI simplicity.  The ring is a smart move,and you can quickly reassign its functions.- MATERIALS: With a metal shell, this camera can easily take falls and impacts.  I'm confident this can sustain a sidewalk drop and keep going.- IMAGE QUALITY:  You can take photos in dimly lit rooms and still get sharp results.  Cafes, bars, and urban nightlife shots come out very well. I've never had a pocket cam capable of night photography like this one.CONS:- BAD LIVE PREVIEW:  No live preview of exposure changes.  This is very frustrating when trying to stop down 1/3 or up 2... you have to guess, which really makes this a useless feature.  Hopefully Canon will address with a firmware update.- BAD PAINT: While build quality is good, the paint is quite poor.  I stored the camera with my laptop in a bag and the paint rubbed off along the ring and on the corners.  Looks field-tested, but the paint should not rub off this easily.- ERGONOMICS: rear dial jogs very easily, sometime leading to over/under exposed photos.-SPEED: I have owned two Canon SDs and this one has a perceptable shutter lag which shouldn't exist at this price point.  It's not a deal breaker, but I wouldn't use it for action photography.

Reviews.Title: My everyday camera when not shooting with my 5D
Reviews.Author: David Chan
Reviews.Content: I will keep this nice and short since everybody else has already discussed the pros and cons of the S95 in detail. I usually shoot with my 5D and an assortment of L lenses when I want and need quality, large prints and shallow DOF. But try lugging that setup around when traveling and you would rather not take any pictures. The S95 is the perfect solution. Remember the old saying...The BEST camera is the one you HAVE with you.Yes. I too debated getting it or the Panasonic LX5 but at the end of the day, I want something that will be as easy to carry and pocket as a cell phone. Plus I like Canon colors should I shoot in jpeg instead of RAW. The panasonic seems to have a magenta cast to their blues which make shots of skys a bit odd. Both cameras have their strengths and weaknesses but the S95 won me over with better pricing, colors in jpeg, HDR,  good low light capability and portability although I would have liked the 24mm wide angle on the Panasonic.Video is OK at 24fps and is fine for an occasional grab. It's a little choppy so you have to pan slowly. Forget about chasing the kids with the camera. But I have my Panasonic TM60 camcorder for times when I want to shoot video. I got the S95 for pictures.Overall, I am very happy with my purchase. It's a very capable tool that can do 90% of what my 5D can do especially when I shoot in RAW and post process. And it won't break my back carrying it around meaning I will always have it ready whenever the photo op arises.

Reviews.Title: Canon S95 : Overpriced Lemon
Reviews.Author: John Podgorski
Reviews.Content: I have been a loyal Canon camera owner for about 35 years, until I purchased the Canon S95.Within a month, the flash unit jammed.  In for repair, returned a month later.A few weeks later, the zoom jammed.  In for repair, returned a month later.A month later, the flash unit jammed again.  Back for repairs again.  I still do not have it returned to me.This camera has been in the shop more than I have had it in my hands.... 3 months for repairs, 2 months of use.Overpriced lemon is my final verdict.Why pay this much money for a camera that is unreliable?Why do business with a company that will not make good and give me a new camera?Personally, I can no longer trust Canon to stand by their products.Henry's Canada was the store I purchased it from... they were no help either.I would not recommend doing business with them either.Sad story... unfortunately, all too true.

Reviews.Title: Niche camera-perfect for my serious side-not tossable
Reviews.Author: SK "sk"
Reviews.Content: I must begin by saying that I own and use a Nikon professional DSLR.  I use prime lenses and occasionally a stabilized zoom and I am not bothered by the size and weight of my camera equipment.  That said, I only take it with me to "on purpose" events and do not use it for "snapshots". I have and enjoy a Canon SX100is and it has served me well without a single complaint.  I bought the S95 to supplement my other cameras and I must admit, to satisfy my ego and my curiosity.  I have experimented with it within the last month and I do enjoy the performance of this little camera.  I like the option of using it as a creative camera, rather than a point and shoot on the green auto setting. I do not shoot video, ever. I can't understand peoples' obsession with short video clips and would use a real video camera if I was that into it. I did want a camera that I can be a little less careful with.  I hoped to free myself a bit from guarding the camera and have something to "toss around" like so many others do. I failed at that one.  The S95 is not tossable.  I guard it like every thing else I own. It's just too nice to rough up.  I should have known better.I purchased this camera instead of the Canon Elph 300HS.  It was a tough call as the 300HS is an excellent pocket camera and it is much lighter and smaller than the S95.  And yes it is probably "tossable".  I do not shoot RAW and do not have a reason to.  My purchase came down to one deciding factor, the lens.  At it's most wide angle, the S95 has a f2 lens, vs the f2.7 of the 300HS and the 2.8 of my SX100.  That is a full stop and that is huge.  It may not seem like much, but it allows me to use the S95 inside any reasonably well lit space without a flash.  That is often the difference between a photograph and nothing.  My primary purpose for this camera is taking photos at indoor family events and a flash is often intrusive.  I decided that this feature alone was worth double the price of the Elph 300HS.  I also could afford it.  If money was a bigger issue, I would have bought the 300HS for myself and been perfectly happy with it.  I bought a red 300HS for my niece for XMAS 2011 and she is thrilled with it. For typical outdoor photos, either camera will perform well.The S95 is not double the camera.  It works for me as I use it.  I believe that those disappointed in it have unreasonable expectations.  It is better.  If you can afford it, buy it or buy the S100.  You will love it. If not don't sweat it.  Buy what you can comfortably afford and don't forget to use your camera.  No camera will take wonderful photographs.  Only you can do that. Enjoy whatever camera you own and use it often.  And always bring a camera with you.

Reviews.Title: Almost There...
Reviews.Author: bghull
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera to accompany my aging Canon dSLR for my trip to France for a few months for school. What follows are general impressions from someone who shoots for fun, but seriously, and expects his camera to be able to perform to the vision in his head.First, the body of the camera is great. As others have said the grip is a little funky sometimes because your hand just doesn't want to quite stay where it's supposed to, but the finish on the paint helps alleviate that. The shutter button is easy to find without looking in it's recessed little area within the zoom knob, and the half-press is responsive to the touch. The scroll wheel on the back is lovely, with just enough grab at intervals to click into place without being over controlling or too loose, as was the case with the s90. I absolutely love the wheel on the front that surrounds the lens; because I shoot mostly in Av mode I can adjust the aperture on the fly with one hand and the ISO via the shortcut button and wheel on the back almost instantaneously, not to mention the satisfyingly old-school clicking it makes.Two body complaintsOne: If you are holding the camera with both hands, you may be surprised by the flash which is motorized straight up out of the body and will most likely be impeded by your finger. The solution, of course, is to avoid the flash as much as possible simply out of the problems of on-camera flash.Two: The mode selection wheel can be a little tricky, especially if trying to go in/out of movie mode which has a large gap between itself and the nearest manual mode, because it is rather recessed into the body and stiff to begin with. Except under the most perfect conditions I have to use m fingernail to turn it, which is more or less an inconvenience.Performance is what I really came here to talk about. There are plenty of reviews that rave over the great photos that come out of this camera, and they're all very true. What bothered me however was the intense barrel distortion that came out of the 6m wide-end of the lens. I first noticed it in my architectural pictures around Paris, where none of the features quite lined up right, and as time went on it started to drive me crazy. I started either using the barreling artistically as a slight fisheye lens or zooming to an (almost 50mm) 49mm equivalent, which kicks my max aperture to f/3.2, nullifying the beautiful f/2.0 real max aperture.After some research, I found CHDK, a program that non-invasively allows you to squeeze that extra bit from your Canon point-and-shoot. The s95 has many of the CHDK functions built-in, but one interesting discovery was the ability to write RAW files as DNG (Digital NeGative) files. When I shot a few DNGs at 6mm and viewed them on my computer, the barreling was absolutely horrendous. I discovered that the s95 does quite a bit of barrel distortion correction when writing JPGs to memory, though evidently not enough. The fix? Lightroom, my editing program of choice, has support for the Canon s95 starting at version 3.4 which allows one to apply lens-specific calibrations to any photo. In order to use this you must shoot in the default RAW mode, which involves more memory and time to write to the card when shooting, but the correction is absolutely unbelievable, and even editable after the calibration default is applied. Moreover, the noise correction that one can apply to RAW files in LR3 is far superior to the in-camera processing, with much smoother textures and crisper detail resolution.For this reason I give it a 4; if Lightroom is out of reach for you (student discount anyone?) or if CHDK is incomprehensible (which it shouldn't be with some work), then the camera performs great in and of itself. If you have these tools it is nearly perfect, with support for scripting via CHDK and much clearer high-ISO shots thanks to LR3 and RAW. It definitely beats lugging my dSLR around pickpocket-infested tourist locations just to get a unique photo.

Reviews.Title: Rivals DSLR Pics in Certain lighting situations
Reviews.Author: M. Wells "Mr. Cool"
Reviews.Content: This is a wonderful little camera that blows every point and shoot digital camera on the market (as of January 2011) out of the water.  I've owned 4 point and shoots in my lifetime, three of them were sony cybershots and one was a canon powershot SD1100, but this one consistently takes crystal clear images unlike other point and shoots.  Plus it has much higher ISO settings than any other point and shoot I've every seen which enables it to take better low light shots, and the noise reduction on it isn't to bad.  There have been times when I've taken photos side by side with my Nikon d300s and this thing rivaled the quality in normal outdoor lighting conditions.  The camera also offers multiple scene modes to choose from.  overall, great bang for your buck and if you're looking for a a great camera but don't want to make the DSLR investment or you're looking for a camera to substitute your DSLR when you don't feel like lugging it around all day on an outdoor trip with the family, go with this camera.  for those who think the price on it is to high, the old saying goes "you get what you pay for".  you'll never get photos as good as these on a cheaper 150 dollar point and shoot.  oh, and one more thing, you can shoot in RAW with this camera which is a feature rarely offered in point and shoots. the HD video quality in normal lighting conditions is so good that I've shot video clips alongside my Canon VIXIA HF S10 HD Camcorder and was stunned of how similar they were in quality.  overall, no complaints.  stop waiting and buy the thing

Reviews.Title: The most overhyped camera of 2010
Reviews.Author: T. Bohn
Reviews.Content: I really wanted to like this camera. I wanted a high quality, rangefinder like, digital camera to carry as an alternative to my DSLR. I picked this over the LX5 mostly because it was somewhat smaller and the many people carried it in their pants pocket. Frankly unless you have baggy clothes I did not find this to be a workable option(too thick and the lens would catch in the edge of my jeans pocket). I carried it in a Lowepro belt case(like my previous P&Ss;). I found the layout of the top of the camera and the motorized pop up flash quite annoying. The top of the camera is quite crowded making it very difficult to use your left hand to stabilize the camera. If you scroll over the auto or force flash setting the will flash pop up so if you are used holding the camera there you will have to adjust your style. The camera has a number of nice features which it should for it's price point and being billed as an enthusiasts camera. In everyday shooting, unless you use the raw processing and/or the extra stop, the photo quality in no better that my wife's Panasonic ZS5 which is about half the price. My main complaint is my camera failed after about two weeks(maybe 150 shots) I received a "lens error" and the camera just shuts down and says restart camera. No drops, no abuse, no scratches. Then I find out on flickr that this is somewhat common. To make the situation more unpleasant Canon reserves the right to replace my camera with a "refurbished" model. This does not seem like a fair policy to me.....  Buy a new camera and get a used one in return.  For it's price/ features I would rate this camera 3 to 4 stars. But due to Canon's repair policy and my first hand experience I can only give it a one star rating and hope my customer experience with Canon improves.

Reviews.Title: I'm a believer!
Reviews.Author: Kate Stokes
Reviews.Content: I shoot with a full-frame DSLR and I am also a hardcore pixel-peeper, so I was hesitant at first about buying any point and shoot camera for fear that I would find the image quality too inferior to stomach. Too many opportunities went by, however, when I wish I had a camera and didn't have one so I decided to break down and finally get a point and shoot that I could have with me at all times. I researched the matter extensively and settled on this model.The upshot? Boy am I pleasantly surprised by the image quality from this camera. I just wasn't expecting such clean, great looking images. The noise level is also lower than I was expecting. Furthermore, I wasn't expecting such a small camera. I thought the camera would be about 25% bigger than it turned out to be. That was also a pleasant surprise; this truly is a pocketable camera.I'm not going to go on and on because the only important thing you want to know is how is the image quality right? The image quality is the best I have ever seen in a point and shoot, and frankly looks similar to lower end (non-full frame) DSLRs I have used in the past. I am, however, speaking of static subjects in ideal light. This would probably not be the best choice for sports photography. Anyway, I couldn't be happier with my purchase. Canon has hit a home run here.

Reviews.Title: Best "pocket" camera available right now
Reviews.Author: K. Kress "Andy Green"
Reviews.Content: First off, no camera is perfect. This camera isnt perfect but its the best "pocket camera" you can buy. Period. A lot of people compare this camera to the Panasonic Lumix LX5. The LX5 is an awesome camera but I dont consider that a "pocket" camera. It is bigger and bulkier and doesnt fit in your pocket very well. I would almost compare that camera to the Canon G11 or G12. The Canon S95 is simply the best camera if you are looking for something very portable and you can take anywhere with you. I have owned the S90 and now the S95 and its the only camera I use. I take it everywhere to capture my 4 year old in all his activities. I used to lug around a DSLR camera but didnt like it because it was so big and bulky (but it took awesome photos) I looked into this camera (S90 initially) and fell in love with it and its all I use now. The S95 is basically the same but basically three things got better. Video which was good just got better because its now in HD. The sound which I thought was very good just got better because video is now in Stereo. (two very tiny speakers are now visable on the front of the camera) The S90 was very sleek and some said too sleek because when you held it, some compared it to holding a bar of soap in the bathroom. It was very slick. The body of the S95 has a texture to it now that is better and not as "slick" to the touch. One thing I also like about this camera is it takes action photos a little better. The S90 "sports" mode took photos at a snails pace of about 1 photo every second basically. (DSLR's take about 4-5 per second and are very fast) The S95 does a little better at about 2 shots every second. This still is not very good but is acceptable for a camera like this and does help if you are taking photos of action, etc. Again, no camera is perfect but this is about as close as you can get until something new comes out next year. However, if you want an awesome "pocket" camera that can take great photos (especially in low light), has a very fast lens (aperture 2.0), can be used fully manual if you want and takes very good video clips, this is the camera to buy. I am sure next year there will be some more improvements with this camera or features added and maybe Nikon or someone else will come out with something comparable to this Canon S95 but it doesnt exist right now. This little camera is the best right now. You wont be disappointed and quit looking around for something comparable because it doesnt exist. The only other camera that I looked at is the Panasonic Lumix LX5. It is a very, very good camera also (maybe a little better then this camera) but it is bigger and bulkier and really doesnt slip into your pocket very well. It also takes photos very well in low light (aperture of 2.0 also) and has a lens that is wider 24mm compared to Canon's 28mm and takes photos at around 3 shots per second compared to the S95 2 shots per second but its a little bigger and about $50 more. I encourage you to look at the Panasonic but the Canon wins for me!! Good luck and quit worrying and buy this camera!!!Update: Here is a really neat "letter" that was written and posted on Yahoo the other day from an editor with the NY Times....I copied and pasted it into this review. Its good!Dear Canon S95,I don't often write love letters to gadgets. But you, you're something special.Truth is, I've been searching for someone like you for years.See, I love the huge light sensor that's inside an SLR. It can take sharp low-light shots without the flash. It can blur the background the way professionals do.I just don't like how an SLR is big and heavy and obtrusive.What I've always wanted is a little camera with a big sensor. Is that so hard?Apparently, yes. The problem is covering a rectangular sensor chip with a circle of light from the lens. Bigger sensor? You need a bigger camera. Those are the simple bylaws of physics.But you, oh, cute little Canon PowerShot S95! I love that you're a pocket camera, only 3.9 by 2.3 by 1.2 inches. I love your big, bright, three-inch screen, your built-in flash, your H.D.M.I. output for hi-def TV sets. I love that you turn on directly into Playback mode, without having to extend the lens.I love the unique control ring around the dial, which I can quickly program to adjust whatever feature I want: focus, zoom, exposure, light sensitivity (ISO), aperture, even degree of color saturation (all the way to black-and-white).I've had fun with your special modes, like the tilt-shift-lens simulator and fake fisheye.I love the wink-driven self-timer. Yes, I set up the camera, walk into the scene, and then wink-the picture is taken two seconds later. Beats hunting around for a remote control. (Or I can ask you to wait two seconds after a new person-that would be me, joining the group-enters the frame.)But above all, I love your enormous sensor. It's 0.59 inches diagonally-88 percent more area than most pocket cameras' sensors. And I love that you have an f/2.0 lens, a rarity among pocket cameras, meaning that you let in a lot more light.And all of this means that you, little S95, can take amazing, sharp pictures in low light without the flash. Your designers have shrewdly dropped the ludicrous quest for more megapixels-you have 10 megapixels, just right-in favor of something that really matters, like better photos.So many times I've used you for pictures at night, indoors, in shadow. Cathedrals, restaurants, parties. No, the results aren't as good as an SLR's-you still manage to blur a shot, especially in very dark situations when the subject is moving-but they're light-years better than any other pocket camera can do. I love to show off your photo samples.You're even better than my last love, your predecessor, the S90. Because you're slimmer. And now you take hi-def videos-with stereo sound. You have a high-dynamic-range mode, where you combine three tripod shots at different exposures into a single photo with a really great range of darks and lights. Your controls are refined in size and placement.Look, S95-I know you're not perfect. Your battery takes only 200 shots on a charge, which is very low. You won't let me use the optical zoom while I'm shooting video; in fact, you can't refocus while shooting video, either. (Your arch-rival, the Panasonic LX5, can zoom during video. Then again, it's porkier and requires fussing with a detached lens cap.)And, of course, you cost twice what most pocket cams cost. You're $400.But you are the best pocket camera on the market. I have carried you for many weeks, in many situations, and I have been thrilled by the sharpness, color, control and photographic success rate that you give me.Yes, Canon S95, I think you and I have a long, happy future ahead of us. Heck, you may remain state-of-the-art for several months at least!Love,David

Reviews.Title: S95 vs S90 vs S100
Reviews.Author: Shawn C.
Reviews.Content: This review is for people who owns a S90 considering upgrading to S95 or S100.I own a S90 since it first debuted and have been very happy with it.  Monday I went to a local camera store and compared S95 vs S100 back to back including image quality on ISO 80 at 28mm & here is my impression: S95's image quality is noticeably superior, S100's image looks more washed out. S95's image is more consistent from center to corners but S100's image has 1 or 2 soft corners. At this focal point, S95's lens is brighter so has faster shutter speed. At ISO 800 both camera has pretty equal image quality but with such bright lens and good IS, you rarely shoot above 800 ISO. Unless you need the extra wide angle or slightly longer range I would choose S95 especially for the low price they offer. I do like the S100's better grip. I ended up taking the S95 home. I wanted to give 4 stars to the S100 but since it is 43% higher than the price of the S95 I give it a 3.Went home and compared S95 vs S90 back to back. Almost identical image quality except S95 has cleaner image processing at the darker areas due to an improve jpg processor. I also like the better ergonomics on the S95 and the price was $100 less than what I paid 1.5 year ago. Other notable improvement that was not mentioned in most reviews was there are more settings for Auto ISO: you can choose a slow ISO increase rate vs normal. In Program mode(P), the normal ISO increase rate was at 1/30" shutter speed, but under slow ISO, the threshold is now 1/15" which is very ideal for still or very slow moving objects in low light. This is just what I needed for the older S90 where under auto ISO setting, the camera wants to choose a much higher ISO than necessary thus produces poorer images, but now I just set it at slow auto ISO and let the camera choose the correct ISO.  I can also set a upper limit in addition to the auto ISO. Most of the other pros & cons are already covered by someone else so I don't need to go over them any more.

Reviews.Title: It's no secret: a top-notch camera
Reviews.Author: C.K.N.
Reviews.Content: I'm not experienced with SLR cameras, but I wouldn't consider myself a novice with point and shoots. After doing much research on the best P+S cameras, I, like many others, boiled down the search to two: the Panasonic Lumix LX5 and the Canon PowerShot S95. By now there were many sites with articles comparing the two. In the end, I decided that the S95's significantly smaller, pocketable size was the dealbreaker. I had to sacrifice a wider lens (24 mm vs 28 mm on the S95) and shooting speed (6 fps vs 1.9* fps on the S95), not to mention the sexy Leica-branded lens (seriously!) but I decided that the more optimal size and low light performance of the S95 was worth it.So far I've brought it nearly everywhere, even to work since it is so pocketable. Note that it's still significantly larger than entry-level P+S cameras.PROS (notable ones I've picker out):+Gorgeous, razor sharp LCD screen+Control wheel, in addition to the rear dial, makes setting options much faster+Great image quality, with sharpness nearing SLR's+Built-in HDR mode is awesome for scenic photos+Simplistic, classy design+Very good low-light performance: ISO 3200 can make a room illuminated only by a monitor seem like it's taken during day (noisy though, but the colors were there) See pics.CONS (Improvements I'd like to see):-Pop up flash is very annoying, that's where my left index finger rests!-Aperture is pretty bad when fully zoomed in, at f/4.9 (though the lens is quite fast at the wide end at f/2.0)-Shooting speed could be better-Optical zoom could be better (only 3.8x)Conclusion: This is one of the best P+S cameras available with today's technology. Very soon the gap between P+S and SLR cameras will be bridged, though there are always factors such as optical zoom and depth of field that can only be improved so much due to physical limitations of a pocket camera.*You can use the low-light mode during day time, which shoots about 4 fps but at 2.5 MP size

Reviews.Title: Professional photographer -- LOVE this camera!
Reviews.Author: KatherineSD "Katherine"
Reviews.Content: Finally a pocket camera that I can use as a professional photographer when I am trying to take shots of people/street scenes without walking around with my giant Canon lenses!  I have been in the market for a small camera for years and have never been satisfied with the image quality until the S95 came out.  This camera is AMAZING.  It does about 90% of what my $3500 Canon 5D Mk II does.  It is an excellent point and shoot (great for my kids and husband, who don't want to adjust anything) but I love the fact that I can go "all manual" without a fuss.  I shoot in RAW but husband and kids like JPG for simplicity.  The images are vibrant and sharp.  Skin tones look natural.  Even in extremely low light, the pics are not grainy and have excellent saturation.  Focus in low light is spot on, something that is hard to achieve with most inexpensive cameras.  I have shown my photographs to my students and they have a hard time guessing if it's my $5000 Canon/lens or this $400 super-mini that took the shots....My only gripe is the ergonomics.  The flash pops up RIGHT where I hold the camera so it's a bit annoying.  Also, while the S95 has a more "nonslip" coating, it is not a rubberized grip like my big Cannon.  I would LOVE to see some rubber on the casing to help make sure it doesn't slip out of my hands.  Finally, on occasion the flash overexposes so I have the EV down -2/3.  That takes care of it.  I just leave it there and my pix are perfect.Cannot recommend highly enough, both to novices who want a great point and shoot and pros who want a small pocket camera that is less conspicuous than the usual "gear."

Reviews.Title: Best compact digital camera ever! (until the next great thing comes out...)
Reviews.Author: Allan R
Reviews.Content: I've always wanted SLR quality in a compact digital camera, and this baby comes very close.  For daytime, good light photography, it's probably as good as many SLR's out there, and in low light, it's far and away better than any compact I've ever used.  The range of manual controls is impressive, yet the camera remains relatively easy to learn.  I especially like the programmable "S" button on the back, which can be programmed to 20 different functions.  I personally keep mine on AE lock (exposure lock).  With many other cameras, you have to move it around the scene until you find the right exposure, then half-press the shutter (which also locks focus), then recompose while keeping the button half-pressed, and shoot.  Kind of a hassle, and of course the focus is locked on whatever you locked exposure on.  With the s95, I simply find the exposure level I want, then press the "S" button, which locks the exposure.  Then I can freely move the camera and refocus on what I intend to photograph without having to hold down the shutter button, or lock in the focus.  And there are many other uses for the "S" button if you choose!  The front control ring is also programmable, being able to select from many options, including a custom option to create your own specific use.  The camera is highly customizable, but without being overwhelming.  It's fantastic!As far as performance goes, I have never gotten such quality images before.  The daytime photographs are incredibly clean and sharp, and the in-camera adjustments and IQ are great.  The light metering is generally good, as is the white balance.  And if you aren't satisfied with the white balance, there is a custom white balance mode, which renders indoor evening shots under lights perfectly, once the custom white balance is applied.  Apertures run from a fast f2.0 to f8.0, which can be used creatively in creating decent DOF photographs.  You aren't going to get SLR DOF performance with the s95, but you can create very interesting images at f2.0.  Shutter speed runs from 1/1600 to 15 seconds, perfect from getting fast action sports to perfect night time exposures.  And speaking of night time exposures, this camera produces outstanding images in very low light.  Using manual mode, you can create essentially grain-free long exposures, using a low ISO and slow shutter speed.  I have NEVER seen such clean night images in any compact digital camera before (assuming you can find one with manual controls!).  Even indoors, the camera produces very nice images, even with ISO's up to 1600.  I've noticed graininess starting around ISO 400, but that's at 100% view and nitpicking the shot.  Most family photos and indoor people shots are not highly scrutinized, so even ISO 800 and 1600 shots are usable.  WAY better than any other small camera's ability indoors at night, that's for sure!There is also a completely customizable mode, interestingly enough called "C".  You can program this to be set up any way you like it...so if you do a lot of specific shooting (night time, indoor family photos, lets say), you could set it up to have the shutter speed, aperture, ISO, etc, the way you like it.  That way, you don't have to enter manual mode or semi-manual and fiddle with the settings each time.  You have one full-time dedicated mode for shooting the way you like!And for those who just like to point and shoot, the auto mode is acceptable.  I personally use "P" mode most of the time, which is pretty much auto, with some control over settings.  But if you just want to turn on the camera and shoot, auto will still render high quality images, though sometimes I have noticed with auto mode the autofocus can give me trouble.  Using P-mode will still make it easy, but with some more reliable focusing.  Besides, hopefully you are buying this camera with SOME intention on learning how to manually create better shots...but again, even if you just want to use the auto mode, you will get photos much nicer than any other pocket camera, a reason to buy this in and of itself.There are so many more outstanding features to list...I could go on forever.  Autofocus tracking, 1.9 shot-per-second continuous mode (with AF servo!), low light mode (with ISO's up to 12,800(!!)), scene mode with countless scene choices (including HDR which does remarkably well), and of course HD video mode.  Let me mention one thing about the HD video however.  It's not that great, in my opinion.  I also have the Canon SD940IS, and it takes beautiful HD video.  This camera does not.  There is a lot of "judder" when filming moving objects, or when panning the camera.  It's not smooth at all when moving.  The 940 is very smooth, even when walking and filming.  The s95 struggles to maintain a clear video, unless filming stationary objects.  Not good if you intend on making videos of your children running or playing!  I think it has something to do with the type of sensors in each camera.  I don't know anything about this technical stuff, but it appears this camera's sensor is more geared for still photographs and not HD video.  However, there are two mics on the front of the camera, for STEREO sound!If you are buying this solely for the HD video, you may want to look elsewhere (you can get HD video in products much cheaper than this now).  Still, the video is probably passable to most, and should not be a hinderance from buying this great little package!EDIT:  When I first wrote the review, I did not know why the HD video was subpar to the smaller, cheaper SD940IS.  The reason is that the s95 only shoots 24 frams per second of video (FPS), whereas the 940 shoots 30 FPS.  The s95's video is clealy choppy, but you can change the video settings to shoot 30 FPS (but will not be true HD).

Reviews.Title: Good camera.  However, probably not a better value than the S90
Reviews.Author: Brad A. Totman
Reviews.Content: I have a T2i, G11, S90, and now the S95.  I really love the size of the camera and the fact it is pocket-able.  It can take pics on the same level as the G11.  I do miss the hot shoe but not the size of the G11.  I do have more misfires than the G11, and certainly more than the T2i.  However, I am disappointed in the video.  I bought the S95 for the HD video.  The G11 takes great video (albeit Standard Definition).  The S90 takes okay video but noticeably inferior to the video I've taken with my G11 (even if they are supposed to have the same sensor, there's a definite difference).  In fact, I think I liked the video from my old SD1200 better than the S90's.  The S95 while 720p, is vastly inferior in quality to the T2i (@ 720p) and really doesn't look much better than the G11's Standard Def.  Yeah, it's 720p, but it looks much more grainy and seems to lack clarity, even in outdoor and well lit video.  I wasn't expecting video on par with the T2i (at 1080p or 720p) but I certainly expected more than I got.  The lack of auto-focus and optical zoom with video is an annoyance.  And while I consider video a secondary feature, I would still like it to be good.  The upgrades over the S90 aren't anything great. It's not a bad camera (it's quite good) but I don't think it's worth the premium over the S90 for the few extra features you get.And another gripe is Adobe Lightroom 3.2 does not yet support S95 RAW files.  Not a knock against the camera or Canon, I understand Adobe works in cycles to add cameras.  Though I do wonder why the 60D already is compatible while the S95 is out and is not.  It's still something it's target buyer should be aware of (I wasn't until I tried to import the RAW files).Edited on 9/22/10 - One feature that I really like about the S95 that I didn't think about until using an S90 again was the ability to set a Maximum Auto ISO.  I would definitely miss that as that is something I use a lot.

Reviews.Title: S95 vs LX5
Reviews.Author: N. Sun "nxs4ever@hotmail.com"
Reviews.Content: I'd had my eyes on this camera for months. I'm not a pro photographer by any means, more of a novice, but the great thing about this camera is that it actually helps one learn about photography. Adjusting settings like the f stop, iso, and shutter speed are reflected in real time on the LCD screen so you're seeing what each setting does.One of the reasons I bought this camera was to take photos that allow for blurring of the background, focusing on the subject in the foreground. This may seem trivial, but this feat is extremely difficult with cheaper point and shoots that don't have an aperture priority mode. I moved up from a new Nikon S8100, a good but not great camera. While there are many modes with my Nikon and it's got more megapixels, the images taken with my S95 are better because of the larger, better sensor.The adjusting ring located around the lens is very easy to use. You can adjust it to control various settings. Mine is set to focus. When adjusting the focus, the camera conveniently displays a mini screen within the LCD screen that shows what you are focusing on.For a lot of people, it's down to this camera and the Panasonic LX5 or the Nikon P700. I'm not familiar with the P700 but I have done some research on the LX5. The sensor is larger on the LX5 and it's got a wider angle lens. I have seen pics taken with both in a Cameralabs review and the LX5 seems to take clearer pictures during the day, but the S95 does just a tad better with more natural looking artifacts at higher isos. In terms of the physical body, the S95 is sleeker and doesn't require a lens cap. The S95 lacks, however, a hot shoe for attachments/accessories. But smaller isn't always better. The S95 can be a bit hard to keep in your hands when adjusting the center control ring, even with my medium sized hands. The battery in the LX5 lasts longer and the LX5 has a dedicated button for shooting video. One thing I was disappointed with was the fact one cannot adjust the focus in video shooting mode. This would have made a great bonus.So the bottom line when choosing between the two cameras comes down to price and availability. Both cameras are awesome, with the S95 cheaper but harder to find in stock in many stores. I snagged a S95 on sale and was lucky to find one.

Reviews.Title: Superb with a few faults
Reviews.Author: Justarasta
Reviews.Content: Just came back from two weeks in Thailand, Cambodia and Laos with the S95 as my only camera.  I was breaking the SLR habit as I needed to travel light and it is genuinely liberating not to have a SLR around your neck.  You can carry the S95 and two extra batteries in a single pocket.A quick review of the 2400 plus photos I came back with in Picassa on the iMac 27 shows great color rendition,  excellent contrast and great sharpness.  I'm not at all regretting the decision to bring only the S95.  I was also looking at the LX-5 as the 24mm Leica lens was very attractive to me.  However the additional size would be an issue and there seems to be some concern about the JPEG color rendition.  I have no interest in a great deal of post processing so JPEG rendition is very important to me.  This is the fourth small Canon I've had.  I've only had a problem with one, a is870 that developed a gray spot on the LCD.  I bought and would recommend a screen protector for the LCD in an abundance of caution even though I'm not generally a screen saver kind of guy.Some random thoughts:  The camera is pretty sturdy (at times it reminded me of my old Nikon F3 for reasons not entirely clear to me) and the black finish is tough and plenty grippy,  LCD screen is excellent and is visible even in bright light.  Full auto mode is hard to beat.  Other modes are useful for specific situations.  The other mode I used most often is low light.  However you should set up the buttons so that with one push you can set WB to the scene as the auto mode in low light is not always accurate.  The problem with the low light mode is that it jacks the ISO up quite a bit.  However it can capture photos in extremely low light conditions that even my SLR could not take.  There are sometimes focus issues in low light mode but it easily goes into manual focus.  The pixilation at ISO's up to 800 is not bad.You can set up different modes to access immediately key settings.  For example you can set up Tv to shoot vivid or slide film color mode and then use auto or another mode to shoot normal color.  You can also shoot in different aspect ratios.  There are many different modes, some of which are useful.  The external ring is best used to set focal length in my experience.  The rotating ring on the back is most often used for exposure variation unless you are shooting in full manual mode.The battery life is not impressive although I admit that I have no idea of how many photos per battery I was getting.  However having three batteries was mandatory for a full days' shooting - although you'll have to recharge more before you go out at night.  The size of the camera is a blessing and a curse.  The small size makes panning smoothly in video mode difficult and getting photos level even with the grid in place sometimes difficult.I have to say that while there are minor nits they are far outweighed by the enormous capabilities of this camera.  If you're looking for a solid camera with a wide range of capabilities and a solid auto mode when you just want to look for targets the S95 would be difficult to beat.

Reviews.Title: The best compact camera on the market!
Reviews.Author: Chronoserpent
Reviews.Content: Simply said, the S95 is the best compact camera on the market today.  If you want a powerhouse that will provide fantastic image quality and manual control but will fit into your pocket, look no further.I am a professional photographer, and I recently used my new S95 as a backup to my Canon 7D DSLR on a 4 day trip to San Francisco, and I was absolutely impressed.  Looking back at my images at a usable resolution (not 100% pixel peeping) I usually can't tell the difference between my $350 S95 and my $2000 7D with 15-85mm lens.  Of course, if I zoom in to 100% then the S95 definitely is noisier, less sharp, has more chromatic aberration, etc.  But it's all a reasonable compromise for the portability.The hardware is metal and rock-solid.  The controls are easy and intuitive to use, though there's a little bit of a delay compared to my DSLR.  The ability to shoot RAW is a godsend when editing photos.The S95 is the perfect backup to any DSLR.  Often I find that I don't carry my DSLR around because it's too bulky or I'm afraid of losing it.  This S95 is perfect!

Reviews.Title: The perfect compact camera (for now)
Reviews.Author: Cal Bear
Reviews.Content: I really think the only way this camera could be improved in the future is for it to decrease in size. Otherwise, it is the perfect camera (for me, for now). The pictures are incredible. I have been on a search for a camera that would have the following features:1. Wide angle (28mm)2. HD Video (and this has stereo mic)3. Good low light performance4. Fun random crap (miniature effect, color accent/swap, fisheye, etc)5. Small enough that I'd be willing to have it in my pocket 24x76. Time lapse!!This camera met all those needs (and more). Another bonus for me is that I also own the D10 (Canon's waterproof), and the S95 and D10 happen to share the same battery! This means I have a back-up battery for either camera when I travel, AND, best of all, I only need to carry one charger!Totally random info, but today I accidentally discovered a neat little feature on the S95: If you press and hold the "play" button (the button you press to view pictures) while the camera is turned off, it'll actually turn the camera on into view mode without opening/extending the lens. I'm sure this was stated in the CD manual (which is annoying, bc I'd much rather have a printed booklet), but I'm a guy and I don't like to read instruction manuals.Also, the fisheye effect will never get old for me. I can entertain myself for hours looking through photos of friends and family in fisheye mode. You actually get 3 different levels of fisheye effects to choose from (from not so fishy to very fishy). The miniature mode is cool, too.One of the more annoying things about the S95 (as some other reviewers have already mentioned), is how the time-lapse video mode can only be done with the miniature effect. I want just regular time-lapse, dammit. But, the fact that you have 3 different time-lapse speeds to choose from is pretty nifty.Overall, I have a feeling I will be owning this camera for a while.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera, specially in low light conditions
Reviews.Author: Josetron
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera to supplement my DSLR when having quick trips. I tested in Las Vegas taking pictures at night, the results are excellent! Never seen a compact camera that perform so well, black were black without noise and the camera in "P" mode can be adjusted to match the right level of light. What is also good on this camera is what you see in the screen is what turns out as picture... even the digital zoom seems to perform well under low light.The only issue I found so far is the flash popping up where you hold the camera (which is annoying some times), but I think it is a matter to learn how to hold it.Very happy so far.

Reviews.Title: Great pocket camera
Reviews.Author: Socalhawg
Reviews.Content: I got the S95 about 2 weeks ago and so far I really like it, it replaces my SD870is, I got this camera to use when my T2i is less convenient to carry with me, the quality fit and finish is very good, and has new features (special effects etc.) that I have to learn about, having said that, I find that because Canon does not include a owners manual it's a real inconvenience to download and print 200 pages of text, at $400 the book should have been in the box, my other complaint is that the wrist strap does not have a plastic slider to keep the camera from falling off your arm, so the stock strap had to be replaced, other than that I would recomend it.

Reviews.Title: You don't get SLR quality at this size anywhere else.
Reviews.Author: TriniMan "Neil"
Reviews.Content: Months of research and a year of use. This is the best camera i've ever owned.  I took back and S90 to buy this after already ruling out the alternatives people here have already mentioned.  It is very portable and small meaning you will take it everywhere.  This means, you'll use it more and take more photos.It's point and shoot size but it's no point and shoot camera. It takes SLR quality photos. The lens is incredible. The only downside, is if you plan to put it in auto and just shoot, not every photos is going to be perfect. You need to learn how to adjust setting based on your environment and the subject. Having said that, auto is still pretty incredible. If you want to maximise on this cameras potential, spend some time learning how to use it. You will never regret it, especially at this price. I paid almost $500 for it when it first came out.

Reviews.Title: Ideal every-where-you-go pocket camera for a pro photographer!
Reviews.Author: Ryan Katsanes Photography
Reviews.Content: I purchased a G11 back in May to be my always with me camera when not carrying my huge dSLR (5DM2 with grip).  Quite frankly I loved the G11 but it was too big to just throw in my pocket, and I secretly wanted an S90 for the same purpose.  Then in August 2010 Canon announced the S95 which dealt with many of the gripes folks have with the S90 and so I immediately pre-ordered one and put the G11 up for sale.I could not be happier with my decision.  Image quality is outstanding with the camera, as S90 owners can attest to, but the physical quality and the ease of use is fantastic.  I love the weight of the camera, the matte finish and the dials are top notch.  I really look forward to having this camera at the ready at *all* times!Bonus tip:  For those of you who can't import the RAW files due to the inevitable lage between release and 3rd party support, simply shoot in RAW + JPEG for now, and then delete the JPEGs later on when RAW is fully supported by your application of choice.Happy shooting!

Reviews.Title: Canon S95 Lens Error
Reviews.Author: S. Martin
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera December 2010, and only used it a few times. Everything seemed to work fine, except when I attempted zooming in on objects. I kept getting a "Lens Error" and the camera would shut off. It was under warranty and I sent it back for repair. First time it was not fixed, and was resent for repair. I just got the notice that it was fixed and shipped. We will see....):

Reviews.Title: Nice Camera
Reviews.Author: Cortina "LC"
Reviews.Content: I had the Canon S90 when it first came out and loved loved loved it so I was excited to see this newest updated version. I bought the Canon S95 recently on Amazon and I am not disappointed! The picture quality is the same, excellent, and the body is even better. I have not had any issues or problems with it. I don't particularly love where the flash pops up but honestly its a small inconvenience for the quality of photos you get out of this camera and I'll get used to it Im sure.  I'm still learning all of the functions, there are many, but all in all for portability and fantastic image quality this point and shoot rises to the challenge and may I say above the other Canons and Sonys Ive had.  FYI,  I recently ordered a screen protector for the LCD from Screen Patronus online and just put it on. Its a perfect fit for the S95. They only custom size to the model of camera you have and you get three. Totally worth the price for preserving your screen. Amazon customer service is stellar. Ive never had a problem that wasnt solved quickly.*UPDATE*Well, I have to backtrack a bit. First I am not a professional photographer but enjoy quality images and experimenting. I have an appreciation for photography and have a little knowledge in it. Also, I believe when it comes down to what is the best camera for you it takes experimenting a lot, and personal preference especially since both the LX5 and the S95 seem to be above and beyond others. I travel a good deal and want great photos. Having said that, after using the Canon S95 for a while I wasn't completely satisfied with the images overall. I used it in various lighting and conditions. They seemed to have a softness, albeit slight, that I couldn't get past. I shot with two different S95s and both produced the same results. My original S90 didnt have this issue. I don't know why. I used it the same way. This is simply what I experienced. While I had my S95 I had also been looking at reviews and specs for the Panasonic Lumix LX5. I took the plunge and returned the Canon recently and bought the Lumix. Ive never owned a Panasonic before. I'm even more impressed with the LX5. There was a noticeable difference in the image sharpness on Program mode, shadows seemed better and focus was crisp. For me, it feels more secure in my hand, the image quality is really exceptional( I think better than the S95 although I have not tried as many low light shots), and the color is rich but also can be natural. Also some the "My Color Mode" options are super! The lens is faster as well. It is a bit bigger than the S95 but for me I don't really "pocket" my camera most of the time anyways so it wasn't a deterrent. I usually have it in a belt pouch or in a bag. The Canon S95 is more pocketable and still produces images waaaaaay better than most out there, especially low light,  but I will be keeping the LX5 because so far, and I have not tried every function yet, it has won me over completely.

Reviews.Title: A great successor to the S90
Reviews.Author: Jason Phillips "Jason Phillips"
Reviews.Content: What a great camera and a great experience from the first photo you snap.  I fell in love with the S90 a few months back, practically ditching my Canon 5D Mk II whenever I needed a quick shot.  I started opting to travel light with only my S90 instead of lugging around the SLR and think I'm almost getting better shots.I've had the S95 for only a day now (I doubt anyone has had it any longer!), but improvements to the placement and function of the buttons, as well as access to the cable ports, is all considered and beautifully executed.The model designation is also more matte and subtle which seems like a new trend for Canon.

Reviews.Title: Awesome camera, but menus annoyingly slow
Reviews.Author: Eric
Reviews.Content: My Powershot S95 is an upgrade from a Powershot SD700IS, and overall I am very impressed. Especially the low-light performance is excellent. I was out taking pictures of my back yard at dusk, with no tripod and no flash, and with a +2/3 exposure compensation, it looked almost like daylight. I tried the same shot with my SD700IS (and another subcompact I was auditioning, with a smaller sensor and aperture) and neither came close to the amount of detail and clarity I got from the S95.  Since I don't like using flash unless it's absolutely necessary, there are a lot of times when performance under limited lighting conditions is important.I have many of the same gripes that others have mentioned in this forum, but most of them feel pretty minor to me. I've gotten used to holding it so my finger doesn't get in the way of the flash. And I'm already used to no auto-focus or optical zoom during movies, since the SD700IS did neither of those either.  Sure, I would prefer that it did those things, but I don't strictly *need* it to.  As far as I can tell after many hours of research (and auditioning a few candidates), this is the best subcompact camera you can buy at any price.  (I've read reviews of the Panasonic DMC-LX5, which sounds great; but it's not in the same size class, and is just too big for me to consider.)But my one serious gripe is a pretty big one: its lack of responsiveness to user input. For example, say you want to toggle the flash between Auto and Off, which I seem to do frequently (since this camera, like most others, often seems to want to flash under inappropriate circumstances). You push a key to bring up the menu, and then another key to cycle through the choices, and when you pause for a second or two, it accepts the setting you have stopped on. On my SD700IS, each key press was handled instantly, so once you're familiar with it, you could do it very quickly, and almost without looking. On the S95, it slides the menu into view, and this takes, I dunno, maybe 3/4 second. (It seems like an eternity, but I haven't measured it, this is just a guess.) And here's the kicker: IT DROPS ANY BUTTON PRESSES WHICH OCCUR WHILE IT'S ANIMATING THE MENU. So not only is it slower to operate, but also I have to pay more attention to it, so I can notice when it is ready to accept my next button press. What the heck?!I find this particularly disappointing, since it's a regression compared to a 4+ year-old camera from the same manufacturer. I find this particularly frustrating, because it seems like an arbitrary design choice they made, rather than some inherent limitation of the hardware (like, say, auto-focus speed). And I find it particularly surprising, since the S95 seems targetted at more sophisticated users, who are more likely to frown on fluffy menu animations, and just want something that works quickly with no fuss. I'm sure somebody thought this would look slick, and maybe it does to some. Who knows, maybe it even helps usability for some inexperienced users (though I doubt it). But THERE IS NO WAY TO TURN IT OFF. I have skimmed the entire manual, and walked all the config screens looking for it, but no dice. Even if the setting was buried deep in their config menus, that would have been enough for me. I'd only have to find it once.The other thing is that it pops up or retracts the flash as you cycle over the options, and this again causes a brief delay before you can move on to the next item. Besides making it slower, if you skip over your desired selection by accident, it may end up having to move the flash again, which causes more delay, and I don't like the idea of extra wear and tear on the mechanism. I suppose some usability guy thought it was better feedback to move the flash immediately, but I think this is too high of a price to pay, and seeing the highlight move between the selections on the LCD screen is perfectly adequate feedback.Some may pooh-pooh the importance of these seemingly short delays. I'm probably going to live for 77.6 years, so what's 3/4 second now and then? But anyone with kids or pets knows that every microsecond is crucial when you're trying to capture a moment. We have 15 cute chickens in the back yard, and they do not stop to pose for shots! Sure, you could say (and some have) that if I need super-quick responses, I should get a DSLR. But I must have a subcompact regardless, to take on trips, and I don't really want to spend an extra $500+ to own a DSLR on top of this. And besides this menu thing, I think the S95 is adequately responsive -- I've lived with the SD700IS for a few years, and have gotten used to it. The S95 is annoyingly close to being the perfect camera (for me).One last (unrelated) thing: I'm not sure why the auto-ISO selects such a high value sometimes. Recently it selected a high-enough ISO for there to be some quality degradation (I forget what it was, maybe 640 or something), and the exposure speed was 1/320th of a second, or something really quick. I'm no photography expert, and I may just be exposing my ignorance here -- but couldn't it have selected a lower ISO, with an exposure that was correspondingly slower, but still fast enough to avoid blurring from camera shake? Yes, there is a setting for this exact thing: how quickly it kicks up the auto-ISO. I tried changing it from "normal" to "low", and it did better in some cases; but in other cases, it didn't kick it up enough, and it selected an ISO so low that it needed an exposure so slow that it gave me the camera shake warning. So neither "low" nor "normal" is good for all circumstances. Why can't it just start with an exposure quick enough to not worry about shaking, and then choose whatever ISO is appropriate for that? (at least within some reasonable range of circumstances)  Yes, of course you can set the ISO manually, or use shutter speed priorty, and I have started doing just that -- but often I don't have time to fiddle with those settings, and it seems like its auto mode could be smarter about this stuff.I'm keeping it anyway, since (as long as you pay attention to the settings it's choosing, and sometimes override them) nothing else can touch it for image quality + compactness, and I generally like the Canon interface (other than the particular design blunder I've been ranting about). But I really really hope that Canon decides to fix the menu animations in a firmware update or something. And by fixing it, I mean adding an option to turn off the animations, or scrapping them altogether.

Reviews.Title: Excellent Point & Shoot - Leave the SLR at home
Reviews.Author: Michael Behnken "mike"
Reviews.Content: I rate the S95 4.5 stars so I will round up and give it a 5.  I primarily shoot w/ a Nikon D700 and over $4,000 worth of supplementary equipment but I wanted something more inconspicuous for taking candid shots quickly when the situation arise.  This is my first point-and-shoot since I bought the first 10mp one, the Casio Exilim and I must say I love this camera.For most shotsFor those who want to compare a point-and-shoot to an SLR this can do almost everything a SLR can do except (totally control depth-of-field, i.e. isolate subject & blur background), get ultra wide, or ultra tele (obvious), or get crisp extremely low light shots (i.e. night cityscape)Pros:-Easily Fits in any pocket-Great Photos in day and low light-Fun extra modes such as miniature and color replace, etc.-Battery lasts longer than expected (a whole day of shooting photos)-note:  videos burn battery a lot quickerCons:-Wrist strap is 1000% completely worthless-Range could be better (would like 24 on the wide end most but more tele would be nice too.-Mode Dial could have some better grip (difficult to turn when hands greasy or wet)-Nitpicky:  Battery fits in slot all 4 ways instead of 1 obvious way.

Reviews.Title: Amazing point and shoot
Reviews.Author: Omar Diab "Sebastian"
Reviews.Content: As an amateur photographer, I can say safely that the photos I've taken with this camera consistently look great. I take them around to random events at my university and on vacations, and the pictures from this camera, given decent lighting, rival those of my DSLR. The best parts? Not only is it so simple to use that my parents can use it, but it also has the robustness of controls of a manual camera, and it fits in my front jeans pocket. There are a number of things that make this camera far better than most other point and shoots--especially any point and shoot that is this size or smaller.First, the image quality in well lit situations is fantastic.  The sensor in the camera is far larger than most point and shoots, which leads to very good image quality. In general, there is very little noise and pixelation in images even at relatively high ISOs, and colors are represented very well.  In terms of raw image quality, I don't think there's a camera of the S95's size that rivals it.Second, the camera can open up it's aperature very large. I find this to be extremely useful as I think that flash--especially those on point and shoots--makes pictures look bad a lot.  One of the most common ways to make a picture look bad is if it's blurry, but that's not an issue for this camera, because the aperature can just open wide. It also allows me to take pictures with this camera that have a very shallow depth of field--a functionality I used to reserve for my DSLR.Third, the manual controls are pretty great. I really like how the ring around the actual lens is a control, mimicking a classic aperature ring.  This allows for natural manual use of the camera, and so I use it all the time for that purpose. The camera shoots to RAW as well, which is great.Finally, a bunch of random things.  The build quality feels good--no unstable parts, mostly metal casing.  Battery life is quite long, though I do have an extra battery just in case. And the screen and software on the camera itself are pretty good--not much of a pain to browse through a ton of pictures on a long vacation, since you can do things like organize pictures by date and jump 10 or 100 pictures at a time. And it's very simple to use, so even my parents are proficient at using it.In short, I love this camera, and it's by far the best point and shoot I have ever found. The only downside I can say is that it doesn't zoom very far--but if you get a camera that zooms farther, you will invariably be making a considerable tradeoff with image quality, and when zoomed in you'll probably take blurry pictures anyway (the more you zoom in, the more your hand shaking can affect a picture), so I don't see it as much of a downside. If you want a quality camera, your search should, for the time being, end here.

Reviews.Title: Excellent portable camera and adjunct to a DSLR, but get Franiec's aftermarket grip.
Reviews.Author: J. Gitzlaff
Reviews.Content: I got the S95 as a more portable adjunct to my DSLR (Canon 5D MkII) and I am very pleased with this little camera.  It is light-years ahead of the top of the line pocketable cameras of only a few years ago.  If you use the S95 properly (remembering basic rules of thumb for composition, lighting and so forth, and not just banging off ill-considered pics because you happen to have it in your hand) you really will be surprised what it can do.  Very responsive shooting, and the RAW images look great with minimal editing.  While the S95 can never replace my DSLR for versatility and solid results under demanding conditions, in ideal circumstances the S95's pictures sometimes rival the SLR's photos in quality much more closely than I ever would have expected.One thing to note - the ergonomics of holding this tiny camera leaves something to be desired.  Without a built-in grip, it's kind of like holding a dry bar of soap.  I bought an aftermarket solution - Richard Franiec's Custom S95/S90 Grip (search for it), and it really did wonders for the feel of the unit.  Much more comfortable, and I feel much less likely to lose proper grip or drop it outright.

Reviews.Title: LOVE THIS CAMERA!!
Reviews.Author: RobinM
Reviews.Content: I haven't taken pictures for almost twenty years but at that time I was a professional freelance photographer. I really wasn't sure I'd be able to enjoy and use a digital camera the way I did my old Canon F-1--figured that it would take too long to learn how to use it and that I wouldn't be able to do the sort of abstract, creative photography that I prefer.I've only been using the Canon S95 for less than a month and already I'm taking the same quality macro shots that I use to with my old 35mm. I've hardly used the  Auto modes at all, choosing instead to use the AV, (aperture priority), mode for my close-ups.Initially I was concerned that not having a viewfinder would be a stumbling block but I so much prefer standing back and composing the picture on the LCD screen that I don't think I would use the viewfinder if it had one. (My eyes don't focus close up like they use to and constantly cranking my neck to squint into a viewfinder use to get painful if I was doing a lot of shooting--especially if I was shooting at a low angle with the camera on a tripod.)I considered getting a DLSR but honestly one thing I never liked about my old F-1 was lugging around all that equipment--lenses, filters, huge tripod, etc.For my S95 I did buy a good small tripod which I pretty much use all the time when shooting macro--but that doesn't weigh me down at all. At some point I may get a DSLR but so far I don't feel like I'm missing anything and the fact that I can just walk out the door with this tiny, POWERFUL camera and tripod has allowed me to take a lot more pictures.I think this camera would be great for someone who's just getting into photography but knows they want to eventually do more than auto-shoot, and for someone like me who's returning after a long hiatus from photography.

Reviews.Title: What is the BEST camera?
Reviews.Author: Phodeaux
Reviews.Content: I am often asked: "What is the best camera?"My answer has always been: "The one you have with you!"The Canon S95 is a GREAT camera for its size and... It can ALWAYS be with you! The camera easily fits in a shirt pocket or purse and is always ready to deliver fine images. Many "Pro" photographers purchase this camera for "their wives", but most wives never touch it! I know many pros who carry around the S95 when it is not convenient to haul around an SLR with a bunch of lenses.When out for an evening I never bring my Canon SLR along, but am seldom without the S95. For a quick snap shot around a table to cityscapes from street level or building top, this little gem delivers amazing images. You won't enlarge the images to wall size, but up to 8.5 x 11 and even larger, the images hang on many walls.Needless to say I really do like this camera and I am sure you will too!

Reviews.Title: Canon s95
Reviews.Author: Frank B
Reviews.Content: I have a DSLR I don't take with me often because the size is not convenient.  The Canon S95 is perfect size for me.  It takes great pictures and the macro works perfect.  There is so much you can do with this small camera.  It's like having my DSLR with me without the bulk.  I have bought a few items from Amazon and still think it's a great company.  Thanks,  Frank Barreiro.

Reviews.Title: I feel like I'm cheating on my S90
Reviews.Author: Steven Micallef "Steve M."
Reviews.Content: Two weeks ago I was using my Canon S90 which I ordered before it came out.  I did not expect to be holding that camera's replacement 14 days later.  In fact, the previous weekend I was at dinner with a friend who has a Lumix LX-3 and I mentioned that that camera's successor was recently released.  Who knew the S95 would beat the LX-5 to owner's hands?After seeing the release on DPReview on the 19th, I investigated the camera further.  I though, wow it looks very similar to my S90.  I compared stats and saw that it was fractionally slimmer and the power and ring function buttons had swapped placement.  The most exciting thing I found on the S95...  I could actually use a neck strap with it!  I found holes on both sides, now I just have to find one that'll fit (Come on Canon, you couldn't put one in the box!).Well, my S95 arrived today and I was excited because I still had my S90 before I dropped it off at the post office to meet it's new owner.  I was happy to compare them side-by-side in person.In person, you'll notice the finish compared to the S90.  That camera feels like a bar of soap in the shower now compared to the S95.  The new finish feels much better. It reminds me of the Magnesium alloy they use on Valentine One radar detectors.  I don't know what they're using, but, good job Canon.  No more thumb rest, I was a little sad to see that go.  The control wheel has a much more damped movement now and not so free-spinning.The shutter button and zoom dial are redesigned, along with the mode dial getting a different texture.Also noticed that the screen doesn't have that purple anti-reflective coating look (when it's off) to it anymore.  It just looks nice and black.  Lastly, the color they used to paint on 'S95' on the front is a darker shade of grey than used before to paint 'S90.'  Same for the words around the lens.

Reviews.Title: My FAVORITE S-Series camera from Canon yet.
Reviews.Author: AP
Reviews.Content: The first rule of digital photography is you can only take a picture if you have your camera with you. The size of this is absolutely perfect for grabbing on your way out and taking pictures anywhere. This is the best camera I've ever owned. It has all of the manual settings I've come to expect in a larger camera and all of the sharpness and image capturing capabilities of a larger camera, too. I've previously owned the S30 and S80 - both of which had a larger form factor. I was a little skeptical that something so small could match them in clarity and color, but this one does. I'm glad that Canon decided to put a pixel-perfect 10 MP sensor in this rather than a less sensitive or noisier 12 MP sensor. It can take the best low-light photos I've ever seen without using the flash in a camera this size, but I often still opt for the flash indoors.My only complaints are small ones: first, the flash pops up right where most people hold the camera with their left hand. You are supposed to use the ring around the lens with your left hand, but most people don't know that when they pick it up the first time. Second, the dial to change shooting modes is a lot stiffer than the dials on either the S30 and S80, but I guess it has to be given the small size required to fit on the body.Regardless, I love this camera. I would buy it again in a heartbeat and I would recommend it to anyone who can afford the price and wants something a light-years ahead of a cheap point-and-shoot.

Reviews.Title: Flash malfunction
Reviews.Author: MP
Reviews.Content: I made the mistake of ordering this model although I had read about the flash problems on the Internet. When the unit is turned on, the flash pops up and it gives an error message: "Wrong flash position. Restart the camera" and the flash does not function anymore. I can still take photos without flash. If I pop down the flash and try to turn it on using the dial on the back, it gives the same error message. FOr me it is useless now. I do not live in the USA and getting is serviced is a hassle.

Reviews.Title: Best in Class- buy it before they're gone!
Reviews.Author: llisandro
Reviews.Content: GF lost her camera.
