I wanted to replace it with a micro 4/3rds, but she wanted to be able to put it in a small handbag when we went out, so I was resigned to a compact point-and-shoot (PAS).My Goal: Find the best camera that fits in a purse/pocket that will take good pics when you're out at night/in a place with sub-par lighting to stop your GF from uploading blurry pics to facebook or having her take crap pics at night with her iPhone that never come out well. (Spoiler: this is that camera).A lot of reviews suggested this is the best (truly compact) PAS. I decided to spend a bit more, as most PAS cameras I've had take crap photos and everyone has red eyes. The S95 is being replaced by the S100, but it was not available yet, and I needed to get it before xmas. I have no regrets, the S95 does everything I need, for less. The S100 upgrades you from 720p to 1080p video and you get 2 more MP. We shot videos on this and displayed it on a 50 inch 1080p flatscreen and they looked awesome. Good enough for me. Save the money and use it to get an extra battery or a bigger flash card.Verdict: It's hard to take a bad pic with this camera! It is the first I've had that is pretty much idiot-proof- set it to auto, hand it to a stranger and you get an amazing pic back. Really. Worth every cent. I no longer have any desire to get a micro 4/3rds- I am confident this camera can take great pics in a lot of situations and to get better than this, I'll just buy last year's DSLR offering.PROS:1. Pics look awesome. Seriously. We snapped pics at the Golden Gate bridge at DUSK alongside our friend with a Canon DSLR with a decent lens and the pics look shockingly comparable. I'm not disputing the power/control of a DSLR, but for the price and size of this thing you just cannot beat it. Indoor, outdoors, at a basketball arena. Everything we've tried so far looks good. I'm not a mindless drone, but I'm also not sitting for hours waiting to get the lighting just right. Seriously, just point the sucker and click.2. We always have it with us, because it's small! We've taken hundreds of photos and have yet to have a single red-eye. Even when the flash does come on. But on auto, the flash rarely comes on and pics still have tons of light.3. Battery life is not awesome, but we managed to take a hundred or so pics over an entire day on vacation. Good enough for me. Amazon sells a no-name battery that costs as much as a latte and has good reviews.4. It is small enough to put it in the back pocket of my jeans, but it's a pretty tight fit- would not fit in a woman's jean pocket. But it fits easily in a coat pocket or a clutch.5. Flash rarely pops up and you still get awesome pics.6. I like that is has "pro" features that give great control over your shots, so this camera can "grow" with you. It can shoot RAW, etc. But honestly, we haven't messed with it yet (only had it for a month) because you can just switch it to auto and it takes awesome pics without any composition or thought on your part.CONS:1. The pop-up flash. Annoying, took me a bit to get used to. Now I hold in such a way that when the flash DOES pop up, my finger is not in the way. But I'm afraid when we give it to a friend to take a pic of us, it's gonna pop up and scare them and they'll drop the camera. This flaw has been noted elsewhere, and has NOT been addressed in the S100.2. Comes with wrist lanyard, but you can't tighten the loop around your wrist for security. A three-cent piece of plastic would have made it a lot more secure if you wanna dangle it from your wrist while using your hands for something else.3. Doesn't have a lot of zoom. There is a panasonic lumix that has more zoom, but it doesn't fit in a clutch.

Reviews.Title: Great, but not perfect
Reviews.Author: Matt Spong
Reviews.Content: I bought this as an everyday carry camera for when my DSLR was impractical. I don't need to rehash what everybody else has said - for this purpose, it is excellent (perhaps the best on the market), but it is no replacement for a DSLR. Image quality can be close under the right conditions though (good lighting, essentially).After using it for a few weeks, the one issue that really sticks out is the blue channel performance under tungsten lighting. Some noise is to be expected here, but it is ATROCIOUS at ISO 1600 or above. Without serious post-processing, indoor non-flash photos are pretty unusable. If you stick to the wide end of the lens you can avoid this, but even at 50mm equivalent you're already limited to to f/3.2 and the long end is f/4.9. Maybe my D5000 has spoiled me, but it seems that the low-light performance of the S95 is a bit overstated.The pop-up flash, which most people seem to complain about, is actually a good thing. It moves the flash far enough from the lens that red-eye rarely happens. You need to turn the flash compensation down, though - on its own it uses too much power in most cases. If you really want to get creative, it can be turned down very low and still have enough power to trigger an optical off-camera slave. I haven't tried this in practice, but I've experimented and strobist-type tricks are definitely possible.All that said, I love this camera, and I'd buy it again in a heartbeat. It's on my belt 100% of the time, and that's the killer feature. Just don't expect perfection.

Reviews.Title: Awesome images. Lens error in a month.
Reviews.Author: Brandt
Reviews.Content: This is the best Canon compact I have had in about 3 years. Picture quality is awesome, and low light performance rocks. I will write more details later, but for now I am frustrated.I pulled the camera out of the case today to find the lens partially extended and the dreaded "Lens Error. Will shut down automatically. Please restart camera." Otherwise known as a E18 error. I've restarted the camera numerous times, and at no point has the motor made any noise, or has the lens moved. I can't say how frustrating this is. Mostly because I have become quite attached to this one is a short time, and it's part of my daily routine. I hope it'll be covered under warranty.. Updates to come.How about an option for resetting this error, or attempting to move the lens manually with the zoom control. Anything that would allow the user to troubleshoot this. I have to believe that things are set up to fail safe, and there is room for some trying. Otherwise Canon has a serious problem with lens extension mechanisms.

Reviews.Title: A lot of fun in a small package
Reviews.Author: princdi
Reviews.Content: I bought this as a gift for my husband.  It took him a few minutes to get use to it but he takes it with him everywhere.  I also bought the leather case that goes with it and he doesn't leave the house without it.  He is a professional photographer so he's used lots of cameras but I've never seen him so attached to one before.

Reviews.Title: Everyone wants my S95
Reviews.Author: M. Holt "Intrigued"
Reviews.Content: Absolutely everyone who sees the photos and movies I take with my S95 wants one.  I've sold at least 1/2 dozen for Amazon, just since November 10 when I got mine.  The low light pictures are excellent, the sharpness and color correction are professional quality, and the sound recording in movie mode is wonderful.  I'm just an amateur, but the large sensor size in the S95 makes my postings to youtube and Facebook look better than most, in fact if I get good at editing, they could easily compete with the pros.  I got this camera because my daughter's artwork deserved great studio shots, and this cam, with manual controls, lets me do that (at least when I've learned enough to get it right!).  I also required RAW mode for future fun with software editing in digital mode.OK, one feature I'd like to see added is continuous focus in movie mode.  It's possible to work around that, and I do, but could save some time setting up an action video.  A super feature is the fast startup and cycle time between shots.  I can react to a photo op fast enough to capture what others often don't even see as a picture.  My old-school training in shooting journalistic style, means I'm not interested in super zoom or long shots.  I want to frame a good photo, that speaks for itself, is pleasing to look at, and can stand up over time.  It's up to me to frame it and get the timing right, but I need a great tool to create a shot nice to view that will still look good years from now.Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera with 3.8x Wide Angle Optical Image Stabilized Zoom and 3.0-Inch inch LCDCanon has hit a homerun this time, and I'm excited to own my new camera.

Reviews.Title: A Leap in P&S; Camera Abilities
Reviews.Author: Iseephotos "scwoodworker"
Reviews.Content: This is my first Amazon product review. I have just never felt the need to comment before but with this camera I just had to. A little background - I am an amateur photographer; meaning that I just do it for fun, not to make a living. I have a Canon DSLR and several lenses that I use all the time. But something was missing in my photographic arsenal. Sometimes it was inconvenient to carry the SLR and I was missing potentially great images that I would happen upon just during everyday life. A solution would be a pocket "carry around" camera and a month ago I started looking around for one.After 4 weeks of research and reading copious reviews the Canon S95 emerged as the best because it had the most features that I desired and looked to be the best value for the money. Here is my summary:Pros:- Amazing image quality- Easy to learn controls (especially if you have other Canon cameras)- Solid construction (metal, not plastic - wow!)- Fits nicely into my shirt pocket (important for me)- An astonishing range of capabilities- Great low light performance- Wheel and ring work wonderfully to change settingsCons: (these are very minor)- Price! (I paid 399.99 I now see it is down to 388.83 but you are getting a lot for your money)- The pop up flash has caught me a few times even though I knew of this issue before I bought the camera (Old habits of holding cameras this size die hard)- OK, I admit I am old school - I like a printed operations manual that I can carry with me. Canon (probably to save money) provides the manual on a CD with this camera. The S95 does so many things I need the manual to reference when I need it during this learning curve. So only getting the manual on a CD is a negative to me (Are you listening Canon? If you can't provide it with the camera maybe you could sell the printed manual as an extra? I would buy one!).Overall I am extremely pleased with this camera.  It has fit the "bill" perfectly for what I wanted and I would recommend it to anyone who has a DSLR but is looking for a "carry around" camera or even to those who do not. It would be a great "step up" for those moving toward the DSLR world.Buy it, you won't be disappointed.

Reviews.Title: Great camera
Reviews.Author: Joel Cleare
Reviews.Content: I needed an excellent point and shoot to complement my canon 60d dslr. I went with the s95 over the s100 because of the mixed reviews on the s100. I've used the canon G12 in the past and thought it was a great camera. I've read and tested for my self and found the s95 takes the same pictures as the G12.  I shoot in manual (M) and RAW and this camera performs great. I set the short cut button to ISO for ease of use.

Reviews.Title: Better than the s100!
Reviews.Author: Richard Vargas
Reviews.Content: I purchased the S100 and was not pleased with the image quality...looks like they tried to improve what was not broken.  Returned it and purchased the S95, love it!

Reviews.Title: The perfect compromise...  for me
Reviews.Author: Peter de Rooij
Reviews.Content: The perfect camera does not exist.  There is no camera with the control and quality of a medium format technical camera, the versatility, handling, low light performance and responsiveness of a DSLR, and with the ease of use,  size and cost of a point and shoot.  So the name of the game is compromise.  You will have to sacrifice some less important features to get the ones that are important to you.I already have a nice DSLR, but have found it has one big drawback.  It is too big and heavy, and too conspicuous to have on me all the time.  So I miss shots because it is at home.  To fill that gap, I wanted a small (truly pocketable) camera, with good quality, decent low light performance, and most of the control that my DSLR gives me.  The S95 perfectly fills that gap.Pros:- small and light (easily slips in a trouser or shirt pocket)- excellent picture quality in most circumstances- decent low light performer, helped by image stabilisation and an f/2.0 lens (though only at wide angle)- shoots RAW, and has all the controls I need (PASM modes, plus the usual scene modes)- clever controls, such as the dial around the lens make up for a shortage of dedicated buttons- good 720p HD videoCons:- small (so hard to hold well)- short battery life- no focusing and only digital zoom during video- no viewfinder (which would help better framing)- not as fast or responsive as a DSLR (obviously)Competitors like the G12 (which has the same sensor), P7000 and LX5 reduce these drawbacks.  But they're bigger, and would be at home much more often.  Which is why the S95 is the best compromise for me.  Together with a DSLR it does almost all I want, and the overlap (where both work fine) is remarkably big!

Reviews.Title: Great camera.. until it breaks from lens error every time.
Reviews.Author: Michael A. Bobrowski
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera 2 times. The 1st time it broke due to a lens error (mgf. issue) . Bought another one, it did the same thing. Sent it to Canon for repair and the camera broke again within 2 months. Now using as a paperweight since it's totally worthless.

Reviews.Title: Watch out for that motorized flash
Reviews.Author: Gadget Gizmo Freak "Gadgetfreak"
Reviews.Content: Great camera except:It looks somewhat delicate. The flash is not a pop-up but actually a motorized pop-up. What that means is that a button controls when the flash comes out of the body and even when it goes in by a button or menu. So the flash is motorized and not a trigger/spring loaded mechanism. This is bad because I tend to hold the camera with a finger on the top left surface where the flash is supposed to pop-up. And when the flash does pop-up, it does it by actuating a motor which bzzz's the flash to come outside and many times my finger comes in the way which may eventually break the pop-up flash mechanism of this camera.Whats even worse is that the flash will not go in by pressing the flash into the body. It will go in when you turn the camera off or through some menu buttons. So dont give your camera to a stranger who will take your picture and try to push back the flash by force. I think that would be the end of the flash. This is a major flaw.If you are planning to buy this camera then you probably already know that this camera is the best picture quality point&shoot; camera in the market.

Reviews.Title: Love it . . . BUT
Reviews.Author: E. Martin
Reviews.Content: I love this camera. It takes some gorgeous pictures. I usually shoot with a very expensive DSLR but needed a small point and shoot to take with me when I go hiking or on a bike ride. I've tried many different cameras but this one takes the clearest pictures. I've posted some of my pictures above for you to see for yourself. However (and this is a big one), I have been getting the dreaded "lens error" and the camera will just shut off. This lens error makes it so that I can not zoom - AT ALL. As a semi-professional photographer, I know that zooming isn't the best thing to do anyway. So, I move closer whenever possible. But, there are times when I wish I could get closer with the zoom and I can not. If the camera is asked to move the lens in any way (other than to turn on or off), It will give an error message and it will shut off. The camera does work when I turn it back on, but I really don't know how long I have before my beloved camera will never turn on again.Now you can use this information to make an informed decision. Get a great camera and takes some great pictures. But be forewarned, you may have problems with your lens.

Reviews.Title: A great buy, especially at the closeout price
Reviews.Author: photogeezer
Reviews.Content: After several false starts trying to cheap out with other super-compacts, I settled on this outgoing model, because the "latest and greatest" S100 offers nothing I need. First, the clean images and sharpness I am getting are unbelieveable. Grab shots at a party in the Auto everything mode are sharp and relatively noise-free.  For more serious scenic stuff I am using the AV Mode with the lowest possible ISO.Don't be put off by the 10 Megapixels. Ten is plenty, and the 12, 14, 16 are probably interpolated up, anyway.I gave the S95 five stars because it does well what a camera does. While I generally dislike the over-miniaturization that seems to plague the industry, I bought the S95 especially for it's small size. I knew I could have gotten the same sensor and lens with a G-series camera. I can't pick the S95 up without tripping the Playback button, but a Franiec or Flpback stick-on grip will help you get a good hold on it. Also, use the wrist cord. It's all too easy to drop this little guy.All controls are intuitive, and the S-button and outer ring can be customized to your liking. Be sure to turn OFF Image Stabilization when placing the camera on a flat surface for self-timer shots. If you forget to do this, you'll have a reason for blurry shots. If you don't like the cartoonish Kandy Kolors in the default color settings, tune it down to Natural OR shoot raw and process in a decent imaging program.Put up with its few annoyances for the image quality. It is that good.

Reviews.Title: Great second camera for the DSLR owner
Reviews.Author: Chicago Book Addict
Reviews.Content: By a way of background, I spend most of my time shooting with my Olympus Evolt E510 10MP Digital SLR Camera with CCD Shift Image Stabilization and 14-42mm f/3.5-5.6 and 40-150mm f/4.0-5.6 Zuiko Lenses and while I like the camera a lot, I was finding it too large and cumbersome to take with me for casual outings.  I found myself using it primarily at home for food photography for my blog, but very little outside of that.Because of that, I wanted a smaller camera that would fit in my pocket, but would still have very good photo quality and would allow me to shoot with a high level of control over my settings, much as I do with my DSLR.  However, I still wanted it to be able to take good pictures in auto mode for those times when I'm too lazy to adjust for my shot or want to hand my camera to someone else.Initially I was deciding between getting a point and shoot or getting a micro four thirds camera like the Olympus PEN E-PL1 12.3MP Live MOS Micro Four Thirds Interchangeable Lens Digital Camera with 14-42mm f/3.5-5.6 Zuiko Digital Zoom Lens (Black), which is at a similar price point.  Originally I had been strongly considering the E-PL1 because I liked that with an adapter I could use my existing Olympus lenses on this camera, but dislike that in order to get one in a similar price range as a higher end point and shoot that I would have to buy the flash separately.Eventually after reading many reviews on Amazon and consumer electronics sites I decided on this camera and am very happy I did.  For a point and shoot the picture quality is very good and I am often happy with the results even when shooting in automatic mode. For example, I've been getting some great shots of my dog, which isn't easy since he's black so there isn't a tremendous amount of contrast.  I've also gotten some really great photos in low light settings.  Recently I took pictures in some caves while on vacation and when comparing the photos of this camera to those of my friends there was a noticeable difference.The zoom is perfect for my needs and the quality of the pictures has been good.  I'm also really enjoying the interface of the camera.  It is very easy and I find it quite easy to adjust my shutter speed and aperture.  The size is also great.  It is certainly not as small as some of the other digital cameras on the market, but MUCH better than a DSLR.  I have no problem tucking it into a pocket or putting it in my purse which has been great.  I'm now taking it out much more often and getting a lot more candids.There are only a couple of things I don't care for with this camera.  The first is the absence of a viewfinder.  Having the screen in the back is fine, but sometimes can be a bit delayed and is a bit challenging to get used to after shooting with a viewfinder for so long.  I really wish that this camera had a viewfinder as well even if it made it slightly larger.  I'm also not a huge fan of the styling of the camera.  Yes, this is subjective and has no bearing on the quality of the camera, but it does look a bit dated and inexpensive even though in reality it is a great point and shoot.Overall, I'm very happy with it.  Granted it's been a month at this point so I'm curious to see how it will hold up over time and how I'll like it as I continue to use it more and more, but after having it for a month I'm quite satisfied so far.

Reviews.Title: HD video works well for a P&S;
Reviews.Author: DH
Reviews.Content: I've had the camera for a month or so and purchased it to be a point & shoot with extra controls like my dSLR.  You can find hundreds of reviews online for its photographic capabilities but I wanted to mention the video capabilities.  I've taken a few impromptu HD videos with it and have been pleasantly surprised at the resulting video and sound quality.  I didn't have huge hopes for that aspect of it as I'm used to my Canon S11 camcorder which has been great but the S95 actually doesn't do too bad.  The pictures are crisp and clear and more surprisingly, the sound quality is good too.  I've been at a few concerts where video equipment wasn't allowed (oops) and brought the S95 in in my pocket and I've taken video of songs that, watching them later on my computer, came out sounding really well with reasonable bass reproduction that I'm not used to hearing result from a little point & shoot camera microphone.

Reviews.Title: Best point-and-shoot... hands down!
Reviews.Author: Sophia Kontaridis
Reviews.Content: I bought the S95 as a replacement for an Olympus Tough camera.  I was tired of the poor image quality of the Olympus and decided to look for a flagship model.  I definitely found it!  This camera is top-notch.  You can easily shoot dSLR quality photos with this camera, not to mention it fits easily in your pocket.This camera is loaded with features including full manual control.  As a photo enthusiast who also shoots with a dSLR, it is awesome to be able to have the same capabilities in my point-and-shoot.Also, a large plus is the ability to shoot RAW.  I have also purchased an Ikelite underwater housing and accessories to use this camera while SCUBA diving.  For this use, RAW is a must.  With this camera you can shoot professional level UW photos without breaking the bank by purchasing a housing for a dSLR.I can not say enough good things about this camera.  You will not be disappointed!One last note... when giving the camera (in auto-mode) to a stranger to take a picture, make sure you warn them about the pop-out flash.  I have had people almost drop the camera when the flash popped out in low-light settings!

Reviews.Title: 5-Star Small Camera - get book to go with
Reviews.Author: Eileen Westgate
Reviews.Content: The S95 is fantastic. I have owned this camera for 6 months. I will avoid repeating its praises already posted by others. Ignore the negative reviews. If you want to take with ease gorgeous, high quality images using a camera which fits in your pocket buy the Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera with 3.8x Wide Angle Optical Image Stabilized Zoom and 3.0-Inch inch LCD and the book Photographer's Guide to the Canon PowerShot S95: Getting the Most from Canon's Pocketable Digital Camera by Alexander S. White.If you know absolutely nothing about photography, set the S95 on auto and start shooting and you will get great shots and satisfactory video too. If you read and follow White's book, you will learn photography and you will be amazed at all the features you have with this camera.A tripod is recommended for using neat features like Fireworks mode and video. And at least one extra battery.Finally, if you get an Eye-Fi Pro X2 8 GB Class 6 SDHC Wireless Flash Memory Card EYE-FI-8PC you can transmit your photos to your device like an iTouch to go directly on-line.I love this camera. My travel pack has my S95 w/ its charger, 2 batteries, my iTouch and its charger, my eye-fi card + an SD card. What a great feeling to know you can go anywhere totally prepared for fantastic photography + video, carrying a tiny package, NO bulky heavy equipment.

Reviews.Title: Best small camera on the market?
Reviews.Author: honmaya
Reviews.Content: I am by no means a camera expert or a photographer, but I do like to listen to their opinions when buying cameras. The S95 was reviewed very positively, and after having used it for 5 months, I can say that it's even better than what I expected.First, it was much smaller than I thought it would be. Reading the dimensions is one thing, but when you actually are able to hold this camera, you can truly appreciate how portable it really is, about the size of a pack of cigarettes would be about right. It is very, very solid, you can tell that it was built to last and the finish is very understated, which is what I prefer. One thing about the size though, if you have large hands, it may be challenging to grip the camera comfortably each time, especially when you are trying to do it quickly.The picture quality is I think outstanding. I'm sure the pictures would look even better if I knew how to properly take pictures, but using the P mode, the images look natural and great pretty much every time. Despite being on the lower side in terms of megapixels, the images have a good amount of detail, and with the fast lens, low light pictures have significantly better results. There is also aperture and shutter priority modes, so you can experiment, or even use full manual. The lens is very flush to the body, and will jut out when the camera is on and ready to take pictures. But what I thought was a cool feature was the adjustable ring around the lens, you can set this to do one of several functions, and it works very well.Overall an excellent camera and an excellent value.

Reviews.Title: The BEST compact camera out there...
Reviews.Author: ppp
Reviews.Content: I was worried about the price but its worth every penny. Did all my research and looked around and this definitely is clearly the best camera out there as of 4/1/2011. Low light photos are the best. I haven't seen indoor low light pictures this beautiful before. Was thinking of a DSLR but felt its not worth the learning curve nor the bulky size. If you can get that DSLR quality at a fraction of the size and complexity, who wouldn't prefer the compact. Finally, great choice and its my Best purchase ever. Go Canon.Note: Don't get fooled by 10.0 MP while you see 15MP one's out there. That's all a myth. Goto dpreview etc and research about the megapixel myths. When you go to a store, look at the f/2.0 numbers and there isn't one out there in a compact camera that's close to 2.0.  Lot's of 2.5's and 2.3.

Reviews.Title: Canon S95 - Great pocket camera
Reviews.Author: Christie Smith
Reviews.Content: I have many (too many) digital cameras, but none that I could take with me all the time, until now.  Just returned from 2-week European trip and have found that most of my S95 pictures are better than those from my bigger and more expensive camera (which I have loved for over a year). I finally only used the bigger camera (with big zoom) when I needed the telephoto.  The S95 is a great size, comfortable to use and easy to learn.  The images (using mostly P) are clear, bright, colorful, stable.  The night scenes amaze me!  Glad I got it!Amazon service was fine, and delivery timely.

Reviews.Title: You can stop looking, this is the camera for you!
Reviews.Author: Emily K. Hoover
Reviews.Content: We purchased this camera when our SLR fell in a stream. We were in the market for a new small camera but wanted the quality that SLR will give you but didn't want to spend the money on a new SLR yet. This camera takes incredible photos. It is great for someone like me who likes to just point and shoot, and also my  husband who likes to use all features of this camera. It is fairly light weight, but a little longer than most cameras. It fits great in the purse or your pocket. The battery charges quickly and you can get a long time with it. I highly recommend this camera to someone looking for a small camera with great potential. I hope this review helped make your decision easier, I know how frustrating it can be reviewing a million camera reviews.

Reviews.Title: Amazing pictures
Reviews.Author: S. Ghosh
Reviews.Content: I never write reviews. I am writing this one because this camera produces most amazing images and I felt I had to let other people know how great is this camera.  The image quality under some situations comes close to my Nikon D300 camera that costs including lens about $3,000.  It allows you great degree of manual adjustments, and most importantly the picture resolution is just unbelievable.

Reviews.Title: This does everything I've wanted it to do.
Reviews.Author: K. W. Rudd
Reviews.Content: My high-end camera is a Canon 5DMII, but I often find that it's not really practical to pack around on vacations or on local walks.  I wanted to pick up a good quality pocket camera that I could use for those times that I wanted to travel light.This camera has been absolutely wonderful so far.  The quality of the shots I'm getting from it are good enough that I am considering leaving the 5D at home in more situations.  We picked ours up just before a family trip to Disneyland so that my wife and I wouldn't be fighting over her camera (since I didn't want to be lugging the 5D all around Disneyland).  We were both blown away with the quality of the low-light shots we were able to get with such a small camera.  An example of some of the shots we were able to capture with this camera can be found in the following webshots album: [...]Pros: * Does real well in low light. * Can save photos in RAW mode for later fine-tuning. * Full manual controls * Great control ring around the lens (I find it most useful for controlling the zoom) * Incredibly portable (no trouble at all packing this camera around)Cons: * The only downside to this camera is the speed at which it takes/saves photos.  It seemed as if I went from 3.9shots/second with the 5D to 1shot/3.9seconds with the S95 ;).  It forced me to wait for the best angle/shot instead of snapping off an early insurance shot like I tend to do with my 5D.  Not a killer, but it did cause me to miss some good shots during my early experiments.

Reviews.Title: A magnificent pocket camera
Reviews.Author: Nick "whereishawkins"
Reviews.Content: I got rid of my Powershot G10 because it wasn't pocketable. I wanted something that shot RAW (because I'm anal retentive about processing photos) and that was somewhat fast. The Powershot S90 came out, and I waited because it didn't come with 720p video capabilities.I'm glad I did. I love my S95. The f/2 lens is great - where my G10 failed in low-light, the S95 succeeds. I don't notice noise creeping into the photos until about ISO 800, but it's there. However, for a $400 p/s camera, it doesn't merit comparison to a proper SLR.Getting used to the ring control wasn't that bad - it was just new for me to have to use my left hand to take photos with a p/s camera. If you've used a Canon before, there's virtually zero learning curve. The surface has been changed from the S90, which didn't lend itself to making you feel like you have a solid grip on the camera. This feels solid and won't slip out of your hands.There are a few downsides worth mentioning. In-camera HDR isn't too bad, but for some reason (maybe this is just me) but it chooses high ISO photos to use for processing and thus, you've got noisy HDR photos. In well-lighted conditions, it's great and a nice little gimmick.Also, the downside of the camera shooting RAW is that you have to wait until RAW codecs are available for both OS X, Windows and third party processing applications. I'm a slave to Lightroom, and I'm waiting for that to be updated. If you're like me, you'll set it to shoot RAW+JPG until LR/ACR is updated, then just delete the JPGs.The choice for me was the S95 vs the G12, and I'm glad I made the right choice. Naturally, this isn't my SLR, but the size and features make it great for me to use when I can't bring a large camera along.

Reviews.Title: Great little camera
Reviews.Author: bmf_tway
Reviews.Content: This is a great little camera I can take anywhere.  Just got it today and haven't really put it through all the test but so far I am loving the picture quality.  I think it's better than my G11 that I sold recently.  It was just too big to carry around and I much rather carry my SLR if it's the case.  This thing is so small I can put it in my pant pockets unlike the G11.  I now have a camera I can take anywhere and have good quality shots.  High iso is great especially with the hybrid IS.  Low light shots are sharp with the new IS.  With the G11 I would have not gotten the shots.  It would have been pretty blurry.  Love the matte finish as it keeps it from slipping from my hands.  I will update more once I get some more time with it but loving it so far.

Reviews.Title: This camera takes amazing pics for a point and shoot!!
Reviews.Author: Bob
Reviews.Content: I paid full price $399 a year or so ago. At the price listed now... WOW... that's a great deal! It takes amazing pictures, is very well made (metal not plastic) and has a ton of settings. I'm not disappointed I paid full (at the time you couldn't even find them) price, but envious of all you getting one for $239. Overall, I have nothing negative to say about this camera.

Reviews.Title: 2nd bad experience in a row with Canon PowerShot models
Reviews.Author: George C
Reviews.Content: I've been a loyal Canon PowerShot owner since 2003, with the S95 being my 5th such Canon compact point-and-shoot camera in a row. I loved the first 3 models, and their early demises were all my fault (dropped 2 in water, and had a 3rd one stolen from my checked luggage en route to Costa Rica...lesson learned). I loved the high quality and reliability of the pictures, and the small size made for an ideal vacation camera. I was more likely to take the PowerShot everywhere I went which meant more opportunities for great pictures, as opposed to lugging around a larger, more advanced model that I couldn't slide in my pocket.However, the sx210is (the 14x optical zoom was the big selling point for me) was my first big disappointment - it had a very long shutter lag, and its auto-focus repeatedly failed to deliver. I missed countless shots during a trip to South America because either the camera took too long to fire after pressing the button, or the picture would be severely blurred because the camera would fire before the auto-focus was able to finish its job. It was a huge step backwards in reliability and quality from the earlier models.I recently purchased the s95 to replace the disappointing sx210. After working fine for 3 weeks, it started "freaking out". Newly charged batteries would drain very fast (within an hour) even while the camera was powered off. The flash seemed to be at the core of the issues - it ceased to extract itself when needed (yes, the flash setting was on "auto"). Furthermore, the camera would completely freeze/ lock-up when the flash eventually did pop-up. I couldn't even turn-off the camera, as the On/Off button was unresponsive - I had to wait for it to power-down on its own, after the which the problem above persisted if the flash was involved. Finally, an error message stating "flash in incorrect position, restart camera" would occasionally pop-up, even when the flash was in the closed position.Needless to say, I've placed a warranty call to Canon and am sending the camera in for warranty service. Regardless, it's disappointing to have had separate issues with my two most recent PowerShot purchases after having been happy with this line for so long. Hopefully this is not a new downward trend in product quality from Canon. But after 2 disappointments in a row, I'll likely be looking at other brands for my next camera purchase.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: Benjamin Cole
Reviews.Content: I pre-ordered the S95 and am very happy with it.  I'm not a professional photographer but someone who is becoming more interested in photography and wanted a camera that I can learn on.  I had an old Powershot A620 and the size of the S95 is great in comparison.  It fits into my pocket or shirt sleeve comfortably.  I've no complaints about the ergonomics (as it was a concern with the S90) and find the controls easy to use and adjust.I went to my buddy's wedding this past week and took something like 800 photos in a variety of settings / lighting.  The photos in good light are absolutely amazing.  The ones in low light are good, provided there isn't a lot of motion. (Although still way better than any of my friends' cameras could manage.)I did buy a generic extra battery and glad I did.  Firing the flash for some indoor shots really killed the battery.Also, the HDR mode is really impressive.All and all, I'm very happy with this camera.

Reviews.Title: World's Best Compact Camera
Reviews.Author: cscTulsa
Reviews.Content: I Purchased the s95 over the Panasonic LX5 and the s90 after a bit of deliberation. Decided on the s95 after hours of reading reviews and doing some serious soul searching :) A couple of days after it arrived I left for an 8 day trip to eastern Europe. I also took my Canon DSLR on the trip. After seeing the ease of use, image quality, and benefits of a compact, I took a total of 2 pics with the DSLR and over 800 with the s95. The camera is unbelievable. With a few minor in camera setting 'tweaks' I had better contrast, more vivid colors and more convenience than lugging around my cumbersome DSLR. the $400 was a bit much to swallow at first, but once I saw how well the camera works and the quality of construction I see the $400 as a bargain compared to $1500+ for a new DSLR. As far as the way I shoot travel pics I like to be ambiguous and a bit stealth, and my DSLR just doesn't let me shoot that way. I truly enjoyed my trip much more by being able to slip it into my pocket, snap a great perfectly exposed shot and then move on. No bulky straps, extra lenses, or giant tourist flag hanging around my neck. Awesome, awesome camera. Set up the various shooting modes the way you like them depending on where/what you're shooting and this little sweetie will blow your mind.

Reviews.Title: The best point and shoot out there.
Reviews.Author: Drew Bruckner
Reviews.Content: At least when I bought it it was. I know that for a fact because I actually had many of the other ones before returning them. this one takes the best photos by far. they are crystal clear and they have quality comparable to a DSLR. I traveled all over Europe with this and it handled the trip like a pro. Don't get sucked in by the other cameras with their "400X ZOOM!!!" Generally, it's just digital zoom which is the same as taking the picture and zooming in on it in paint. Plus, after a certain zoom, the picture distorts slightly. This one is made for function, not just to attract window shoppers.

Reviews.Title: Repairs
Reviews.Author: mark
Reviews.Content: We had our Canon Powershot S95 approximately two years with average use. The shutter suddenly wouldn't open. The standard repair charge by Canon is $149 plus $11 shipping for a total repair cost of $171. A new camera costs $355. You make the call. Our next camera probably won't be a Canon.

Reviews.Title: Better than the S100
Reviews.Author: roser
Reviews.Content: I had the Canon S95 prior to buying my S100.  I loved the S95 and sold it right after getting the S100, figuring the S100 would be a superior camera. I think the photo quality is slightly better with the S95.  The S100 photo quality is still excellent, and has some some features that I'd use once in a rare while, like high framerate photography.  I thought the GPS would be useful for geotagging photos when I upload them to facebook, but I can rarely get a GPS signal, and when I have the GPS on the battery drains really fast.  If you can pick up a S95 for $100+ cheaper than the S100, I encourage you to do so.

Reviews.Title: Excellent small camera for a range of users
Reviews.Author: Akamai22
Reviews.Content: I am a life-long photo hobbyist with a couple of high-end Nikon DSLR and SLR cameras and a dozen Nikkor lenses, so I have clearly tried to spend my way to good pictures.  My primary subjects are fast moving grandsons.BUT, it has always been a pain to lug that stuff around, and I find myself less and less willing to deal with all the weight, bulk and possible theft issues.So I bought the S95 "for my wife"; she loves it but I use it too and I think the fact that it's useful to both of us is really amazing.  She wants to point and shoot and to plug it straight into a PICT Bridge printer.  This cameral does all this very well, as others have noted.What amazes me about the S95 is how useful I find it... the lens is pretty fast and the colors are excellent to my eye.  The manual controls are easily learned; focusing is reasonably fast in most circumstances and the focus ring is very useful.The size is amazing and since "the best camera is the one you have with you" I get good photos in what would otherwise be "cell phone or nothing" situations.I thought it was a good value when I bought it; it's nearly $100 cheaper today.The only negative is that there isn't a lot of room for my big hands but that's not Canon's fault.I really don't see how you can go wrong with this camera.

Reviews.Title: Perfection with qualifications
Reviews.Author: K. Mulcahy
Reviews.Content: The Canon S95 takes stunning pictures that are way beyond my expectations, just like most other owners have reported.  In the basic mode I use, I simply can't believe how good the picture look.  I take a lot of landscapes, gardens, street scenes and detail closeups and am strictly amateur.I could gush all day, but people are probably more interested in the few flaws I can perceive at my non-professional level. First is the instructions, which are only available on a disk.  This camera is fortunately fairly intuitive but to use any of the higher features you need to be reading the manual which I'm not willing to print out and lug everywhere.  I also don't like that they use vocabulary appropriate for professional/advanced photographers, who wouldn't need to use the manual much anyway.  Ultimately, I may or may not advance beyond the basic level.The camera tends to make things very colorful, which I happen to like, but when adjusting the pics (very few need adjusting compared with my old old Olympus digital) I once in a while have to turn the color saturation down.  I'd rather have it be this way than have the pics come out too drab.  I'm amazed at the quality of pics I can get outdoors in the middle of the day under blazing sun.Speaking of adjusting pics, I am very pleased with the Digital Photo Professional editing program that comes with the camera.  You can resize, tilt, adjust all aspects of color, hue, contrast, sharpness, etc.  I'm not interested in the complications of Photo Shop and there's really no need.  In fact, I frequently find after diddling with the adjustments I prefer the shot exactly as the camera took it.  Probably the most common adjustment I make after re-sizing and cropping is to up the contrast on overcast outdoor shots a small tick or two.One reason I chose this model is because you can set it to focus manually.  I thought I needed this because my old camera took so many out-of-focus shots and there was no manual focus.  The S95 is so good with focus, I never even bother with the manual focus.  The viewfinder shows you what the camera is focusing on, and if that's not what you want, you just half-depress the shutter button again for a different focus option.  Very cool.  Even in non-macro mode, and without a tripod, I get very close up shots of flowers that are startling in their clear detail when blown up.Some have said the camera body is slippery or flimsy.  I think it feels very substantial for something so small, and the grip feels quite secure.  Of course, you need to get used to how to hold it.Others have rightly said that a LCD viewfinder is impossible to use outdoors on a very bright day.  I did get used to not looking through a real viewfinder pretty quickly, but the LCD screen on this camera requires an act of faith when shooting on a bright sunny day.  Have to say that usually the faith is rewarded.  I can't say much that's helpful about indoor shots, because I don't take many, but when I do they look fine.  Outdoor shots at twilight are very beautiful.  I don't use the video mode.For my last nit-pick, I signed up for the Emails to customers, and have been pretty disappointed.  I was hoping for good tips and info about using the camera better.  Instead, it's just routine marketing.  Well, maybe with a camera this good they can coast on the non-essential stuff.  I'd buy this camera again in an instant and be grateful for the opportunity.

Reviews.Title: Awesome compact camera
Reviews.Author: Anand
Reviews.Content: I was searching for a compact camera which can deliver close to DSLR quality snaps.After doing lot of research I finally bought Canon S95, it is amazingly compact and captures excellent images.5 Stars to this product. It might not look good on paper as compared to other cameras at this cost as it has only 10 MP, 3.8X Zoom, 720p video, however when image quality is compared it's simply best.

Reviews.Title: For the professional photapher
Reviews.Author: Mariela R. Flores
Reviews.Content: For the professional photographer that does not want to carry their big dslr everywhere this is the "point and shoot" camera to get.

Reviews.Title: Best point and shoot out there
Reviews.Author: sabst79
Reviews.Content: This is my first P&S; camera.  I have Nikon DSLRs and decided to get a smaller camera for days when I don't want to take the Nikons with me.  I've played w/ a few different P&S; cameras and this one is by far the best.  Picture quality is amazing, and the different options are great.  This is definitely not a camera for anyone who just uses the auto mode.  If you're that person, don't waste your money, get something that costs half as much.  But if you like to have control of your settings, this camera is by far the best one out there.

Reviews.Title: Super snappy picture taking fun
Reviews.Author: Nicole E. Savageaux
Reviews.Content: This camera is a huge step up from all the other digital cameras I have owned before (coolpix, etc) in terms of picture quality.  In trying to improve my food/lifestyle blog I needed a point and shoot camera to take food close up, and scenery on the go - this camera does both with ease. The picture quality is far better than twice that of any other camera I have owned, and therefore really worth the extra cost.  The only down side is that when on automatic the flash unit rises from the top of the camera precisely where my left index finger seems to always be -  a minor ergonomic design flaw (of course I could remember to hold it in a different way) and it is a bit heavier than others, but not by too much.  This is a really great camera for my purpose and I am so glad I own it!

Reviews.Title: My favorite compact so far
Reviews.Author: T. Vo
Reviews.Content: I own many "best" compacts -- such as Fuji F30, Fuji F100, Panasonic LX-5 -- the S95 is my favorite of the bunch.Here's what I like about the S95:- Great out of camera JPEG colors (much more to my likings than LX5)- Small enough to conveniently take anywhere (unlike LX5)- Quick startup and response- Easy to use manual controls and menu systemHere's what can be improved:- Battery life not too great- Slow shot to shot time when using flash unless you have a fresh battery- Support zoom during video (like LX5)- Support full HD video at 30fps instead of 24fps (like LX5)Though the LX5 has a nicer lens and better video, I still prefer the S95 for the reasons above.

Reviews.Title: Canon PowerShot S95
Reviews.Author: LV
Reviews.Content: This is not a professional review. Just my thoughts.I purchased this camera for two reasons: kids and dogs indoors and out.I am only a novice, but love cameras and taking pictures of the afore mentioned.I needed something that could handle moving targets and low light.I like the fact that it is small, though not too tiny. I like that it feels like it is made well. I like the quality of some of the photos I've gotten. I'm lucky if half turn out so I always take a lot.My biggest gripe, like many others, is the location of the flash. That could have been so much better. It is not so easy to hold the camera where I would normally hold it. If the picture quality hadn't been as nice, I'd have returned it for that issue.Because I am such a novice, I am unable to correct the temperature of the pictures. It seems the pictures all come out with a warmer tone (a slight yellowish cast) than I like. I actually prefer cooler tones on most things. But the option of warm/cool tones is not on this camera or I can't find it. Besides the flash, that is the biggest draw back for me, because I have to color correct every picture and that is time consuming.But, I am quite pleased with the detail I've gotten on around half the pictures. It replaced my Fuji F31fd...which was a tough decision to make. I don't regret that decision...just wish I could change the color temp and move the doggone flash. :)I gave the f31fd to my daughter who had lost her camera and kept borrowing mine.

Reviews.Title: Best point and shoot camera - hands down!
Reviews.Author: M. Hansen
Reviews.Content: I've owned a Canon powershot camera prior to this - bought 5 years ago and I loved it.  I had no idea how MUCH BETTER my pictures could be until I bought the s95.  It was a little bit more than I wanted to spend initially but no doubt worth it now.  You go on vacation and having beautiful pictures is worth the xtra money, seriously.  The low light feature is AMAZING and the pre-set options (nostalgic, super vivid, poster, minature) are fun to play with.  I am not professional, I don't use manual unless I set it to micro or need the flash on/off - so this is from a person that likes quality and professional looking pix w/out the hassle.  Only fault is that my finger is always on the flash pop up when I shoot.  So when that happens I have to reset and be mindful of my hand placement.

Reviews.Title: Canon S95
Reviews.Author: mashfiqur rahman
Reviews.Content: I have researched for about 4 months for a Point & Shoot Camera with good manual control & low-light performance, great image quality and various modes for taking pictures and no matter which camera I looked at, I kept coming back to the S95. Yes, Lumix LX5 is slightly better camera but it's not as small & probably not as easy to use. Since battery life is an issue for S95, I brought a battery from Maximal Power DB CAN NB-6L Replacement Battery for Canon Digital Cameras/Camcorders. S95's 4X zoom is the only reason you might want to buy another point & shoot, other than that it's perfect.

Reviews.Title: Small, quick and fun
Reviews.Author: D. Hendriks "End Autism Now"
Reviews.Content: I got this camera as a snapshooter so I don't have to lug around my DSLR to every party. It works great! There is a bit of shutter lag, but not enough that I am missing shots, unlike most other compacts I have used. The combination of image stabilization and an ultra fast f/2.0 lens lets me shoot indoors without a flash, so I avoid that washed-out snapshot look. The Aperture-Priority (Av) and Shutter-Priority (Tv) and two control dials let me get the look I want in my pictures, not the prescribed program that most compacts require, without wading through dozens of menus. Nice job, Canon.The biggest downside is that the autofocus can be a bit erratic. The camera doesn't always accurately focus on the subject and switching to manual focus mode can be a pain because I need to fiddle around with the four-way controller to turn it on, and then the function of the control rings changes. Other minor quibbles are that there is no viewfinder and the camera is so small it can be hard to hold. But don't let any of these reasons stop you from buying this great little shooter.

Reviews.Title: If you are not happy with the feature set and quality of this camera....I recommend that you get different subjects to shoot.
Reviews.Author: mrbubble "mrbubble"
Reviews.Content: Like some kind of mental patient I painstakingly compared cameras side by side-some which will be returned (sorry Amazon)while the others are good enough for...well...others than me. The sensor/aperature/lens is good and or big enough that it uses natural light where many of the other cameras used flash and the results were no where near as good. The color saturation-even with the flash-is better than the 5 others tested.Once you get used to the large pop up flash you will find the results gratifying. It's not cheap but the amount of time it will save me from editing photos in Photoshop make it worth while. Don't you want great photos?If you are not happy with the feature set and quality of this camera....I recommend that you get different subjects to shoot because.....bad pictures are not this camera's fault.

Reviews.Title: Awesome Camera
Reviews.Author: AV
Reviews.Content: I have replaced a Canon SD500 (7.1 Mpix) with this puppy... I am an avid shooter, I own a Canon 50D dSLR, I have been a Canon owner for quite some time (G3, G4, G5, Pro1, 20D, 40D, 50D, SD500 - and now, s95).I took it for a test run on a nightly outing to Boston... I have to say that I had little expectations for a pocket camera. After all, the P&S; category, generally, leaves a lot to be desired. This one, literally, blew my mind. Out of 80 shots that I brought home, 75 were keepers. Keep in mind, I used the camera at night, hand-held, at 30 degree outside temperature, no flash...I am sure, if you did the pixel level analysis, you would be able to come up with some flaws. I am sure that if you compared it to a real dSLR, with an L-quality lens, you would be able to find some flaws. But for what it does - being a dSLR shooter - I will call this a serious dSLR backup candidate. Quality - awesome. Imagie stabilization - awesome. Handheld, 1/4 second sharp? Seriously, not many cameras can do that. And P&S;? I do not think you can get any to perform...Movies? Awesome quality. My only gripe is that they are not in MOV format (from AVI that my sd500 used to do), and Microsoft Movie Maker does not handle these... But then again, for good compression ratio and for 720p, I am willing to forego some of the editing capabilities. As for the ability to focus while shooting the movie - the camera's depth of field handles it fine under most occasions. And with regards to the zoom while shooting, you can tele- in, but you cannot go wider than what you have started from. Keep in mind, this is not a video camera... If you are into creating professional movies, look elsewhere. If you need the movie capabilities, the camera will do just fine - and take AWESOME pictures while at it :)

Reviews.Title: Amazing
Reviews.Author: Gups
Reviews.Content: I am just a mom of two boys who has always wanted to take beautiful pictures.  I thought it would take a really expensive D-SLR and classes to take the quality of pictures I wanted.  All it took was this camera.  It is AMAZING.  It takes beautiful pictures no matter the scene or light.....and it captures my boys beautifully.  It makes everyday pictures look professional.  I am so pleased with this purchase.

Reviews.Title: Impressive pocketable camera!
Reviews.Author: DanB
Reviews.Content: Very pleased with the camera!Great low light pics. Wanted very high end pocketable camera with manual controls. Found very favorable professional reviews for both the Canon S95 and the Panasonic LX5. Noted that while the LX5 had a wider lens (24mm), a larger battery, and more control over video shoting,it was larger than the Cannon S95 and didn't review well for auto mode operation.Only recommendation for potential buyers: get a spare battery and seriously consider a fast SD card (e.g. Class 10). Camera can process pics and video very quickly but can be hindered by a slow card.

Reviews.Title: It's really what I want!
Reviews.Author: Firestar
Reviews.Content: I bought it for replacing my old Fuji f50fd.  The image quality of f50fd is good, but at low light,it's performance really made me disappointed.  I searched through websites, read hundreds of reviews, comparing prices thousand of times.  Finally, I was wavering between 2 cameras: Canon s95 and Panasonic Lumix LX5; I like the portable size, no lens cover and HD video for S95, but the wide angle and the design of LX5 is also really attracting me.  If you are good at finding good deals, the price between this two cameras actually is not much, usually is under $30.  To me, it's not a big difference if I really want to buy a good camera for me.  If it's over $60 difference, I may think to get the cheaper one, but it's not.  Eventually, I decided to get Canon S95 because I prefer carrying the camera in my pocket.  I compared the size carefully,read many reviews, then I think LX5 is really not that good for pocket, the lens actually bothers people.  More over, at portrait mode, Canon camera can take wormer pictures than Panasonic one, that's also what I'm looking for.  I prefer taking pictures for people with scenes to taking only the scene.  When I got the camera, the image quality is really much better than my previous one, and the HD video mode is really nice.  Can't refocusing during recording may be a problem to some people, but to me it's fine.  Some people also mentioned tht the popping-up flash light may bother people, but I think if you are a careful person, it won't really be a problem, especially after you getting familiar with your camera.  I recommend this camera.

Reviews.Title: My 5th Canon, and the best yet
Reviews.Author: scott covey "Scott in Colorado"
Reviews.Content: I started with an old Canon S100 (as I recall), went to the 110, and so on, to the 550, the 970, and now the S95. It's interesting I did not even look at other cameras, which I should have, as my brother just got the Nikon S8100 and it looks nice. I have no doubt that the Canon will take better pictures, but the Nikon has nice features. I really wanted a 28mm wide angle, and the S95 has so many features I have yet to read / discover them all. I like the adjustable flash, wink / smile detection, a Custom program mode. Honestly, every time I pick the camera up, I can't wait to use it.. the adjustable / programmable outer ring around the lens is nice. It may not be the best camera for the money, but for my money, and satisfaction, it's a great camera. I bought the SD4500 before this, and returned it, never looked back. The 4500 had some nice features, and if you have this camera, it's a good one for sure, but not want I wanted. Don't purchase accessories through Canon, you'll pay way too much. I bought an extra batter, the exact same one, a Canon, in Canon packaging, for 1/2 what Canon wanted on their web. I wrote them about this, their response, "other companies can sell for less, buy from them".. which I did. Good luck on your purchase, whatever you end up getting.NEW, 10/1/11 - I've had my S95 now for about a year, and still LOVE IT! So much so, I wanted to edit my original post - I use the S95 almost every day and find features I use, that I have not been using. For instance, I set up the short-cut key for a 4:3 format, I normally shoot in 16x9.. however on the digital picture frame I have, the 16x9 format leaves black bars on the top and bottom of the picture - it still looks good, but just bugs me. After trying the 4:3 format, this puts a 700x536 pixel image on the digital frame, which fills the frame completely. I now push the "S" button, the camera changes to 4:3 format and I shoot a 2nd shot for the picture frame, then "S" again, and back to 16x9. Did I say I like this camera? Good colors, everything everyone else says, good, is true. It's a great camera in my opinion.Scott

Reviews.Title: Great camera, just hold on to it tight!!!
Reviews.Author: J. Chin
Reviews.Content: Okay, i dont' know alot about cameras, i mostly take pictures of my kids or the dog or the cat, moving targets and not always in the best light.  This camera gets great great pics!!!  Even sometimes if i disable the flash, it still gets good shots!!!  It's not 100% perfect, but it's a big improvement over my previous camera which was a canon is780 (which i loved btw)...but this one is better, the detail is great!!  I've had the camera for about 2 weeks now, i keep it on auto all the time, or sometimes i switch it to movie mode.  I have not taken the time to learn anything about the camera yet.  Still even leaving it on auto, it's a great camera!!the only negative thing i have to say about it, is that i feel like i'm going to drop it alot, i try to hold it so i don't block the flash or the screen or touch any of the controls, so i have nothing to grip.  i've gotten used to it, but it would be cooler if they put a grip attachment on it or something so you feel confident that you're not going to drop it when you're holding it...

Reviews.Title: Low-light specialty
Reviews.Author: FunnnyWabbit
Reviews.Content: This is not a DSLR replacement, but it comes prettty damn close.  When I don't feel like lugging my "big" camera and glass to an event, I bring this camera along.  Who am I kidding, I actually prefer bringing it along to all my events.  The automatic settings are actually pretty great.  Ultimately, low-light photography is where this little sucker shines. I rarely use a flash and when I do, the pictures look great.  No more blurry compact camera pics.  The quality is amazing and all within a tiny little frame.  One last thing, the zoom is fantastic.  Even the digital zoom feature is relatively clear and sharp.  Buy this camera, you won't be disappointed.

Reviews.Title: OUTSTANDING
Reviews.Author: Roy C. Wahlgren "Roy"
Reviews.Content: I got this camera for my wife.  WOW!!!  What a way to score points!!!  She absolutely LOVES it.  The images are super sharp and very bright.  Much better than anything we have ever owned.  OUTSTANDING!!!  roy <><

Reviews.Title: I just may throw away my SLR
Reviews.Author: Leslie
Reviews.Content: I love this little camera! I have a nice NIKON SLR with a telephoto but I get tired of lugging it around. I can do things with this little camera that I cannot with my DSLR:. Record videos -- I've recorded videos of live music both indoors and outdoors an shared them on Youtube! Wow!. Aspect ratio - I love being able to change the aspect ratio to get those wide shots.. Low light - This camera performs decently in low light situations.I like having a small, light weight camera that takes terrific pcitures.

Reviews.Title: Fantastic Camera
Reviews.Author: Brian Pozar
Reviews.Content: I have had a Nikon D40 for a few years now and wanted to buy a point and shoot that was as close to DSLR quality as possible. I looked at the Nikon P7000 and the Canon G12 first. The Nikon has had a lot of complaints and I finally decided against it. I almost went with the G12 but then found out that the S95 is virtually the same camera, just without the physical manual controls.I couldn't be happier with the choice I made. Image quality surpasses my D40. Low-light performance is fantastic. Startup time and menus are very fast. Total Win!

Reviews.Title: Brilliant!
Reviews.Author: M. Mullins "Book to Book"
Reviews.Content: I love this camera.  The S95 is my new everyday walking-around camera, replacing my Canon G10 (and very briefly a Nikon P7000).  The S95 produces images of wonderful quality with good noise control (for a 1/1.7 sensor camera) all the way to ISO 2000.  Operation of the menus and controls is very fast with little to no delay in selecting menu options.  The customizable front control ring allows you to quickly change frequently used settings.  Battery life could be better, but I'm getting a little more than the advertised 200 shots per charge, and the battery is small and light enough that it's easy to carry a couple of spares.

Reviews.Title: Love to take pictures
Reviews.Author: R. Sweeny "grammi"
Reviews.Content: We were on vacation in October and wanted a camera that would take great landscaping pictures. We got some wonderful shots. The ones that didn't show up good was not because of the camera, but the person taking the picture. We got an extra battery as some reveiws said that the battery ran low fast. We never had to use the extra battery and we took alot of picture. The only bad thing is when you need to ues the flash that when it comes up it almost always hits your finger. You do get used to it and learn to move your finger before it comes up. I would highly recommend this camera for the beginner and the experienced picture taker.

Reviews.Title: Excellent camera
Reviews.Author: AnthonyCA
Reviews.Content: To the point: great compact digital camera, has many of the functions of a dslr.  pictures come out great in customized "P" mode, if you are an advanced user.  If handing it off briefly to a family member/friend to use, it's pretty much goof proof if you switch it to "auto" mode.  The flash is the most powerful I have seen in a compact digital camera.  Most functions are very intuitive, especially if you have previously used canon cameras before.  Get it before the holidays to take memorable pics!

Reviews.Title: Lovely little camera
Reviews.Author: S. Veronica "superstar"
Reviews.Content: I am totally smitten by this camera. It's very portable and takes great shots. I used to rely on my Nikon D90 12.3MP DX-Format CMOS Digital SLR Camera with 18-105mm f/3.5-5.6G ED AF-S VR DX Nikkor Zoom Lens to get the best possible shots but I don't have to lug that thing around anymore. I'm an amateur photographer but I have taken a few classes so I think I have a pretty good idea of what a "good" picture looks like and until now I would have said you could not get one from an ultra-compact. Boy have I had to change my tune.I love all the manual controls and the control ring on the front of the camera. This camera is also very easy to customize to make it work best for you. You have the ability to choose what the control ring on the front of the camera does and there is a custom setting you can set on the dial ring on the top of the camera to remember your favorite camera settings. There is also shutter priority and aperture priority mode, low light mode and manual exposure mode. The camera has manual or automatic focus and many different scene modes.There are also some fun features on this camera for the hobbyist or artistic photographer. I've been have a great time with the fisheye and miniature effects, which can also be used in video. The fisheye is pretty self explanatory for what it does and the miniature gives you a tilt-shift look to your pictures in camera. It's almost like getting a set of Lensbaby The Composer for Canon EF mount Digital SLR Cameraslenses for your camera thrown in for free, which is great because this camera would not be able to accept the mount anyway.I would suggest buying a few accessories for this camera, all of which I have outfitted my setup with. First an lcd protector, I bought the GGS Glass LCD Screen Protector for Canon PowerShot S95 and it fits perfectly. You can purchase the GGS Optical Glass LCD Screen Protector 3" for Digital Cameras for cheaper but it is a smidge smaller than the lcd on the camera. I also bought the Deluxe Leather Case PSC-3200 (for SX210IS, also compatible for S90) because it fits my camera with the custom grip from Richard Franiec attached (which can be purchased at lensmate .com). I also bought the custom lens adapter from lensmate so that I can use filters with this camera which opens up even more opportunities for creativity. I would also suggest buying another wrist strap as the one that comes with the camera is a little too long for my comfort, I'm afraid it will slip off. I'm still searching for the perfect wrist strap though, if you have any suggestions I'd love to hear them.I believe that you can take great pictures with any camera because you can fix quite a bit in post processing these day, but I also don't want to give up the ability to manually control the cameras settings in order to have a small camera. With the canon s95 I get the best of both worlds, I'm able to manually configure the camera in all the ways that please me AND I can fit it in my pocket. Oh, and did I mention that this camera shoots RAW? Awesome!While there is no one camera that is perfect for everyone I think this is close to my perfect camera. Sometimes I wish it had more optical zoom but other than that I really have no complaints. Besides, you really should move closer to your subject if you want to get a great pic rather than zooming in. This camera is also great for street photography because it is easily palmed if you want to take some stealth shots. You can set your camera to your custom settings and just shoot away!So what are you waiting for, if you're reading this review you are considering this camera. Stop. Go buy it. You'll love it just like I do.

Reviews.Title: The only compact camera for actually taking photos
Reviews.Author: ~D "wiredrabbit"
Reviews.Content: I have had Sony, Canon and Panasonic compacts and did find the Sony to be good at times, but fell down in some situations, the Canons were always good and except for low light performance, I think I might consider the smaller sensor Canons.  Panasonics have great features and if photographic quality isn't an issue, they are great, some of the larger format Panasonics can compete, but nothing comes close in a compact.  Having had these and recently purchased this, I find it an excellent camera and great value.There is nothing that is close in this size.  I am able to make the other cameras work, but I can easily get amazing results from this. I can push the background back to bring up the subject.  The lens has a nice boke, which is utterly amazing in a compact P&S.;  And the quality is generally excellent.  I have seen some less than perfect shots, but I come back feeling the camera will help me correct any mistakes.  It won't compete with a DSLR, but it is so nice and small.I considered the G12, but really went for the easy carry compact size feeling that the G12 offered more, but not much I needed.  If I really need more, than I'll get the big gun (the inexpensive lens for which cost more than this). This is in my pocket.  Always. It still turns out great quality.I don't want to see Canon turn this into some sort of super zoom - or movie maker (unless they can keep the size the same with a bigger sensor)  I don't want GPS or any idiot modes.  The pop up flash is odd, but doesn't really affect much.  I haven't noticed battery life issues yet.  I have seen some blow out and odd focus choices, and I find the menus a bit challenging.  I don't like the auto setting, leaving that for when I am taking tourist shots as auto doesn't use raw and the focus can't be changed, but it is OK if all I am doing is taking a shot of a sign which helps explain what the next real shot is all about.  Like when taking interesting detail shots in Soho in London and I want to remember what I was thinking, I write it down "Soho, London, still life in an alley" and take a picture of it.  Old school GPS.Where this camera can go is into darker situations, in pockets and still perform with excellent quality, because when I am walking on a path and look up to see the sun shining through some clouds in behind a tree in a way that the scene really looks like it is on fire, I don't want to look back on that shot and think, wow, what a great moment, too bad the clouds look all fuzzy because I didn't have my good camera on hand.  Fortunately, my companion had her Canon that day and now I have one.What would I ask Canon to improve?  I'd suggest a slightly longer zoom, yes.  I think they could stretch this and still have a nice lens.  I would really want a faster lens.  I like being able to take photos at 2.0 aperture and would love if they could get 2.8 out of the current range.  It is still better than the competition, but there is potential. That'd be worth a bit of space.Then add another small dial on top for more manual control. One on the top, one on back (which it already has). It would be brilliant.  It already can use the dial on back and the lens ring, but I'd like to focus as well.  Already, a little compact camera that one can directly change the aperture and shutter speed with a dial (or program a dial for something else if you must) just like a real DSLR camera!  I just want to be able to set the front ring as a focus ring and still do it.  It would be pocket size photo nirvana.  As is, it isn't hard to change and I've not seen the like in a point and shoot.I'd also like to see it made weather proof.  I always worry about dust and scratches and rain.  I've had cameras lost to dust and worry about rain showers.In truth, I worry that Canon probably doesn't put so much into this, the market is too small and the cost for the sensor is high, but I think the market is building and a great niche, so come on, throw some resources on this great little camera.It really is a great camera for just taking photos. It is no DLSR, but the only better cameras are made by Nikon and Canon and are all bigger, starting with the G12 and the Nikon P7000.  I took some photos with owners of a G12, a panasonic GF2 (I think) and a Canon EOS1D Mark III and all were impressed and funny enough, none of them had their cameras handy because they are harder to carry around.It is a little power house.

Reviews.Title: Comparable to my DSLR
Reviews.Author: Rishi Raj
Reviews.Content: Have been using digital cameras for some time now. Bought this camera after extensive research and it has not disappointed me. Excellent for low light situations. Don't need to use my DSLR any more because this camera shoots better pictures, and allows me to adjust all aspects of the picture like exposure, ISO etc. Absolutely thrilled.Update: Still very happy, but as expected, takes longer to focus than my DSLR.

Reviews.Title: Great camera with limitations
Reviews.Author: Bluelondon
Reviews.Content: I've had the S95 for about a month now and while it is one of the best compact cameras on the market today, I will be returning mine due to 10-15 dead pixels on the screen. No fault of the Camera itself, these things happen, but in addition to the dead pixels, I have other issue with the camera which I shall explain further.Let's jump straight in to the pros and cons, in no particular order.pros:1. compact size.2. excellent image quality, very sharp.3. manual controls, if you are looking for a camera that will help you improve and grow your understanding of manual photography, this is a great place to start.4. f/2.0 aperture = great for low light.5. nice 3" LCD, bright and clear.cons:1. SPEED. I made the mistake in buying this camera when I should have bought a DSLR. it's not the S95's fault, it was mine for not testing the camera out in a shop before buying, I thought it would meet my needs, but I was wrong. If you are intending to use this for stop action photography, meaning kids and pets, think again. While it will take great images, it will not take them when you want. There is a slight delay. By the time you half press the shutter, auto focus, and then take the shot, the moment is long gone. So expect to take around 10 shots of your kids on the swings to find 1 image that is a keeper. I didn't expect DSLR like speeds, but the S95 really doesn't offer anything different compared to my 3 year old Canon SD6300 6MP camera, in terms of speed.2. Flash location, I'm sure everyone knows by now that it's in a terrible spot.3. Movie recording is pretty much useless on the S95. No autofocus or optical zoom means that you either have to shoot a static subject or forget about recording movies altogether. I downloaded the CHDK hack for the S95 which lets you autofocus and zoom optically in movie mode but even that is not ideal as you have to boot up the camera in playback mode, update the firmware, then switch to live mode to record a movie. It get's on my nerves having to do this every time. It's 2010 for god's sake. Camera 5 years old used to autofocus and zoom optically in movie modes.4. Battery life is poor. 200 pics is just not enough, so if you get this camera, get a couple spares.conclusion:All in all, the S95 is a great compact camera. I have definitely taken many keepers in the last month. The images are very high quality and sharp for a camera of this size. And while it didn't meet my needs in a camera, it is no fault of the camera. Just be sure you understand its limitations before buying it. It is not a fast camera, you have to pace yourself when shooting, and I've already explain why video recording is a pain with this camera for anything other than still subjects. But for everything else (portraits, landscapes, still life, etc) this camera is probably the best compact on the market today. I know the LX5 and others are better technically, but they are not as compact as the S95 and thus is the reason why the S95 is so popular.So as long as things like the slow operational speed and limited movie mode don't bother you (other cons like flash location and battery life can be worked around, not a deal breaker) then I think you will really enjoy this camera, especially if you are looking for a compact camera to help you understand photography better and move away from the green auto mode.

Reviews.Title: This is the professional point and shoot camera
Reviews.Author: Weihao Lu
Reviews.Content: Coming from DSLR, I have to say the picture quality is just as good.The biggest plus of this camera I've found is the HDR mode. It will actually take 3 pictures of the same scene with different exposures and combine all 3 to create a very high quality vivid HDR shot, but make sure you have a tripod for this mode!  I found this feature is extremely helpful with photographer like me because I used to combine them with photoshop and thats really time consuming.This camera's low light performance is also the best in its class.  I have taken shots without flash and it comes out very clear and sharp with minimal noise.

Reviews.Title: Canon S95 vs. S90
Reviews.Author: surfbum
Reviews.Content: This review is mostly for the S90 fans who are wondering about the real life changes to the S95.  I have attached most of my original review of the S90 at the bottom of this update for those who don't know much about the S80/S90/S95 series....1)  Let's get down to what most of you care about:  The HD video.
