It's good.  Not great, but exactly what you expected.  Exactly.  The 720p ability is not what everyone wanted, but it's a huge improvement and it works.  Zero jellyvision and the IS stays true to form.  Jaggies are minimal and sound is improved but can still be blown out by loud noise (such as a concert which I simulated with my stereo - and probably causing my neighbors to all go WT...?).One negative is that you can still not change focal length while shooting.Comparing the video to a Canon T2i with an 'L" series lens, the S90 frankly performs better.  While not as sharp, there are less jaggies and the internal IS makes a huge difference.Comparing the video to an HD Flip, there is no comparison.  Forget 1080p, the better optics and system will make the S95 your go-to camera for easy video.Comparing the video to an Apple iPhone 4, surprise.  The iPhone is the sharpest of all four, however it's lack of IS and the jellyvision factor make the S95 far superior.  Kudos to Apple though for sticking such an amazing camera in a phone (plus Apple doesn't blow out sound like the S95).I'll see if I can post some video or a link, but believe me when I tell you that the low light video is amazing.  I'm an airline pilot and I've been able to record night approaches and lightening storms that no other camera including my T2i could capture.In conclusion, I'm very, very satisfied with the video upgrade.  Very satisfied.2)  Feel & Handling  The smooth texture of the S90 never really bothered me but that said, the new matte finish is definitely an improvement.  While the specs say otherwise, the S90 feels heavier and more solid.  This isn't a word, but everything is just more "clickier".  It doesn't feel "platicy" anymore.  I like it.3)  That Darn Backside Control Dial.  O.K.  I HATED that thing on the S90.  The S95 provides an improvement, but am I the only one who thinks it's still too "loose"?  While you won't inadvertently change settings by just bumping the backside, it's still pretty easy to do.  I would have preferred something - again - "clickier" but it is definitely an improvement.  Thank gawd.4)  A Kind of Big Negative/Warning  If you buy the S95 buy a 3" screen protector at the same time.  Unlike the S90, the back of the S95 is completely flat and there is no protective recess around the screen.  I'm not sure if they've put Gorilla Glass on this new version, but I know I scratched my S90 almost immediately and the S95 looks like it might get scratched easier.  That said, I like how clean the new controls are.5)  Eye-Fi  No one really mentions this, but the S95 adds Eye-Fi card support built in to the OS.  From what I can tell so far, it doesn't do much except have an on/off control for uploading but what it DOES do is NOT turn off the camera for power savings while uploading.  Huge bonus.  Mahalo Canon for working with Eye-Fi!!!6)  No Manual  This really ticks me off.  You know the small pocket sized manual that Canon always includes with their consumer cameras.  No more.  They refer you to a .pdf copy located on the CD-ROM (you can also downloaded from the support web page however that version has an irritating watermark).  This just really ticks me off.  I'm all for saving trees but if I spend $400 on a high end consumer camera, I still think I deserve a hard copy of the manual.  Boo hiss Canon!Finally, I'll amend this review when I get a better idea of the new Hybrid IS technology and HDR functions work but I can say that without a doubt, the addition of 720p video and improving (but not fixing) the control dial make this a worthy upgrade for me.  Yeah, it sucks that I had to dish out another $400 but my S90 will now become a dedicated U/W camera and considering how often I flood them (at least once every two years - that's how my beloved S80 died) it's worth it to me.For those who have never used the S90, my original review is below.  The short version:  You will NOT be disappointed with the S95 if you take the time to learn how to use it.  Otherwise, save some $$$ and pick up the SD4000....ORIGINAL S90 REVIEW:Be warned, I am a self professed camera geek. I believe cameras are like surfboards; you need a quiver of surfboards/cameras for the right wave/job.The Canon S90 is - by far - my new "go to" pocket camera and the one I will always carry with me in my flight bag. I have been using it for just about a month now and after a couple thousand shots, only now am I getting comfortable with its functionality. This is NOT the camera to buy your mother-in-law for Christmas. She will never speak to you again.My other cameras are:Canon 7D - with 'L' series lenses.Pentax W60 (waterproof) - for surfing, sailing, biking, hiking, skiing and handing to the kids to beat each other with over the head.Canon SD980 - which was my *quality* pocket camera but will now be relegated purely to U/W scuba photography (since I own the U/W case anyway and would live in fear that my S90 meets the same fate as my S80 and gets flooded shark diving in Tahiti).Here's the deal with the new Canon S90: If you are willing to delve into the sub menus and experiment it will become a very, very powerful camera in your arsenal. It can do anything the G11 can do but because of the size you might have to work a little harder initially to figure out the functionality curve. It's like flying. Once your familiar with the controls (which takes awhile) the interface becomes transparent and you can make it do just about anything you want. But it will take a lot of tinkering. No lie.I'll leave the critique on picture quality for the professional sites but will just offer this: the results are very good for the size of the camera. The low light performance is best in class, period; and I've tried them all including the LX3 (which is also darn good but noisier - love that 24mm lens though).Bottom line, if you want SLR quality go buy an SLR. You're not going to get the same results with the S90. Duh. If you don't like small cameras or have large fingers then maybe you should look at something like the G11. The S90 is *too small* for all of its functionality but that's the dichotomy, isn't it? The functionality is all there but by design is forced into a sometimes frustratingly cramped interface. That said, this camera is very good at what it is: a pocket camera with a wide fast lens that can shoot in RAW.Let's talk about size. I'll agree that the build quality initially seems *cheaper* than what you would expect. That said, the case, dials, and shutter are all solid in real life day to day use. Especially the shutter. To be honest, it's a bit strange but you can't deny the light weight and I love that it's smooth and flat and easily fits into your jeans. It's as small as any compact with the exception of the lens ring/bulge and while I wish the bulge weren't there, it is what it is and the functionality of that ring is surprisingly awesome. It's definitely more pocketable than the LX3. The screen is gorgeous and I don't miss the viewfinder at all.The power up/down flash is irritating and I pray it doesn't break but I got to admit there is less red-eye than most cameras (which is supposedly why they went with the design). As long as the motor doesn't give out because I'm inadvertently holding the flash down when it tries to pop up I'll live with it and tip my hat to Canon's engineers.The control ring functionality is awesome and the Ring Function button is very, very functional and remains customized for each "mode" you select. In this way you can set up your camera for high speed Av photography different than for say Tv photography. Nice.On that functionality, making this camera do what you want really boils down to getting to know the camera. After a month, I can finally adjust aperture, shutter speed, and the four directional manual white balance without thinking about it. ISO, exposure bracketing, flash intensity, metering, and continuous shooting are just a button/spin/button/spin away. Once you've memorized the function layout, exposure adjustments are fairly quick and painless. And of course you've got the outer control ring and function ring give you instant access to two of your major settings wether that be ISO, exposure metering, manual focus, white balance, zoom, aperture, or shutter speed. You're really wasting the power of this camera if you just leave it in Av so you can shoot "fast".Whew. Exhausted yet? If you are then maybe this camera isn't for you. ;) No, seriously.However, if you are willing to commit yourself Canon has given you the tools to get the shot you want. Or I suppose you could just leave it in AUTO.I'll see if I can figure out how to upload some sample shots but here are some real life experiences I've had. Day shots of the NYC skyline are beautiful. A little soft compared to a Canon 7D with an 'L' series lens, but like I said before, duh. The same shot at night can be accomplished without a tripod at about 1/60 of a second. No blur. At an English Beat concert the other night I was snapping away at f2.0 (wide) and 1/100 of a second. Not always fast enough but about five times what I could do with my SD980. Stepping it down from ISO100 to 800 sped it up and while a little noisier, fit the concert like feel. Ice skating at night at Rockefeller Center (well lit) I was taking photos without the flash as if it were daytime. In summary, this camera rocks.UPDATE: Low light photos uploaded to Amazon. Look for NYC skyline and adjacent concert pics. Unfortunately Amazon resolution is limited but you'll get the idea of what you can get away with.The one thing I don't get is the 640X480 movie mode. I ask why, why, why knowing full well that there is an engineering answer that hasn't found its way on to the Interwebs yet. Somewhere in the software/hardware mix there must be an answer because not including HD video is inexplicable to me. On the other hand, most video I take with this kind of camera just gets uploaded to YouTube anyway so 640X480 is fine. That's what I've got a dedicated HD camcorder for. One thing I will add, the sound quality is noticeably better than any other mono point and shoot I've used. I'm not sure what's up with that but it's noticeably clearer with deeper base. Kind of a nice surprise, really.At the end of the day this is a great camera and a very worthy successor to my beloved (and flooded) Canon S80. If you want the smallest *quality* camera you can currently buy the S90 is it. There are a few issues but that beautiful fast lens makes them bearable. If you want an SLR like interface and are willing to sacrifice the size, then you should take a serious look at the G11 (or similar). This camera is too small for that kind of interface and while the top level functions are intuitive (aperture, shutter speed, ISO) you'll have to commit yourself a little to go any deeper. The beauty is, you can!Bottom line: If I lost this camera today I'd buy another tomorrow. From a camera geek that travels the world, that says a lot.Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera with 3.8x Wide Angle Optical Image Stabilized Zoom and 3.0-Inch inch LCD

Reviews.Title: Good Compact Camera
Reviews.Author: Olga
Reviews.Content: I think this is a very good compact camera; however, it doesn't provide DSLR quality.  It's great in low light conditions, but is not as good in bright light conditions.  I took my Nikon D5000, Canon 870is and the S95 out and took the same exact pictures with the cameras.The Nikon performed the best as expected.  The S95 was comparable to the Nikon in low light conditions.  My most surprising revelation was that the 870is is a pretty great camera too.  Performing beautifully in bright light and medium light conditions.Pros:-low light photos-image quality-manual controls - many more than the canon 870 and very easy to use-very intuitive interface-can set the ring in the front and back of the camera to perform custom tasksCons:-In bright light the sky appeared white instead of blue in several photos-flash placement - has pinched me when going down and gotten stuck coming up forcing me to restart the camera.-Video doesn't auto-focus during recording (much cheaper models do)-Takes a long time btwn shots - I'm used to a DSLR so that may just be my issueOverall, the S95 is a great camera.  I would recommend it if you need a small camera right now.  Otherwise, I'd wait until the S100 is released in the spring.  I like having the S95, but I feel it's over priced for what it is. (I paid $400).

Reviews.Title: Canon S95
Reviews.Author: S. Simmonds
Reviews.Content: I originally purchased a Panasonic LX5 which is a wonderful camera, however, I wanted a camera I could easily slip in and out of a pocket and the LX5 was a little heavy and thick.  Keeping track of a loose lens cap on the LX5 worried me also.  I ended up replacing the LX5 with the Canon S95.  I have been very happy with this camera.  The menus are easy to use with a large variety of options, the screen is bright and sharp, the quality of photos is excellent, and the battery life is good.  Being able to assign the lens ring to different functions is very handy. The camera body is less slippery than the S90, however, I still opted for the Richard Franiec S95 grip which makes the camera much more secure in my hand.  The control ring has also been improved over the S90 but still moves fairly easily so I opted for the Lensmate control dial ring which inexpensively solves that problem.  There are three things I don't like about the camera.  Two are fairly insignificant but one does bother me.  The wrist strap that comes with the camera has no slider to tighten it around your wrist so it's just one big loop that will easily slide off your hand.  I am using a wrist strap from another camera.  The plastic door that covers the USB port does not have a solid feel when closing and it makes me feel like its going to flip back open.  I worry that it will not close properly after many openings and closings so I opted for a card reader instead. The one major point I do not like about the camera is the way the flash is operated.  In order to turn on the flash the camera must be supported in the left hand and the natural position of your left index finger is right on top of the flash that is trying to pop up.  It is also easy to push the flash button on the control ring with your thumb when you don't want to. First it will run into your left index finger then it will take several strokes to get the flash back to the off position.  My ideal situation would be a switch operated by the left hand that when pushed would raise the flash.  Or at least have the button that is not right under the thumb.  All in all this is the best point and shoot camera I have ever owned (this is my 6th) and would highly recommend it.10/27/10  -  One thing I forgot to mention when I first wrote this review is a program the LX5 has that I wish would be incorporated in the S95.  Before I sent the LX5 back for the S95 I played around with a program that does double and triple exposures.  A really fun option.  I'd like to see this on the next Canon S.

Reviews.Title: Lens Error
Reviews.Author: jbh
Reviews.Content: After only 1 1/2 year of owning this camera the lens will no longer open and I receive a lens error message.  Looking online this seems to be a very common problem with the Powershot cameras.  The flat rate to repair this is $145 through Canon - warranty is only good for 1 year.  A camera at this price point should be made to last a little longer than this.

Reviews.Title: I would marry this camera
Reviews.Author: Observe_the_cat!
Reviews.Content: Seriously.  I have like five cameras at any given time, and this is by far my favorite.  I prefer it leaps and bounds over my Rebel T3 for its portability, image quality, and ease of use.  ANYONE can figure out how to take kick-butt pix on this camera.  It does great low light shots on the auto settings and has some fun special programs like miniature effect and color inversion.I've always thought DSLRs were the way to go, but not when you have a Point and Shoot of this quality.  I get tons of compliments on my photos using this camera.Fits in my pocket or bag, holds a charge for a long time, takes regular memory cards.  All around a winner.  I love Canon!

Reviews.Title: S95 lens error
Reviews.Author: Andy Chou
Reviews.Content: Right after 13 months, this 'lens error will shut down automatically' came up. Luckily, I used AE card to purchase this camera, they fully refunded the money I paid. no more s95/s100 for me.Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera with 3.8x Wide Angle Optical Image Stabilized Zoom and 3.0-Inch LCD

Reviews.Title: Best Compact Camera Around
Reviews.Author: David Russell Hill
Reviews.Content: I have bought a total of 3 of these cameras over the past 12 months.  For my wife, daughter, and myself.  Can take amazing pictures out of the box and with a little experimentation with manual controls and Macro settings you will get amazing pictures.  The newer model S100 may be newer but not any better in any meaningful way (IMHO).My wife has become a "photo nut" and joined the "365 Photo Club"  on line.  You submit at least one photo a day on line with the day's theme.  The photos are viewed by your followers at the club and comments made.  Photo of the day is awarded each day according to who got the highest score.Anyway, since Jan 2012, I swear my wife has taken at least 50 photos a day with this camera, trying to submit a winning picture.  She has won on many occasions.  Camera is still going strong.  By extrapolation 365 x 50 = 18,250 photo cycles will have been shot by the end of 2012.Highly recommended.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: Legendary D
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera in Best Buy back in July 2011.  Needless to say, it's still working great.  I did notice a lot of concerns about the "lens error" especially after numerous users complained about it only after a few days or weeks after purchasing it.  So far, no error messages on my behalf.  Which prompts me to take better care of my camera now.The image quality is great.  Crisp and clear, which I have pictures taken on the highest quality settings.  As well as the videos that I've recorded.  Given I'm no professional photographer.  I've outfitted it with a SanDisk 32GB SDHC UHS-1 memory card, so now I don't need to worry about running out of memory.  My only gripe about it is the flash when it pops out, it tends to get in the way if I'm holding the camera with both hands.Seemed to be durable as well since I've bought it over a year ago, I've taken it to numerous outings (windy days, slight rain, extreme Summer heat and Winter cold), camping, hikes and even kept it in my pocket which wasn't a good idea.  So far I've put about 800+ shots on it without any problems as of yet.  Though I haven't dropped it...Overall, a great camera.

Reviews.Title: Better than some 16MP camears
Reviews.Author: Old Fashioned
Reviews.Content: I bought following and returned 'coz the pictures taken by these were not sharp enough:1. Canon PowerShot ELPH 3002. Olympus SZ30Above two didn't come close to my 7 year old (now broken 'coz of mis-handling) Olympus Camedia 4000. Finally, I found this Canon S95 and am very happy with results.What's wrong with Steve's DigiCams review site? Go there and compare sample shots taken by all of the above cameras. Also, check out Olympus Camedia 4000 in there. Even with cheap LCD monitor the differences are very obvious. Yet, Steve's tends to praise all cameras. I guess since manufacturer's give him camears (as opposed to Consumer Reports buying them from street).In short S95 is a superb camera. I don't care about mega-pixels as much about sharpness. A huge portion of my pictures are for web upload; not so much printing. So, extremely happy with S95.

Reviews.Title: Outstanding camera
Reviews.Author: T. Propp
Reviews.Content: I got tired of trying to take decent low light pictures with my old point and shoot so I decided to try the Canon S95 after reading good reviews about it's low light capability.  This camera takes outstanding low light pictures.  It's so good that I've used the flash maybe twice in the year that I've owned this camera.  It has manual aperture, shutter, and ISO settings, but to be honest it takes such good pictures with the automatic settings that I seldom mess with the manual settings.  I was able to take some nice night pictures of the moon at night using the manual settings, though, to get the exposure just right.A lot of other brands will boast 5 zillion megapixel resolution, but this camera takes way better pictures under any conditions.  You don't really need more than 10 megapixels unless you plan to print poster sized prints.  I've had more than a few people comment that I must have a really nice pro SLR to take such good pictures.  I liked it so much that I bought one for my father and he's been pleased with his camera as well.

Reviews.Title: Fabulous point and shoot
Reviews.Author: Jerry
Reviews.Content: I have owned literally hundreds of digital cameras, both p&s; and DSLR.  No reason to pay more for a camera unless you need to stop action.  This little thing is fabulous for almost every use and it fits in your pocket.  Save yourself a bunch of money, skip the DSLR and just mess around with this baby.

Reviews.Title: Great amateur indoor performance
Reviews.Author: Joe Philly
Reviews.Content: I just got this camera yesterday with the special deal from Amazon, and I'm very impressed so far.  It's much thinner than the Canon PowerShot S70 7.1MP Digital Camera with 3.6x Optical Zoom that I used to have, and the performance is much better than the Canon PowerShot SD800 IS 7.1MP Digital Elph Camera with 3.8x Wide Angle Image-Stabilized Optical Zoom that I'm replacing with this camera.  Compared to the SD800IS, I notice that in my indoor family shots, the background is much lighter.  I think the larger lens must be letting in more light.  I've been very happy with the SD800IS for the past 5 years, but the S95 will be much better for indoor family pictures, which is my primary use.  The only negative I noticed so far is that 5-10% of my pictures are not focused properly.  I imagine I have to learn to use the settings better to avoid this.  I also took a macro picture of one of the kids' dolls at 4" away, and the performance blew away the SD800IS.  It took a nice sharp picture with no flash, which the SD800 can't do at that close range.  There is a dizzying array of features available once I read the manual, but I can use the basic features of the camera for a while before doing that.  I'm amazed that I got such a great camera for just over two hundred bucks.

Reviews.Title: Not bad for a compact camera
Reviews.Author: D. simoes "Deb"
Reviews.Content: First I would like to say that this is a compact camera and I knew pretty much what I was in for. My needs on this purchase included: something small, and easy to carry around and good quality images (I am a studio art major and in some conditions I need to take some good shots of a class' still life _that I cannot obviously  take home with me_ or some of my own paintings to post up on the web). In addition I wanted a camera that I could take with me when I go out at night with some friends: the ability to take pics in dim light was not exactly a primary need but it wouldn't hurt to have it as well. My price range was around 300 dollars, but if anything stood out I wouldn't mind to make some compromise for amazing features.That being said, I narrowed my search between the LX5 and S95. Being paranoid of buying such an expensive item through the internet i read multiple reviews before I made up my mind on the latter. Though the LX5 was judged to capture blown away images, I felt uneasy about its size and lens cap (I should add that I also had a military ball to attend in a few days, and I needed to make sure that this camera could fit in my clutch!). I am not exactly a photo enthusiast, and I knew that the default setting and jpeg images was what i was gonna use for a while, before i took time to learn more. Although the S95 would not match the LX5's RAW shots, the jpegs were supposed to.This is what I can say so far from my experience:-Not too impressed by the image stabilization. If your hand is not steady enough, count your shots to be blurry (the LX5 is supposed to be better at that).-More grainy than I would expect, for my certain zoomed pics (but hey, it is a compact camera after all, and for my normal shots, the pics were pretty good. The LX5 blocky lens probably come to better use for that)-Worked pretty great in low light (the ball was held in pretty dark rooms to create ambiance and there, at least, the S95 held on its own)-Fit nicely inside the small purse along with my numerous items, and its compact design overall is pretty nice ( not that it is quite that important but its a nice bonus)-Images' color in normal don't seem to quite match the actual setting, but still pretty closeOverall not too bad... Im sure as I learned more its manual control, its worth would be even closer to how much I spend for it! Im not sure if I would have still chosen over the LX5  had I had a chance to have a hand held experience (for some reason even best buy doesn't hold it in display...). But I am not too disappointed for what it is: A transportable-easy compact camera with good/satisfying images :)

Reviews.Title: Little less than what i expected
Reviews.Author: DY
Reviews.Content: I was looking for a Point and Shoot camera with good shutter response to take pics of my kid. After reviewing lots of camera online, finally settled on S95. The photos are crisp, focus is quick on half press, but the shutter lag is a let down. Probably I was trying to find features of a DSLR in a PoS and surely failed in that. Will probably buy a D3100 soon.Quality of videos from S95 are little inferior to those from flip, so i still use flip to shoot videos mostly.

Reviews.Title: Excellent pocket camera
Reviews.Author: TomVette "TomVette"
Reviews.Content: This is an excellent pocketable camera. Photos are vivid, sharp and show good dynamic range.The camera is very logicial in its operations and best of all takes really usable pictures in low light conditions at ISO levels up to 1,600, even though the camera can push to 3,200. The lens is very fast F 2.0.The camera competes in bright light with my Canon 40D SLR. Low light picture quality is not as competitive but still very natural and useable, unlike some of my other pocket cameras.This is the small camera for the serious SLR photographer to use when an SLR is not practical. Highly recommended.

Reviews.Title: Great camera for novice or pro!
Reviews.Author: Lindsay Nixon "happyherbivore"
Reviews.Content: I'm going on a month-long trip and didn't want to take my Nikon D40. Several professionals recommend this camera on their website and although I wasn't jazzed up to spend $400 when I already own a Nikon D40 and several lens; I got it anyway.INCREDIBLE.I've had a week---spending a lot of time using it so I'm good to go on my trip next week. It takes beautiful--beautiful pictures. Even thouse completely in the dark about photography and things like aperture, will take gorgeous photos.I love the large viewing screen. It has so many great (and actually usable features) that most small cameras do not. It also fits into the "cell phone holder" of my travel bag...my iphone doesn't even fit in that holder, but this camera does.I recommend it!

Reviews.Title: One of the best compact cameras I've used
Reviews.Author: Ammy_Evaluator
Reviews.Content: At the risk of repeating what others have said, here are my top 3 favorite things about this camera:1. It is small. It fits in my shirt pocket, and I can take it anywhere I go.2. It gives you full manual control over the capture process - in the most intuitive and convenient manner possible.3. Its image quality is about the best I've seen with compacts.This is Canon at its best.Happy Clicking!

Reviews.Title: Great Camera!
Reviews.Author: Pamkf "Pam"
Reviews.Content: This is my go to camera.  I have the Canon Rebel that shoots video, but this is the camera that I reach for time after time.  The reason is that it is so compact and takes such wonderful pictures.  This is the one camera that others who have shot pictures with it always ask if they can borrow.  I tell them they can't because I don't want to part with it for even a short time.  I would definitely recommend this camera.  The only thing I would suggest is for Canon to add a GPS function.  Otherwise this camera is picture perfect!

Reviews.Title: Excellent camera, great low light pictures.
Reviews.Author: D. Knauth "dkny2001"
Reviews.Content: I've been buying Canon powershot cameras about every other year, and this, probably my 5th, is the best yet.  It's small, easy to use, but most importantly, it takes great pictures, particularly in low light conditions.  Other review go into the technical aspects of it; from a user's perspective, it has all the features I've come to expect from this line of Canon cameras, and it takes very nice sharp pictures.  Battery life has been fantastic, coupled with an 8gb card this camera can seemingly go forever.  The only two issues I've noticed in several months of regular use is (1) sometimes in video mode, it seems to have trouble focusing-- if it doesn't find a focus right away, the only way to correct is to stop and start again; and (2) sometimes in portrait mode / low light conditions the flash fails to engage.  Both have happened to me a few times, but these seem to be intermittent issues, and really haven't been more than an occasional annoyance.  Best small digital camera I've owned, and I expect I'll be happy with this one for at least a few years to come.

Reviews.Title: PowerShot S95 Review
Reviews.Author: Olga
Reviews.Content: Picture quality in a darkness is great! I don't like the location of the flash on this camera,it's just under you finger exactly where you hold a camera.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: B. THOMAS
Reviews.Content: I waited quite some time before buying the Canon S95. I have over 40 years of experience in photography with my first camera being a manual Nikon FM, then on to a Nikon FE, F3, Canon EOS 620 etc, all SLR's. With the advent of the digital point & shoot cameras I had a 4MP Olympus Stylus 410, obviously I needed a major upgrade as the Olympus could'nt cut it anymore, especially in low light situations. I looked very closely at Nikon, Olympus, and came close to going with the Panasonic Lumix series with a Leica lense. However, I was intrigued with the Canon S95. Simply put, it is an amazing camera, jamb packed with just about every tool that a novice or pro could want. There is much to read and absorb for learning the capabilities of the S95. The few gripes that I have are that it is quite small for those of us with big hands, but that was part of it's apeal to drop in your pocket on the go. Also, the software supplied from Canon can be somewhat awkward to navigate, but  has much more information about the camera and was not as bad as some here have posted in my opinion. The fast F2 lens makes incredible low light photos and the flexiblity provided by the controls are intuative and well thought out. (love the control ring) Though a bit exspensive it's still well worth it and I highly recommend it for those who want High quality photos and decent video..

Reviews.Title: Awesome Camera
Reviews.Author: Andrew
Reviews.Content: Pretty awesome camera. My wife and I bought this one to take on our honeymoon in Europe and it didn't let us down. Awesome shots in all kinds of situations. The only thing we noticed was sometimes between shots the load time was a little annoying, we believe this may be some what due to the memory card though. Also, the pop up flash is really cool, but it kept surprising me. You will get use to it, but remember to remind people who are taking your picture with it, or they will drop your $400 camera.The different scenes are really cool for all types of situations, we found ourselves mainly using the auto mode as we didn't have time to stop and think a lot about settings etc. Another cool feature is the ability for the camera to shoot raw photos. From what I've seen out of this camera I would say it definitely is the best point and shoot out there, but also will rival getting a DSLR for the weekend warrior photographer.One quality issue, the case has a slight "creek" on it when you squeeze in one spot, not a big deal, but kind of annoying for a $400 camera, you would expect a very high quality build. That being said all other aspects of the camera case are very nice, even the DSLR "esque" adjustment ring.Hope it helps!

Reviews.Title: Bought it after 4 months with Panasonic TZ10
Reviews.Author: Dagan Yuval
Reviews.Content: The review refers mostly for use in auto mode in both s95 and TZ10 and low light in s95 (TZ10 does not have a low light mode). Also note that I did not buy both  cameras from Amazon.I purchased a brand new: Panasonic TZ10 base on the good reviews of the TZ serie. The results were and still very good in day light and the video is really amazing for a compact camera and the zoom is remarkable. But Indoor, the image quality was not enough for me and after struggling with it for few months I gave up and decided to look somewhere else.So, after a quick research, I decided to give the Canon s95 or the Canon G12 a try -  the s95 won for the compactness.Compared to the TZ10 the S95 is smaller and it really slips into pockets easily.The image quality with the S95 is great under any light conditions and superb in good light conditions. In low light you need to change to low light mode. Finally, I solved my low light problems. The zoom of course is not as the TZ10 so when I need large zoom usually outside in day light -  I use the TZ10.With a little more zoom (also in video mode) - the s95 can be realy the perfect P&S; for me.The s95 is more expensive than the TZ10.By the way, In my opinion, the images from the Canon looks better, but the Panasonic image colors are much closer to reality.

Reviews.Title: Beautiful Masterpiece!!!!
Reviews.Author: Amrit Babu "Dr Amrit Babu"
Reviews.Content: Initially I was a little skeptical about spending the big bucks to get this camera. I have always had a Canon and was willing to switch to another brand mainly because of the night shots my camera took.  I had the Canon SD IS 1100 and thought of giving Canon one last try based on few recommendations from my friend.  So I ended up getting the Canon S95 and my wife took this to SFO for her girls trip and all the ladies loved the pics it took.  IT is really amazing and definitely worth the price.  I highly recommend it.

Reviews.Title: Smarter than S90
Reviews.Author: W. Soh
Reviews.Content: I had an S90 that I struggle with the AutoISO.S90 ISO jumps to 800 and above when I don't want it to - which results in graniness.S95 fixes this BIG problem. ISO stays around 600 in low light and image is MUCH CLEANER.Now S95 is almost perfect.Note: Sepia filter is removed in S95 but you get miniature mode instead.Still I prefer manual pop up flash like the LX5. This one has to scroll through buttons to activate the flash - that's the only flaw which is BIG to me.

Reviews.Title: Amazing camera!
Reviews.Author: Po
Reviews.Content: I have never had a point and shoot and up to this point I have used much larger cameras (i.e., Nikon F100, D70, Canon AE-1).  I wanted to buy a camera that would allow me to start taking pictures again after not having touched my cameras for 3-4 years and I wanted a camera that would produce quality images, but would not be very cumbersome.  That is precisely what this camera does, and on top of it, it produces high quality video that allows you to record a variety of events without the inconvenience of having to carry around a much larger camera.  I am extremely satisfied with this product.  My ONLY two complaints about this camera are (1) that, depending on the mode, the flash can pop up while your finger is on the place where it is housed, causing the flash to freeze in place and requiring you to turn it off and then back on again.  Not sure how this could have been avoided though considering that it is precisely where you would expect the flash to be housed and (2) on the video you sometimes get vertical lines.  That said, I am consistently impressed with the high quality of the images produced, even when taken in very low light situations.  If you can swing it, you will not regret buying this camera.

Reviews.Title: Great still photo camera, video just good.
Reviews.Author: W. Jaffier
Reviews.Content: I previously owned the Canon SD870IS and I loved that camera.  The s95 is a great upgrade, so if you're upgrading from the SD870IS, it's safe!  Pictures are outstanding, even in auto mode.  Manual mode has lots of options for those that know what they're doing!  Video looks beautiful but I wish it was 30fps instead of 24fps.  As some have stated, relatively fast action at 24fps comes out a little too jerky for me.  Lack of auto-focus while recording is inexcusable for a camera at this price point.  I've read that this can be overcome with a CHDK firmware update, but have yet to try this.  I haven't run into the battery problems that some have pointed out.  I've used the camera for a few parties shooting both pics and video and each time the battery level showed to be not less than 1/2 life remaining.  Obviously people will get different mileage based on what they're doing.Despite my gripes, I don't regret getting this camera.  The video is still good and with a little thought up front, the video can be great.  When the s9x upgrade comes out, I'll be onboard as long as they up the frame rate to 30fps, at which point it will be a complete all-around camera!

Reviews.Title: Best Camera On The Market!!
Reviews.Author: Moshe Medalie
Reviews.Content: I have owned several Canon cameras over the last 5/6 years, and I must say that I have never come across a camera so brilliant like this camera. I am not a professional cameraman, so I use the green "auto" function most of the time, and I must say that the camera is near perfect for all auto function shots.If you want to learn how to use an SLR, this is the way to go. Camera gives tips on how to adjust aperture and shutter speed, but still allows you to have full manual control.What more can you expect from Canon?!

Reviews.Title: Very close to the perfect cruise camera.
Reviews.Author: Steven M. Frankel
Reviews.Content: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera with 3.8x Wide Angle Optical Image Stabilized Zoom and 3.0-Inch inch LCDI'm in a holding pattern on my quest to discover the perfect cameras to take on 2-3 week ocean cruises.  Because of health and baggage weight issues, I decided to limit myself to one rolling carry-on bag that could -- while going to and from a cruise -- carry 1-2 camera systems, a monopod, a 5-pound  laptop,  and a 4-pound Canon iP-100 color printer.On the cruise, while shooting around the ship and on land tours, I want to limit myself to about 3-4 pounds for the cameras, lenses, monopod and bag; and ensure that at least one camera is able to be carried in a front pants pocket.On my last 2 cruises I carried a Panasonic Lumix GH1 with the 14-140 and 20 mm lenses, and a Canon "shirt-pocket" SD780 IS  for walking around the ship and going places where cameras were at risk or frowned upon.  This setup weighed 7 pounds in the bag and it took care of my photographic needs beautifully; but it's increasingly difficult to take all this on walking tours and take candids of day-to-day life on the ships.  I also ended up adding a 2-pound 24" carbon fiber SLYK monopod with a ballhead to my luggage when I discovered that video requires a more stable platform than most humans can provide; and upgrading the GH1 to a GH2 on general principles.Planning for my next cruise, I replaced my aging SD780 IS with a Canon S95 "front pants pocket camera" and discovered, to my delight, that up to the 8x10" prints I can produce on my little portable printer, the S95's image quality is very close to the GH1/GH2's; and it can even shoot decent videos (but not in the GH1/GH2 class) with just a 7-oz, 15" monopod to steady it; as well beautiful indoor candid shots thanks to its f2.0 lens.  Thus for my next trip in May, I've reduced my cruise camera package from 7 pounds to 1 pound, and its replacement cost from about $2000 to $500.I think that the S95 is already close to the perfect cruise ship camera, and "all" I'm looking for right now is a second camera: a 1-pound super zoom camera with at least a 20x zoom ratio, an electronic finder nearly as good as the GH1/GH2's finder (LCDs are virtually useless on bright days on the water), and print quality that's at least as good as the S95's up to 8x10s.  After looking at all the available models, I don't think that this "second camera" exists yet; but I believe it will be available in the next generation of super zooms that will hopefully be available by Christmas.  I believe it can be done by Canon by adding the S95's sensor and a higher quality electroncic  finder to an update of the SX30 IS; or by Nikon whose P500 has everything but -- in my opinion -- the sensor quality of the S95 and a viewer that's nearly as good as the GH2's; or by Panasonic or Olympus when they decide to produce a 4/3 super zoom with an internal GH2-quality electronic finder.  Any of these probabilities will result in a great camera to shoot boats and long-range candids for around one additional pound of weight; and allow me to end up with a 2-pound, 2-camera, (hopefully) $1,000 system that provide all the capabilities I need for all my styles of cruise shooting.For virtually everyone else however, I've no hesitation in annnointing the Canon PowerShot S95 as my choice as "2011 Cruise Camera of the Year."

Reviews.Title: Canon Powershot S95: Amazing
Reviews.Author: byrno
Reviews.Content: The price for the camera matches the high quality and long features list.Surprisingly heavy for the size but such a powerful camera, it leaves my Digitial SLR sitting on the shelf a lot more often.Basically functions as a point and shoot all the way up to eating into features you used to only get on the DSLRs but much more compact.Guaranteed you'll catch your finger on the automated flash moving down at some stage but, only a minor complaint on an otherwise excellent camera.

Reviews.Title: Love the features
Reviews.Author: Konacoffee
Reviews.Content: I got this camera mostly for fun as I'm mainly a dslr Canon photographer.  This camera has many wonderful manual features and easy to carry around when I don't have my heavy dsrl gear.  Low lighting shots are very good.  Love the various "scenes" - tons of fun and creative capability.  Basically I love the size and the features.  There's always room for improvement on image quality, but then I'm comparing it to a dslr with a much better sensor.Two downsides:1.  Macro capability is not good.2.  On telephoto I see lots of "digital noise".

Reviews.Title: This is my second Canon, and i love it.
Reviews.Author: J. Evans
Reviews.Content: I've owned a Canon SD630 for the past 5 years and the camera was awesome. It still works to this day, but i thought it was time for an upgrade since the family was going on vacay and i wanted the best possible pics to remember it. I wanted to stick with Canon since i loved the one i had so much. Size was important(since i am not ready to lug around a big bad, just for a camera), and great picture quality. I think this camera is exactly what i was looking for. I've had it for about 3 days now and i've been able to figure out a lot of the "fancier" functions like controlling shutting speed, aperture, and the low light capturing pretty quickly. This was something i never tried to do on my old camera, im not even sure if my old one could. This one was easy to figure out and i am no camera expert. The pictures i have taken so far blow me away compared to the norm ive had over the past 5 years. I am in love with my new camera. There is so much more that i can play around with.My only complaint is the wrist strap. it's just one big loop that hangs around your wrist and could fall off very easily. i plan on purchasing a new one that has a way of adjusting the hole to fit my wrist. My old canon had a great wrist strap so i dont know why they would get rid of them. Other than that i highly recommend to people who want a great camera in a small package.

Reviews.Title: AWESOME CAMERA!!! ABSOLUTELY SUPERB IMAGES
Reviews.Author: Davo "davosan"
Reviews.Content: The S95 is absolutely outstanding! I'm amazed! I wasn't supposed to buy a PowerShot in a while, since 8 months ago I bought a Canon SX210IS in order to have a short trips substitute for my Canon Rebel XSi. I was quite disappointed with the SX210, since it took blurry, not well defined and colorless pictures. Last december, it was stolen from my luggage so I had to buy a new one (my second chance, this time I had to buy a good one). After 8 months, I though not much should have changed, but then I saw many reviews about the new S95 and I was curious. After surfing around, I found this webpage in which you can check and compare easily the specs and other information about many cameras on the market.[...]My first concern, was the flash thing (that it was placed in an unconfortable and not intuitive place). FORGET ABOUT IT. The SX210 was a real pain in the a.., every time I wanted to take a picture I found my finger stopping the flash to pop up. With the S95, even if the flash is placed in the same place, it has enough space behind to let you place your finger without interfering with the flash.The zoom is perfect! Even the digital zoom is amazing.The size and weight, no comments! Just great!But the more important thing about this camera is how amazing and beautiful the pictures come out. It's magic! It just interprets exactly what your eyes see, no more, no less. It has been a while since I am not as happy with an electronic product as I am with this camera! I'm starting to feel sorry for my poor Rebel XSi because it hasn't seen any light since I bought this one!Don't delay your decision, if you want a compact, full feature camera with an incredible image quality, this is the one! If I find out how to upload pictures in here, I'll put a couple.

Reviews.Title: Excellent "tween" camera
Reviews.Author: Barret
Reviews.Content: Guys, this camera rocks. The settings and the features are unlike any that I have seen before. Kick butt feature is the dial on the lens like a SLR camera, but, completely customizable to be any feature you would like, from focus to you name it. another kick butt feature is the color accent which allows you to choose a object and the camera remembers the color, and turns everything else into black and white. so, if you choose blue eyes, and the rest of the persons face would then be black and white, accenting their blue eyes. I went online to try to find this camera, everyone in Illinois was sold out. I had to go to a big box, and have them locate it and ship it to me. I am at DePaul in photography class, and I am telling you this camera does more than I need for this class. I choose not to purchase a $600.00 comparable camera when all I need is this one. I paid $399.00 + $50.00 for overnight shipping. Great video recorder as well. and the best part, when I am finished I pop it in my pocket and go. Try that with a DSLR!!!!!!!!

Reviews.Title: A great Point n Shoot
Reviews.Author: Utsemi
Reviews.Content: I have had this camera for several months and put it through the paces. I am what the camera industry calls a prosumer, professional consumer. I have many DSLR cameras and equipment. The Canon S95 is very easy to use and intuitive. It also has many advanced features that will make any dslr user feel at home. The biggest draw back for me was the shooting speed, but too be honest it is faster than any other Point N Shoot I have shot with, just slow in caparison to a dslr. The only minor draw back was the battery life, I only got around 100 to 200 with flash and about 200 to 300 with out. So make sure you are always fully charged before you go anywhere. If you are looking for versatile, compact, light weight point n shoot that will deliver phenomenal shots the Canon S95 is the way to go.

Reviews.Title: Good choice for 2nd camera for DSLR owners
Reviews.Author: Just a photog
Reviews.Content: Nice size, RAW + JPEG, excellent image quality and it does slow 2nd curtain sync, what's not to like? Small battery means you will need a spare, not cheap for a point and shoot and the video is just OK. I don't mind carrying an extra battery and if I want video I'll get a video camera.This is a terrific still camera for serious photographers looking for something to carry around all the time which is exactly what I am doing.

Reviews.Title: Almost As Good As An SLR......
Reviews.Author: Toolman
Reviews.Content: No need to repeat the obvious improvements over the Canon S90 that have already been discussed.  This is a very nice small camera, certainly among the best available. Probably the best.  It is not an SLR, but comes very close, and is great to have with you when you can't carry the big stuff and lenses and all the assessories.I am very happy to have bought this, even though I already have an S90.

Reviews.Title: Great, pocketable P&S;
Reviews.Author: BKK Reviewer
Reviews.Content: I wrestled for weeks whether to buy this or the Panasonic LX5. In the end, the S95's size won out, and I've been extremely pleased with image quality. It so happened that my Nikon D90, for which I bought this as a pocketable complement, broke during a recent two-week family vacation. The S95 is so great, I only missed my D90 a few times. The only thing I've been unimpressed with is shutter lag, which is the the bane of all point-and-shoots, and I expected it, but I'd hoped they'd done more to remedy it since I last bought a P&S; about four years ago. (It's been largely sitting on my shelf during those years because it was so slow as to be utterly useless). The S95 is quick but by no means fast. Where it excels, though, is image quality, low-light situations and its easy access to manual controls. Its ergonomics are really terrible, though. But I guess that's just the compromise you get when you want something that fits comfortably in a pocket. Oh, and that click wheel they put on the back of the S95? I can't imagine how anyone used the S90 at all if it didn't have the clicks -- I'm constantly turning the click wheel by mistake as it is.

Reviews.Title: PowerShot S95 - BEST POINTSHOT CAMERA
Reviews.Author: asap85
Reviews.Content: I just bought the Powershot S95 about a week ago. I have been playing with all the features and I have to say "What a great camera". I played with the SD4500 at the store so I can't give my best opinion on that. But I will say the the s95 has shown very promising results. The Biggest difference is the Manual use feature. Its like having a manual car and you are complete control. I have gone through Sony, Nikkon, and other Canan point shoot cameras. This camera gave the best Low light photos and that was my biggest priority. I choose not to ever use the flash now. So nice to just take natural shots with natural colors. Using the manual feature you can turn any night time photo into a day time photo. You just need to know how to use the shutter, aperture, and iso levels. This is the only point shot camera that alows you to control everything. The price is worth every penny because once you buy a camera your stuck with it for a while and you want to get the most out of every penny you pay. I am not a professional nor and advanced user and after reading the manual(very important) I was able to take amazing clear shots. You can also adjust the flash amount which saves me from all of my photos looking bright white. If you just want to take the camera straight out of the box and just starting shooting, then AUTO feature will do great. I think the powershot s95 is a great camera and is something you should consider.- Again: READ THE MANUAL!!!(atleast on the different modes and how to use them)

Reviews.Title: Extremely poor flash placement
Reviews.Author: Jason, Engineer, Gadget nut, Father of 3
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera knowing about the flash placement and thinking it would not be that big of a deal.Well, I should have followed my instincts on this.  The typical way that I, my wife and, I believe, most people hold a small camera like this is with the "pinch" method of finger and thumb pinching the camera from both ends.  This method puts your finger directly over the pop up flash and each thumb under the camera on either side.  When the flash needs to come up it forces its way up and you have to move your finger.  I returned the camera to Amazon with no hassles.As a gadget and photo nut sometimes it takes the common sense of my wife to look at me and say "Why would you want a camera that is not designed well?".  Reluctantly I listened to her about this new toy I have purchased and realize that she is right.Image quality was nothing special compared to my Canon SD780is even though review sites like imaging-resource.com show significant improvement in noise and sharpness in the test images.  I recently bought the Sony HX5V and have been very pleased with the colors, detail and operation.  The colors on these small Canon's all seem to be too ruddy or orange to me when taking people shots with the flash.Just to qualify my review I own and use the following cameras:Nikon D700Nikon D90Canon SD770Canon SD780is

Reviews.Title: Replaced twice... error message
Reviews.Author: PhotoBuff "PhotoBuff"
Reviews.Content: I have purchased this camera twice in the last 2 years. The first one jammed and just never worked again and the second one had a problem with the flash getting stuck and would not pop up when i wanted to take a flash pic. the error message would say "flash error" and it just jammed. I liked the pics and feel disappointed but don't feel like i can try again a third time as its too expensive to keep replacing

Reviews.Title: from a non-pro...this camera is outstanding
Reviews.Author: westsidemd "westsidemd"
Reviews.Content: IF you are not a professional photographer and don't have the time or inclination to really get into photography (because that is what it takes to capture the best photos), then like me you are just looking for the best bang for your buck as far as pointing and shooting for the best possible results.  if so, then this camera is your do not pass go camera.  i don't know a thing about aperture, shutter speed or any of that nonsense.  all i know is sometimes the picture turns out better with a flash or without a flash so i like to know how to change that function.  other than that, i keep it on auto mode and point and shoot.  with this camera i've taken photos where friends and family have asked me if i had them professionally done.  that's good enough feedback for me!i love this camera.  it takes crisp clear colorful bright outstanding photos.  it's small, i can take it anywhere.  it's awesome.

Reviews.Title: Way Better Than My DSLR
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: Perfect pictures every time -- seems no matter what the lighting conditions are. I mainly just shoot jpeg in auto and it blows away anything I could get with my Canon EOS-10D (DSLR) and I've had eight years of experience with that camera (was a good camera in its day).Reviews that complain about the design: Its a DSLR shooters compact -- that explains the design -- you just gotta get used to it, and if you can you'll love it. I find myself holding it like a DSLR thanks to that nifty ring on the lens, therefore, I don't have the problems others talk about regarding the flash popping up under their index finger, but I can see how that can happen. Button positions only took an hour to get used to, but they make sense considering the concept. Smudges on the screen? It's a nice big brilliant screen. Heck, I get smudges on my smart phone too -- wipes right off.As you can see, I got no complaints.

Reviews.Title: A very high end camera on a budget -  Love it!
Reviews.Author: Traveller2k
Reviews.Content: I used SLR and other P&S; earlier and have a DSLR now . After purchasing this and looking at my 10x13 and 11x17 I know I have what I always wanted. Going to sell my DSLR. Recently we went to a professional photo studio to get some portraits for my kids in ethnic attire. After 20 minutes session we selected 3 pictures and after coupon paid them $52.Reaching back I created the similar background and used this camera and my prints almost came close to what I got by paying to a studio. Absolutely recommend it to anyone who can stretch budget to ~$350 range rather than ~$150 for normal P&S; and you will love your purchase 10/10. It has what other bulky SLR's in $2500+ price range offer

Reviews.Title: Adding to the tally/ vote
Reviews.Author: M. S. Kubota
Reviews.Content: Terrific camera with very few short-comings.  Coming from lugging around heavy SLRs (EOS-1D), this has changed my perspective on travel photography.  Don't get me wrong- I miss the speed, ergonomics, and total control of the SLR.  But the compact nature of this camera and it's ability to give me 85% of what I want and need while traveling has put my SLRs in the backseat.  And while I still remain dedicated to still photography the video capture is a huge bonus.  Between this thing, my iPad and my Droid X, traveling has never been better than it is now in the 21st century!

Reviews.Title: Outstanding!
Reviews.Author: Grandpa
Reviews.Content: When I made photography my career over 40 years ago, I never thought I would ever see a camera that does everything the S95 does. The S95 technology would be considered science fiction back then. I have been a Canon customer for many years and use the EOS 1DS in the studio. The small size of the S95 allows me to take it with me wherever I go, but I still have the option to shoot in RAW format like the pro equipment. My most challenging adjustment was getting used to shooting without a viewfinder, but I am very pleased with the image quality and the features of the S95.

Reviews.Title: 2 cameras, both had hot pixels in video
Reviews.Author: C. Negron
Reviews.Content: I just wanted to point out I've received 2 of these and they both have had hot pixels in video mode, at least that is when it was most noticeable.They hot pixels (red in this case) were visible after replaying on the PC which points to a sensor issue. Please check yours when you get it. I will wait a while before I order another one, in case its a batch production problem.Otherwise most everything is an improvement over the previous model which I owned as well. Take this with a grain of salt, but I've also felt that the pictures from this camera are a bit softer than they were on my S90.

Reviews.Title: Great camera if your expectations are realistic.
Reviews.Author: Pappa C
Reviews.Content: OK, calm down everybody.  Let's be realistic here.  This is a great camera for its size, but those of you saying it is going to replace your DSLR are sadly mistaken.  It is nowhere near DSLR image quality.With that said, it is a very nice camera that can be taken anywhere.  And the image quality is just good enough to get you by when you don't want to lug your DSLR around.  We love ours and take it on family outings or local trips.  But when I need image quality, I don't hesitate to grab my DSLR.  Just don't expect too much out of this little camera and you will be quite pleased.

Reviews.Title: Great little camera for when you don't want to carry your DSLR
Reviews.Author: Jon S.
Reviews.Content: I love that this camera shoots in RAW (except in auto mode) and has manual settings. It is good in low light and lets you do much more than you could with just a standard point and shoot.

Reviews.Title: As good as it gets
Reviews.Author: WV Radio Guy
Reviews.Content: This little Cannon replaced what I consider the finest pocket camera in the world, the Fuji F-30. If Fuji still made that camera, I would have bought several more as spares. But they don't, so I was looking for a camera that came as close to the Fuji as possible, and the Cannon was it. The thing that made the Fuji so wonderful was it's amazing low light capability. Nothing came close, but this Cannon is as close as you'll get. The interesting thing is that while the Cannon isnt quite as good as the Fuji for hand held low light conditions, it's actually better than the Fuji for normal lighting conditions. The resolution is really amazing for a pocket camera. Are these top of the line pocket cameras expensive? You bet! But you get what you pay for, and if you want the best photos in a pocket camera, the Cannon is the way to go.

Reviews.Title: great point and shoot
Reviews.Author: Bobby "Bobby"
Reviews.Content: I have used this camera on many trips. The picture quality is awesome, especially in low light situation. I bought this camera when it was still relatively cheap like $280. I cant believe the price has gone up by so much. The battery last a long long time. The video I took has very clear audio and very sharp video as long as one doesnt zoom.

Reviews.Title: Favorite Canon Compact - But Got Euro Version
Reviews.Author: Terry M
Reviews.Content: Caution - I ordered a second one as a back up (Aug 2012) from "Big VALUE Inc". Although it is new and at a good price (320), the one I got was a Euro / UK version and came with the CB-2LYE charger (that has a cord that plugs into it) with a UK cord and a US cord. The USA version comes with a CB-2LY charger with a built-in flip out plug. I did get a brand new S95 and a genuine battery - which is what I really wanted - just no USA charger.As for the camera, it is my favorite Canon compact I've ever had. I have had several ELPHs (S110, S230, S500, SD1200) and this camera blows them away. It reminds me of the G12 more than the ELPH series but is the smaller size. Yes it is a little more money than the ELPH, but it is also a MUCH better camera - it is like a miniture G12 with almost all the features and half the size. If you need a great camera that is small enough to bring with you this is it. I prefer the S95 over the new version because it uses the same battery as my Canon D10 underwater camera and my SD1200 ELPH which I now use at work.

Reviews.Title: Still the best bet for the serious amateur or potential pro
Reviews.Author: Samuel Chell
Reviews.Content: You can purchase point and shoots with more impressive specs in virtually every category, but you can't buy a subcompact  (the actual size of this camera) that's capable of making better photos than the Canon S-95.  It's a time-tested camera, one that even the pros return to repeatedly, coaxing prize-winning photos from it time and time again.  Not only does the camera afford the user less automation and more control (including the ability to produced raw, non-compressed images), but its "reasonable" cap of 10 megapixels (instead of the 12 or more that are increasingly being jammed into small cameras) produces shots that are ultimately clearer, deeper, richer, and more "verisimilitudinous" than those taken with cameras weighed down by excessive baggage.Even though point-'n-shoots now have ISO settings running up to 6400, 12,800 and higher, the small sensors of these cameras tend to pick up more distortion, or "noise," which is merely made more conspicuous by high megapixel counts.  The more megapixels manufacturers cram onto these sensors, the more visual flaws you can expect to see in the images.If you've ever wondered why your 3.2mp camera of 7-8 years ago seemed to produce better pictures than the 16mp miniature camera you recently picked up, it shouldn't be a mystery.  Either get over the American obsession (i.e. that more is better--supersize it, whether your TV screen, your megapixels, your gigabytes) or prepare to step up to a camera with a super-sized sensor at a super-sized price.  Even then, no one should require more than 10 megapixels--short of covering the outside of their house with a blown-up photo of their baby photo.The Canon S-95 continues to be the most desirable camera in its category and prize range--it's simply incapable of being "improved.  The camera is constructed in a way to bring about improvement in the person who's taking the pictures.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: Shane W. Reese
Reviews.Content: This Canon Powershot is very much improved from older models that I've owned. It is very compact and well made.  Although it is a bit on the heavy side. It Takes beautiful pictures. Video is real good as long as you don't zoom in all they way. Very easy to use with a quick read through the manual. The worst part about the camera is where the pop up flash is located. It's right on top where I usually rest my finger. It takes some getting used too. I would recommend this camera.

Reviews.Title: Good pocket camera
Reviews.Author: Bong
Reviews.Content: I'm a DSLR user who needed a pocket camera I can take to family event where I didn't want to bring my big DSLR but takes better photos and video then my iPhone 4.  This is a great compromise.  Small enough to fit in my camera with much of the features of my DSLR, including RAW shooting and manual settings.  The controls felt so much like my Canon DSLR that I tried using it in low-light situations where I found it produced acceptable pictures where my iPhone could not.  But I was disappointed that the low-light shots were quite grainy, a far cry from my DSLR.  I guess that was asking too much from such a small camera.I was also pleasantly surprised with the quality of the video.  I've stopped using my camcorder and use this for all family videos.Overall, I'm very happy with this camera and glad to have a reliable camera I can bring anywhere.

Reviews.Title: My go-everywhere camera!
Reviews.Author: John A. Milliner "konfuzd1"
Reviews.Content: It seems that other reviewers have more than covered the great technical aspects of the s95, so I just wanted to put in my two cents and share my personal experience after owning this camera for a little over a year. I am the unit historian (aka photographer) for my National Guard unit. Last year, a few of us were selected for a mission to Poland, specifically for which I purchased the s95. It did not disappoint. From action shots to low light, every image was sharp and the color was excellent. At one point, however, I found myself in a Tyvek suit around a lot of water and I passed the camera off to a soldier from another unit. I don't know what happened in the interim, but when I got it back it looked like it had been dropped from a height of about ten feet. There were two deep gouges in the lower right corner of the rear plate, and the plate itself was noticeably bent - so much that the battery door was very difficult to open and the top panel no longer fit properly. Even more unfortunate was the fact that I didn't notice this damage until the next day, mainly because THE CAMERA STILL WORKED JUST FINE! My grip had covered the obvious damage, and it was not until I went to charge the battery that I noticed the scuffing and deformation. I know this is not marketed as a rugged camera, but I must say I've been quite impressed by its survivability. For the last year, I've used it extensively in the field. It's been wet, dusty, dropped and banged around, and my images look every bit as good today as they did on day one. At full screen (not 100%), its pretty hard to tell the images shot with the s95 apart from those from my 50D or T2i. Bottom line: for me, this camera has absolutely earned its keep. It is worth every penny!

Reviews.Title: Amazing pictures and fun to use
Reviews.Author: Chris K
Reviews.Content: I have a larger SLR camera that I love, but it is not always convenient for travel. I was concerned that I wouldn't be able to find a point and shoot camera that is capable of taking quality photos that I would be happy with. I am awed by the S95's capability. I enjoy the flexibility of being able to take photos in manual mode, automatic, or one of the "Scene" modes.  The photos I have taken have come out amazing. The colors are vivid and the images crisp. The software that comes with the camera for editing RAW images does a good job and is easy to use.  It is small, convenient for travel and takes amazing images. I would recommend this camera.

Reviews.Title: Great camera
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: This camera is a very nice high-end point and shoot. It has many features and allows you to change things manually which is something I love to do. I know it is just a p and s but I still wish the zoom was better.  Also while recording video, once you start the only zooming will be digital.Overall the price was a little high, and zooming was sub-par but the quality and customization more than made up for it.

Reviews.Title: Awesome pictures!
Reviews.Author: ryn996
Reviews.Content: This camera is worth the money. It takes amazing shots and is easy to use, even with all the advanced settings. I've owned Koadak's and Panasonic's, but Canon digital cameras always take the best pictures.

Reviews.Title: Amazing great camera
Reviews.Author: Alfredo Rico
Reviews.Content: It performs up to expectations.  Great colour, focus, speed, manual and automatic controls, etc.  Great camera.  The only reason I gave it a 4 star is because for the difference in price, you rather go for the S100 with better zoom, slow motion video and faster "High-speed burst function" (shooting continuously when the shutter button is held down). I actually don't really get trilled for the higher resolution of 12.1 MP since the more megapixels (generally) less light sensitivity for indoor pictures.  Anyway, in my opinion, best camera in the world (other than reflex).

Reviews.Title: Excellent small, take-everywhere, camera
Reviews.Author: Joel G Hashimoto
Reviews.Content: I really like having the S95 as a complimentary small camera to carry when I want something better than my iPhone 4 but not as big and heavy as my D7000. Movies look good and the ability to capture raw files is great. The ability to change main settings easily is nice but I find myself using P mode most of the time since it is a 'point and shoot'. I got this camera when it was on sale as a 'Gold Box Deal Of The Day' so it was a great value. The current price is the only thing that gives me pause (and the reason for the 4 star rating). It just depends on how much you value having such a competent camera in a very small package.

Reviews.Title: Canon PowerShot S95, Big Features in a Small Package
Reviews.Author: Bob P
Reviews.Content: This purchase was as a gift for our daughter, so that she could post pictures of our new grandson.  It was selected specifically because it had superior lens and image-capture features, as well as a great reputation for quality.  It did not disappoint.  The pictures and short video that has been shared have been excellent.  In fact, I am about to shop for another one for myself.  Pictures shot with this camera compare very favorably with shots taken with much more expensive SLR models, without the bother and fuss of additional lenses and the bulk of the SLR, especially when a young family has enough other things to be carrying around.  A curious fact is that the newer version, the S100 is not as highly rated, so this model is more desirable, if you can find one.

Reviews.Title: wow
Reviews.Author: Tony Huynh
Reviews.Content: some of the pictures i take look like they came out of a magazine.  if you know how to use the P mode, this thing is amazing.  the contrast is perfect, the colors aren't over saturated, the crispness of the pictures is amazing.  GET THIS CAMERA!

Reviews.Title: Great camera
Reviews.Author: GH "Ross"
Reviews.Content: This puppy takes great pictures but like all cameras with manual settings it has a learning curve.  Dont just clip off a few shotson auto and base your opinion on the results.  Take lots of pictures and try every setting to become familiar with its capabilities.  Its worth the effort.

Reviews.Title: Love it!
Reviews.Author: klm
Reviews.Content: Best point-n-shoot I've owned yet. We bought this to replace a Panasonic Lumix waterproof camera that was of great build quality but only really took good pictures under good lighting. This Canon takes great photos pretty much wherever and is truly easy to use. I know a bit about cameras, but am too lazy or busy to get into all the various settings so I needed a good auto camera. VERY happy with this one.

Reviews.Title: Canon S95 only worked for 3 weeks
Reviews.Author: Ib
Reviews.Content: About 3 weeks after receiving Canon PowerShot S95, the linse went suddenly black, everything else worked, I was able to see the photos already taken etc. I was going to europe next day, and thought I would have a better look at it when I arrived there.  I went to a Canon authorized shop in France and only then realized that the guarantee only covered Canada and North America. Canon in France told me that I needed a new linse, but would have to pay that myself, which would be almost half the price of the camera. It would have been nice to know prior my purchase, that the gurantee was limited.

Reviews.Title: A five-star compact P&S;!
Reviews.Author: R. Jones "Coffee Hound"
Reviews.Content: I've owned this unit for several months, but was waiting until I had taken a few hundred photos with it.  I purchased it as a replacement for the Powershot Elf 300HS which was good in many respects, but falls short of the quality and consistency of the S95.  This one will stay in my arsenal and on my belt loop holster when I need a great kick-around reliable camera.  The 10 MP photos are stunning.  For quick-fire everyday shots, I use the vivid setting available in the "P" or program mode.  Everything else is automatic and I rarely do much editing to the shots.  If I want to tweak the results, the processed jpegs lend themselves readily to adjustment tweaks in photoshop or whatever program you use.  Raw is available if that's your bag.  The low light capabilities of the S95 are good for both photos and videos.  I can't complain about the 720 Hi Def.  It's plenty powerful for the slideshows and Blu Ray discs that I produce and creates efficiency by saving both time and space when burning discs-i.e., the files aren't so large as to be space hogs.  The slide shows produced from this little beauty are as good as it gets and I have burned some really impressive bluray discs.  Most of the S95 shots on "Program" need no editing or adjustment whatsoever.  Just load 'em up, add motion and transitions, a little background music and burn away!  The results are wonderful, colorful, and professional looking.There is very little lag time photo to photo and I rarely find myself waiting for the camera to complete any processing.  Just fire it up and take off.  It's ready when you are.  For its size & weight, I think it's one of the best & highest quality pieces of consumer photo equipment Canon ever built.  And I put the quality of it's photos right up there with my highly acclaimed Canon Powershot G12 which is considerably larger & heavier.  Either of these camera's make a great backup for my Canon 60d SLR, but I'd prefer to carry the S95 over either of them.  The only time I use the larger units is when I need a more powerful flash in the hotshoe.  Oh, and the 3" digital screen display is a beauty.  I used it last week in bright sunlight, and didn't have significant problems framing my shots.I recommend the S95 without hesitation to anyone wanting high quality photos in a strong lightweight camera that's comfortable in your purse, pocket, or belt holster.NOTE TO CANON:  If I could add one thing to the S95 to make it a perfect unit, I would add a little video record button that was available full time like the Elf 300 HS rather than having to spin the mode dial to the movie mode.  It makes moving back and forth between photo and video kind of cumbersome and old-fashioned.

Reviews.Title: Love It!
Reviews.Author: Heather Dedman
Reviews.Content: Absolutely love this camera! I have an older canon dslr that has been my main camera for several years now, and as much as I love it and the pictures that it takes I needed something more portable. But I wasn't willing to sacrifice quality or control. This camera could not be more perfect in that regard. It takes amazing pictures and decent video, and I can still change any of the settings that I would ever really need to change. I will say that the preset settings on this camera do a pretty decent job on there own. I've been particularly impressed by the low light setting. However I love having the ability to tweak the setting if necessary.  This camera is also perfect in size, nice and small without being too small, and fast too. The shutter lag is virtually non-existant! And we all know how important that last one is. Nothing is worse than missing the picture because you are waiting on your camera, and that has not been as issue with this camera!  I love that this camera uses rechargeable batteries! The battery life is decent, and with the spare I bought as a backup I don't think a dead battery will ever cause me to miss a photo. My one complaint is the pop up flash. It pops up exactly where you naturally want to place your finger to hold the camera. I have gotten used to it and try to hold the camera with just my right hand. But, if anyone else is using my camera (say to take a picture with me in it) they always place their finger over the flash which sometimes prevents it from popping up.  I worry that this will eventually cause the flash to break. However that is a problem I was aware of when I got the camera, and it would not prevent me from buying this camera again.  The pros definitely outweigh the one con.

Reviews.Title: Canon PowerShot S95 Delivers!
Reviews.Author: Gary Adams
Reviews.Content: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera with 3.8x Wide Angle Optical Image Stabilized Zoom and 3.0-Inch LCD  I've been waiting nearly  a year to replace my compact digital camera.  During my search for a new camera, I finally decided the Canon PowerShot S95 would meet my needs.  When Amazon put the camera on a one day special sale, I jumped at the opportunity.  I have not been disappointed.  For cameras of this type, most of the "practical" features are very similar.  My decision to purchase this camera came down to 4 distinct criteria.  First was the "manufacturer."  Canon is one of the primary leaders in photographic quality.  Their reputation is solid.  Secondly, I wanted a camera with a "fast" lens.  The wider the aperture, the better the light gathering capability the camera has.  At a wide angle setting, the stated aperture is F 2.0.  Few cameras meet this criteria.  Third, having a "long zoom" was not that important to me.  I wasn't going on a safari and many of my images would be taken indoors of family and friends.  If I need closer up images of my subject, I merely move closer.  Finally, "price" was a major consideration.  In my assessment, the Canon PowerShot S95 gave me the most "bang for my buck."  The ease of use and the quality of the images coupled with the four criteria mentioned above made this camera the best and smartest purchase for me.

Reviews.Title: Best Compact Camera!!!
Reviews.Author: C. Nguyen
