Reviews.Content: I have used many Canon cameras (870is, ELPH 300, sx230) and they all get destroy by this camera.  The s90 is the best and its a big step up from those other cameras that i have used. It feels great in the hand and looks very professional.  The black color is just perfect.  The 3'' lcd screen is very clear and vivid.  Very fast camera for turning on and taking pictures.  No more wait time.  The pictures taken are very clear and have natural but vivid color. The battery is long life. I highly recommend this camera.I have seen the s100 in person and I don't like the new dull black color that they use.  It makes the s100 looks old.

Reviews.Title: great pictures
Reviews.Author: S. Madden
Reviews.Content: This camera may not look, or feel very good but it takes excellent pictures, pictures worthy of a camera that costs at least twice as much. And now that this model has been discounted its an even better deal. Apparently it has a very large censor that is usually found on SLR's. Check out David Pogues video and written reviews on the New York Times site. He raves about it. One caution though, the flash pops out of the top left side of the camera. Be careful not to have your finger over it or you could damage whatever little motor makes the flash pop out. We're very happy with it.

Reviews.Title: Great Little Camera
Reviews.Author: M. Reid
Reviews.Content: I'm a Canon guy, so while I tried to start the process of buying a small camera by evaluating all the similar models, it wasn't hard to narrow my choices to the Canon models.  In the end it came down to the S95 and S100, and for the difference in price, I couldn't justify the added cost of the S100.  My other camera is a Canon 5d MkII, so I'm familiar with the quality of Canon cameras, and the S95 is no exception.  This camera is well built.  It feels solid.  And, most of all, it takes great pictures and it's easy to use.  I wanted something that my wife would enjoy using, as well as a camera I could have available to me when taking the DSLR was too much for the occasion.  I think I hit the sweet spot with the S95.I turn the dial to (A)uto and hand it to the wife.  She is thrilled with the pictures she's able to take.  I can then take it and change the settings to make it shutter speed priority, aperture priority, or use it entirely in manual mode.  I can record pictures in jpeg, jpeg+raw.  I can use autofocus, or I can focus manually.  All with this small, thin, relatively inexpensive camera.  If you like picking up your camera and taking pictures, you'll like the S95.  If you like getting involved in the intricacies of photography, but want a small digital camera with tons of options, you'll like the S95.All-in-all, this is a great little camera.  I am very happy with the Canon S95.

Reviews.Title: I would rate it 6 stars if I could
Reviews.Author: S. Vogt
Reviews.Content: Even though its a year and a half old at this point and its replacement is out... I still think this camera is nothing short of amazing for all the photographic firepower it packs into such a small body.The S95 is well made and feels very solid. It doesn't have a front grip like its successor does but the textured surface makes it fairly easy to grip and hold onto. It is the only enthusiast compact that is truly pocketable. It doesn't have a hotshoe like the other cameras in this class do. But I really don't see a lot of people attach external flashes to their enthusiast compacts. It sort of defeats the whole purpose.The menu system is like most of other Canon's point and shoots. You have your menu button and then your function button. Both are contextual based on what mode you are shooting in. The main attraction of this camera is the rotating lens ring, which you can customize to what ever function you want it to perform. This is part of what makes this camera so great to use.The zoom range on the camera is only 3.8x. Which some people may find too little for what they do. The powershot G12, which uses the same sensor as the S95, has a 5x zoom, so that might be something in the favor of that camera model if you're deciding on the S95 vs. the G12 (you can't go wrong with either, IMO).This is not a very fast camera, but it is faster than its predecessor, the S90. You will find the Autofocus speed tolerable, though. Shot to shot times are mediocre, not terrible, but some of the other models are a little bit fast than the S95.It's photo quality is excellent considering its sensor size. Colors are vibrant, exposure is great, and sharpness and detail capture are excellent for this class of camera. My observation is that photos are pretty clean up to and including ISO400. There's some noticeable noise at ISO800, but photos can still be usable at that sensitivity as well. ISO1600 is not great looking. But, considering its sensor size, this is a pretty good showing.This camera of course shoots in RAW as well which will help you pull some extra detail out of the photos at higher ISOs especially. The jpegs look good, but shooting in RAW will get you superior results.Overall, given its enthusiast level feature set and its excellent functionality and superb photo quality, this is a camera that I recommend to anybody, novice or enthusiast.

Reviews.Title: Possibly the best point-and-shoot in the market today
Reviews.Author: Relentless "skepticalbeliever"
Reviews.Content: I'm writing this review from the perspective of a photography hobbyist for 20+ years. The first thing I have to make clear is that you have to bring your expectations in line with what this camera is at the end of the day: a point-and-shoot. It does take very good pictures, but don't expect them to be comparable to those that can be taken with a DSLR -- period.Now, there are couple reasons I gave a four-star rating:* Fish-eye effect is quite frankly atrocious. If you have ever taken pictures with a real fish-eye lens, you'll immediately notice that the effect in this camera is almost comical, looks nothing like the real thing -- not even close.* Not fat-finger friendly. Has lost of controls, nobs, rings, etc. that are small and close together which can be a pain to deal with if you have above average finger width.* User manual (the real one) is online and print only. Which makes it quite annoying when you're on the go and trying to look up certain functionality.* ISO's above 400 yield a tad too much noise to be useful or fit for printing (without some serious noise reduction post process).Why should you buy this camera?* This camera has one of the best image processors in the market (Digic IV), one of the largest photo sensors for a point-and-shoot and relatively low megapixel count -- this is actually a really good thing I wish more manufacturers would start doing.* Very good picture quality, color rendition for such small camera.* Very reasonable amount of noise under ISO 400, degrades quickly at 800-plus.* Tilt-shift (Miniature) effect is actually very good and pretty darn close the real thing.* Lens is reasonably good, very nice and sharp at apertures of 6.3-plus.* Very nice Macro mode with very nice bokkeh (very nice to see in a point-and-shoot).In all, I think this camera is well worth the money and makes for a good "companion" camera to bring with you when toting your DSLR is just too cumbersome or risky.

Reviews.Title: Well worth the price even when not on super sale.
Reviews.Author: Keith. A truth teller
Reviews.Content: I was one of lucky ones who got this at the 239 price. However even at the regular or 299 price point this is an excellent camera.I know other people who own this and have seen the results first hand. Much better low light performance than your typical point and shoot(larger sensor,faster lens) and in good light this camera is capable of excellent 16x20 inch posters. Ive seen many prints that size from it.If you have high standards for image quality this camera will deliver.

Reviews.Title: Beautiful camera!
Reviews.Author: dane
Reviews.Content: This camera was out of my budget for awhile. When I finally got it, it was greater than expected! After using $100 cameras for years, it is amazing what difference in quality you get with this camera! I was literally blown away! The image is exceptional, my wife says pictures look better in the camera than in real life! I agree. The camera is all that was said in my numerous research online and more. This is the best camera I got so far, and so happy I made this purchase, my wife even more so. I would prefer if this camera was a bit cheaper, say less than $300.00, since I had to stretch a little to get it, but I did not regret spending the money at all. This camera is a treasure! Buy it.

Reviews.Title: Powerful little camera!!!
Reviews.Author: Mshmademedoit
Reviews.Content: Great camera with features of a full on DSLR that fits in your pocket.  But looks like the S100 might take the cake with a wider lens and zoom option when in video mode.  Overall definetely recommend, especially at 329$!!

Reviews.Title: Great camera!
Reviews.Author: John Seale "J.F. Seale"
Reviews.Content: I love this camera!  Our organization bought it for use at our programs - we wanted a high-quality camera that would take great pictures, even indoors or in lower-light situations, but we didn't want to invest all the way in an SLR, especially since that would mean a learning curve for most of our staff and volunteers.  This camera is the top-of-the-line for a point-and-shoot.  Picture quality is great, especially when shooting in RAW.  I love the option to shoot in RAW and JPEG simultaneously - this allows me to quickly run through all the average pictures, then use the RAW format to make a great picture even better.  I also love the control ring on the front of the camera around the lens.  You can program it to control all sorts of different aspects of the picture-taking for instant adjustments without running through a menu.  Overall, it's an excellent camera, well worth the higher price.  If there were one thing I would wish for, it would be a longer zoom.  It feels pretty short.

Reviews.Title: Great pics - except with flash!!
Reviews.Author: Doob In NM
Reviews.Content: I love this camera for daylight/lowlight conditions - beautiful colors, good low-light performance, and the image stabilization is great.  However, when the flash is used (in Auto mode), there is a strange bright yellow tint cast on everything!  Maybe this particular camera is defective, I don't know of other similar complaints for this model.  But it is a serious yellow tint - and hair highlights turn bright yellow.

Reviews.Title: You need to buy this camera!
Reviews.Author: Ashley
Reviews.Content: This is probably the best camera I have ever used. The picture quality is AMAZING! The camera captures colors that are rich and intense. I also took a picture in a dark room and it captured the entire space perfectly. There were no dark shadows or grainy areas.

Reviews.Title: Incredible camera, and so far, so good.
Reviews.Author: Ryan G
Reviews.Content: Wonderful wide-angle shots... incredible low-light performance for a compact (thanks to the huge sensor)... and the best white balance (color) in the industry.I had an S90 (this camera's predecessor) which ended up having 4 serious but noncritical problems within 18 months.  I used it a lot, but I also took good care of it.  It was my 4th digital camera from Canon, and it had far more problems than any other Canon I'd owned (dark spot on lens; flash state issue; loose battery connection issue; and PC connection issues).  But that was the S90.I've now had the S95 for 3 weeks and shot many photos with it, and I'm very impressed.  No issues so far, but the picture quality is stunning, and the startup time and shot-to-shot time (when you turn review off) are incredible - something like 5 frames per second.I actually intentionally bought the S95 rather than waiting a few more weeks for the newer/better S100 to come out.  Why?  Because this camera tries to pack SO MANY physical features into such a tiny package.  My theory is that that's why my S90 had so many problems.  Notice that the S90 and S95 are almost identical cameras, spec-wise; so why bother updating it?  I think it's because they worked out a lot of those kinks.Then along comes the S100, with an even wider-angle lens and better telephoto.  No thanks!  I don't want more problems... I'll wait for a revision on the S100, after they work out the kinks.  I think the S95 is the best thing for now.But I'll be sure to post here if I have problems with it.

Reviews.Title: Overall great camera but definitely loses 1 star for the placement of the flash
Reviews.Author: Hoppaguy
Reviews.Content: I read numerous reviews on this camera and read about the flash problem in that you usually put your finger where the flash comes out of the body in the upper left corner (when looking at the screen. I thought that it wouldn't be a big deal and it isn't for my family because we know not to put our finger there. The problem is when you have other people take your picture; they almost always jam the flash which over time will break the flash mechanism.You might wonder why I would still give 4 stars but the picture quality is amazing. The picture quality rivals my Canon SLR 50D. The low light pictures are what really amaze me because of the warmth of the colors. I decided to buy this camera as an SLR replacement because I was tired of lugging around another bag which almost feels like another carry on for all of our trips. I was also getting tired of lugging the SLR to parties or other events and would just leave it at home. Well, it doesn't do you any good if you want to take a picture and you don't have your camera with you. I looked at a few SLR replacements like the Nikon P6000 but in terms of value and picture quality, I decided on the Canon S95 and have been very happy with the purchase!

Reviews.Title: "Change the battery pack"
Reviews.Author: doctorwl
Reviews.Content: This camera is really good for picture taking. I like it very much. But it has a big problem. For some unknown reasons, occasionally, when I want to turn it on, it keep showing "change the battery pack" on the LCD screen and the camera cannot be turned on, even with a fully charged battery. Recently this happens very often, so I sent it for repair in Canon service center. When I received the repaired camera and tried to turn it on..."change the battery pack", WTF, it still cannot be turned on. This is not a rare case, if you google this online, you will now many people are suffering this.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: William White Jr
Reviews.Content: I own the Canon EOS 5D Mark II full body DSLR.  I wanted a pocket camera that works well when I didn't want to lug  to full body around.  This camera has the same build quality expected from a Canon with a great feature set for those who like to use something other than the "auto" setting.  It small enough to fit in your pocket and takes awesome pictures.  There are other cameras out there with farther zoom capabilites and better video, neither of which were my requirements.  This camera has a similar functionality to my full body and works with all my existing software seamlessly.  I would recomend it to others who have similar wants.

Reviews.Title: unbeliveable clarity!  Almost as good as my canon xsi rebel
Reviews.Author: virtualspirit
Reviews.Content: I wanted a compact camera to carry around as my Canon Rebel EOS is too big.  I tried a bunch of different Canon compacts before I purchased the S95.  Honestly, I didn't want to pay so much for a  compact, but once I got my hands on it, I was amazed.  I have taken some fantastic macro shots of flowers with this camera.  It's amazing.  Still working on figuring out all the various features.. really worth every penny.

Reviews.Title: Excellent camera quality
Reviews.Author: Dennis P. Coyne
Reviews.Content: Very impressive camera.  Have had it less than a month but really like it very well.  I leave for a trip and will only take this one with me - will leave behind my Canon digital SLR.  That is how much confidence I have in the camera.  The Vivid feature under Scene really makes landscape images "pop".  Still learning all the features that will work so well.  The hand strap can be placed on either sider of the camera - nice feature.  The HD movie was beyond my expectations - most excellent.Disappointments - no viewfinder but the screen is very good.  No printed manual - if you spend $400 for a camera, I expect a manual.  Printing parts and cutting it to size were a pain.  The power on button is a little small.Overall - love it - great camera

Reviews.Title: Best pocketable option when you can't bring a DSLR
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I've tried MANY small cameras and did a lot of research and settled on this one and glad I did.  Compared to everything else in it's class and smaller cameras, it's a fantastic choice.  My only gripe is it's a bit slick and doesn't feel secure in my hands but a wrist strap fixes that easy enough.  Get this to carry with you on trips and outings when a DSLR can't come along... you'll find yourself leaving your big camera home more than you think.

Reviews.Title: Very good camera but pricey
Reviews.Author: MAGIC KOALA
Reviews.Content: I bought the Canon S95 after a terrible experience with the Canon 300 HS. All I wanted was a pocket-sized point and shoot, reliable and acceptable picture quality. When I say picture quality, I will add that I use mostly DSLRs (7D, T2i, XSi), and I also have the excellent G11. But I needed a point and shoot for a particular project, and the reviews were very flattering for the 300 HS. Unfortunately, many of the reviewers don't really understand what good quality looks like, especially when it comes to lowlight situations, and effects of ISO. The pictures on the 300 HS were muddy and muted, and anything over ISO 400 looked very grainy and noisy. Perhaps I could have lived with that but the camera also received a lens error message repeatedly within hours of use, rendering it useless. As much as I did not want to spend twice the money,  I decided to go for the S95. It did not exceed my expectations, it did everything I expected from a 400 dollar camera. There is nothing I can ding it for except for it's rather high price. It is compact, light and the controls are very clever. There is nothing to be said about the picture quality, it is excellent as claimed by Canon and the reviewers. Yes, the better sensor has a lot to do with but I can't help but think if the 300 HS had a lower megapixel count, it would've made for a better picture quality.As for reliability, I understand the dreaded lens error message is quite prevalent but I am crossing my fingers.

Reviews.Title: Excellent DSLR alternative
Reviews.Author: Hikeaz
Reviews.Content: I bought this as an alternative to my canon 30D that would be easier to carry regularly.  I've had it for about 4 months and am extremely impressed with the picture quality.  I must admit I use this only in full manual mode.  I don't use any of the auto features or the flash. I set the iso as slow as conditions allow and adjust the exposure manually based on the composition.  If you want complete control over your exposure then this is an ideal camera with picture quality that rivals my dslr.  If you want an idiot proof point and shoot then you can find one for less than half the price.  If you were upset by the demise of Kodachrome 64 then consider this camera.

Reviews.Title: mini  professinal camera
Reviews.Author: inge
Reviews.Content: excellent  digital camera,  with  versatiles possibilities,  it's  the  most little  professional  camera ,

Reviews.Title: Awesome Camera
Reviews.Author: Michael Vega
Reviews.Content: This is one of the best cameras I've ever owned. It takes amazing pictures for one of its size and price.

Reviews.Title: Epic little camera!
Reviews.Author: Jonah Horowitz
Reviews.Content: I picked one of these up a few weeks ago. I've been totally blown away by the image quality. Basically, if you can get over the high(er) price tag, this is the camera to buy hands down. It takes better pictures than my girlfriend's Lumix GF2 DSLR. The low light performance is excellent, the macro detail is amazing, the color performance is great.The only one really little nitpick I have is that I sometimes hit the play button on the back by accident when I'm holding it to take a picture, and really, that's a minor quibble.

Reviews.Title: Great camera
Reviews.Author: Anna
Reviews.Content: This is a great camera and I have big complaints about this.Holding it can be awkward and I tend to hold on the side of the camera where the light bulb would pop up.The quality of the pictures is great and is worth the price if you really want quality pictures.There are lots of fun features to this camera.I would recommend this.

Reviews.Title: Good Sidekick Camera
Reviews.Author: hydRa
Reviews.Content: Canon Powershot S95 is a good side kick camera, it's a pocket size DSLR. Picture quality is good even in low light situation.

Reviews.Title: A few quick comments about the s95, TL500 and LX-5
Reviews.Author: ebull "ebull"
Reviews.Content: Let me say from the outset, image quality, good ergonomics and compact size are what I mostly need in a camera of this typeI have used this camera for 4 months solidly, its what I put in my pocket when I dont want to take my Olympus e620 (also a relatively compact camera in its class)Naturally there are compromises to be made in using one of these compared to an SLR and others have already gone there.So my comments are based on what would be expected for a camera in this class compared to similar top end compact cameras such as TL500, LX-5 (which I have only tried in the shops for 15 minutes)Im more or less assuming image quality is going to be similar, I like to shoot in RAW so minor faults in things like white balance, sharpening, noise reduction, exposure accuracy can be sorted out later in Lightroom on the big screenWhat is more likely to influence the images I get are the ability to be in the right place at the right time with the camera settings ready to goThings I like especially about the s95 are the fact it is the smallest of the top end compacts so I find it easy to have with me, the customizable ring around the lens (which I use to choose exact zoom range at 28, 35, 50 and 85mm, it helps me visualize frames better in my mind when I use standard zoom lengths), customizable shortcut button which I have set to ISO (or AE lock), built in lens cap, easy to delete unwanted photos you have just taken, reasonably responsive shutter speedDislike, the fact the aperture is f/2.0 only at 28mm and gets smaller and smaller compared to say Samsung TL500 or Olympus XZ1Wish list; I wish it had a menu item for set zoom lengths (at the moment only the lens ring has this ability. Otherwise you just use the zoom lever and there is no numerical feedback as to the focal length. This would free the lens ring for other thingsI wish it had a snap focus setting like the Ricoh GRD III so I could shoot from the hip a bit fasterIf I didnt get this I would probably get the TL500 because of the wider zoom at 24mm, the more solid brick like build, the slightly faster lens and the cheaper price!Thats it in a nut shell!

Reviews.Title: Great camera overall
Reviews.Author: L. Garcia "Mapache"
Reviews.Content: a great camera for the value. works really well in low light. I notice it blows out colors sometime, particularly in the red-violet zones with a lot of light (like sunsets) and upclose shots of flowers with a lot of light will tend to blow out whites and reds when on auto. you can switch to manual to compensate for this. overall a great camera for traveling.

Reviews.Title: An excellent camera
Reviews.Author: Tagayo
Reviews.Content: Picture quality is best in class.Perfect size for a compact.Only issue (personal) with camera is the flash location.

Reviews.Title: Great camera,won't disappoint
Reviews.Author: rod
Reviews.Content: I'm going to keep this really simple.I used to have a Casio Exilim.The low light images weren't very good and most pictures had alot of noise with a limited zoom. This camera is exactly what I wanted great zoom, picture quality and no noise. Really easy to use,I really never need to use the flash either.

Reviews.Title: The best compact camera...hands down
Reviews.Author: Moze07
Reviews.Content: I bought this for my trip to Hawaii on Spring Break. Needless to say, I am more than satisfied with the camera. Performance, mobility, ease of use - this camera tops all that's in the market right now.At first I was contemplating whether to buy this camera or Lumix LX5...but I decide to stick with this camera because I got a bargain for the refurbished set...and I never look back...I think I will stick with this camera until it cannot be used anymore, to say how great this camera is...The colors are vibrant, even to the eye of a DSLR people (my friend)...the manual control is outstanding where u can easily set the aperture and shutter speed with no hassle...The ease of use to toggle between images is amazing...it's same as using the classic iPod to toggle through songsThe pictures of sunset in Waikiki Beach that I took with this picture is fantastic...it has an intelligent chip that can recognize efficiently the best setting for the picture (auto mode)...not satisfied with the auto mode? u can always use the manual mode...Buy this camera, trust me, u won't regret it...

Reviews.Title: Best pocketable P+S on the market
Reviews.Author: Cicada
Reviews.Content: I picked this up at Best Buy with a gift card i had and one of their 12% off coupons, so I got a really good deal. I've been wanting a new P+S ever since i handed down my old SD1000 to my sister, who lost hers. This was almost 2 years ago, and at the time i'd been lusting over the S90, but never bit the bullet. One of the main reasons was the exclusion of at least 720p video (I have a 7D and i do mostly video work, so i like to see a good movie mode on a digital camera :p).Glad I waited, as the S95 improved upon the already awesome S90. The texture is better for grip, the rear control wheel has detents (to make it easier to manage and not inadvertently turn it while holding the camera), an HDR scene mode and they included HD (720p) movie mode, among other small improvements. It's pocketable, which is what I wanted, since I don't like carrying around my 7D everywhere, which was often not feasible.It shoots in RAW, which is nice -- and it's great in low light due to the big sensor and fast f/2 lens. at ISO800 and even ISO1600, this thing puts out better pictures than my old SD1000 did at ISO400-500!Flash exposure compensation is nice on this camera, and the dials are really useful for adjusting everything fairly quickly. It's still a compact point and shoot, so I rarely use full manual controls, but leaving it in program works for me most of the time, and I can still adjust the important stuff using the dials and control ring.

Reviews.Title: A few quirks but overall a great camera
Reviews.Author: P. Val "Peter"
Reviews.Content: Camera is excellent.  Takes great photos.  Great in low-light without flash, much much much better than the SD4500is that I returned.  Feels very solid.  Most of the options you will change are on the back control wheel for easy access, or you can program the control ring or programmable button on the back.  The popup flash can be annoying but if you take a few easy easy precautions it won't be annoying at all.  Small price to pay for such great pictures and manual capabilities.  Video is also really nice, and the stereo sound for the video is really good as well.A few negatives:1)  Popup flash - after only a few days of use I've gotten used to the popup flash, the problem is when you give the camera to someone else to use to take a picture of you or something.  They almost always grab it by the popup flash, and that really makes me worried that someone else is going to ruin my precious camera lol.  I just usually leave the camera on P mode, and leave the flash setting on "off", so it doesn't popup every time you turn on the camera.  Then if i want the flash to be on it takes like literally 1 second to turn it on using the flash button on the rear of the camera.2)  Control wheel at the top of the camera is sort of annoying.  You need to turn it to get to video mode, etc.  Could have really helped if there was a dedicated button to shoot video.  Anyway its a small concern but could have been better.

Reviews.Title: Pretty Good Overall but some shortcomings
Reviews.Author: DC Phone Home
Reviews.Content: Battery life is great. Can take long movies.I don't like the popup flash. when you give the camera to someone else to take a picture, their finger jams the pop out flash. I'm afraid this will break the flash after a while.The size is a little bulky, but a tradeoff so you don't have to lug around a huge SLR.everyone is amazed by the pics I take, especially on "Vibrant" setting for a colorful landscape.

Reviews.Title: Great Little Camera
Reviews.Author: Frank G
Reviews.Content: I bought and used both the S95 and the new Panasonic LX5 and liked them both; each had comparable features and great images for the size.  However, the S95 won out as the keeper because of its smaller size (thus actually pocketable for me) and its retractable lens cover.  The LX5 was just that much larger so that it was too bulky to fit comfortably in my jacket pocket and the removable lens cap was a real bother.  A street camera needs to be quick to the eye and removing (or remembering to remove it in the first place) the lens cap just added another delaying step to the process.  Canon learned a number of lessons with their S90 and the improvements to the S95 show that they can learn.  The Cons: I will repeat the lamentation of so many other reviewers - Give me back the paper manual!  A short sighted cost saving measure on Canon's part as it may prevent the customer from using the the most of all of its features.  The included Canon RAW software is still awkward to use and I do use RAW a lot so I will have to upgrade my other software.  Maybe Canon can drop the inadequate software and restore the manual.  Listen up, Canon!Both are great cameras, either one is a good choice, but the camera that you like to use the most is the best choice.

Reviews.Title: Probably the best in picture quality among compact digicams
Reviews.Author: Gadgester "No Time, No Money"
Reviews.Content: I'll keep this review short.  If you want a compact (non-bridge and non-DSLR) camera that takes *great* pictures, this is it.A semi-pro friend of mine recently showed me his new S95, his first compact digital camera, and called it the next best thing to his arsenal of digital SLRs and lenses. He showed me some indoor and outdoor shots and I was immediately hooked and ordered my own.  While the resolution is "only" 10MP (I've never been a pixel junkie myself), the picture quality rivals that of many consumer-grade DSLRs from just a few years ago.  It has full manual controls and feels lightweight and solidly built.  The 720p video mode is very good.  While the optical zoom is only 3.8x, I think the lens is of such high quality which explains the great picture quality, as well as high price.If you're fed up with disappoining picture quality from your digicam, or want a compact model that takes excellent pictures, the S95 is most likely the one you've been looking for.

Reviews.Title: Beautiful pictures, but............
Reviews.Author: Geo. G.
Reviews.Content: This is a fine little camera that takes beautiful pictures and has a really good looking display.  Unfortunately, I had to send it back because, for a person like myself with very large hands, it is an ergonomic nightmare.  My left forefinger was always in the way of the pop up flash and I had to be very careful of how I held it when taking pictures.  For a person with small hands it is good; for me, not good.  Fast lens and good sized sensor.  Canon's larger point and shoots should have fast lenses like this one.

Reviews.Title: Love this camera
Reviews.Author: N. Barragan
Reviews.Content: I love this camera, picture quality is great. The only thing that I do not love about it is the flash, it pops out of the corner and it takes some getting used to. This is the camera I carry around with me all of the time.  I have recommended it to all my friends.

Reviews.Title: Best Camera
Reviews.Author: Betterlife
Reviews.Content: I love this camera. I purchased this one to replace my old old camera (only 2MB picture). The results are amazing. I'm happy that I don't need to use flash for low light settings. The auto mode is fantastic for people who just started to use this camera. I'm going to try more scene modes. The screen is wide, I like it.

Reviews.Title: Still new, and I like it.
Reviews.Author: PDXdenn
Reviews.Content: I haven't used all the features that the S95 offers, but what I have used has been good. The miniature effect is cool. Low light is great! I spent a lot of time reading reviews of all sorts of point and shoots, and went with this one for picture quality. I almost went with Powershot 4500is, but I choose the S95 and I'm pleased with the choice. It's a P and S so don't expect a full size DSLR. I have used the movie function briefly twice. The quality is good! Very clear and good sound. O.K., bottom line: So far I like the Canon Powershot S95. I look forward to getting to know it better.( A hard copy instruction manual would have been nice) I will use this to carry around with me.  A tad expensive, but good quality photos. Battery life has not been an issue for me, but I did get an extra one. Good Camera!

Reviews.Title: Perfect Companion for those with SLR cameras!
Reviews.Author: skipper42
Reviews.Content: I've had a Nikon D80 with 18-200mm lens for a few years now and love it. It's just not convenient to take it with me everywhere.I've been looking for a high quality compact camera which I could have with me wherever I go and it looks like I found it. All the modes and features this thing has are great. I love that you can manually focus with this camera. The control ring on front you can also program for various modes. You can have it set for manual focus, exposure, ISO, White Balance, etc. The one mode which I found doesn't work too well was the fireworks mode. Keeps the shutter open to long.This has a Super Vivid mode which really makes the colors pop. No need to do the contrast curve in Photoshop! The only problem is that it is a shooting mode, not a setting which can be used while in other modes. This limits when you can actually use it!I've never seen a compact camera so good in low light conditions. It still doesn't really compare to a DSLR in that regard, but try to find a compact that does.One of the best features of this camera is the movie mode. This has TWO microphones on the front of the camera. When you play these movies back with decent speakers, the sound is amazing! This is a camera which fits into your pocket (while in a soft case) and is capable of shooting good movies with good sound.The stitch assist mode works pretty well. Let's you line up your panoramic shots as you shoot them. Photoshop merges them effortlessly. The Canon software that comes with it isn't quite as good.You don't have the excuse now for why you missed good opportunities because you didn't bring your camera!

Reviews.Title: Great for low light
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: Very good camera.Love the ability to take indoor shots without the flash.  This is why I bought the camera and it is GREAT for that.Love the control ring and wealth of manual controls.Image quality is good.Biggest negative is that it is hard to hold - no natural place to put your hand.  It's easy to leave my finger on top of the flash and block it from coming up.  Control ring on the back does still move a little too easily since it tends to be under my thumb when holding the camera.And flash pictures are not the greatest.But I can live with the problems to get the low light capabilities.

Reviews.Title: I love it
Reviews.Author: Kenman
Reviews.Content: I love this camera.  It takes great pictures, has awesome functions, and slips nicely into a pocket for portability.  For someone who is at a beginner level with camera's, its got the size of a pocket cam with the performance of a professional one.

Reviews.Title: Cost: $399 - $369 = $30 Less
Reviews.Author: Bob
Reviews.Content: As soon as I purchased this camera from Amazon I began noticing ads directly from Canon for the same Canon PowerShot S95 for $369.  Most reviews I had read said the S95 was a bit pricey. Wish I had seen the ads before buying.

Reviews.Title: Great alternative to an SLR
Reviews.Author: Daniel
Reviews.Content: I wanted something compact that still had good manual controls without stepping up to an DSLR. I have no desire to lug one of those around. This camera just fits in my pocket and does everything I need it to. Great low light shots etc. etc. If you're considering buying this camera then you already have sen the great reviews. I agree with them and would recommend this to anyone who wants a more compact solution either as a backup for an DSLR, or in my case a great smaller alternative.

Reviews.Title: Excellent high end pocket camera
Reviews.Author: A.N. Other
Reviews.Content: I was looking for a high quality pocket camera that could shoot without flash in low light, and the S95 definitely fits the bill.  It has an ISO 3200 low light mode that I used to take some amazingly crisp pictures at night, where the only source of light was ambient urban.  The other strengths of this camera are well described by other reviewers, but include compact size, bright and sharp screen, great color (though at times a little too punchy), and fairly logical and easy to use controls.  The images are generally sharp, though a little less than what I get with a Nikon D40 SLR.  This is only detectable when images are massively enlarged on the computer screen, and may not be relevant for most prints.  I found 4 x 6 prints, for example, to look comparable with the two cameras, and would anticipate similar results for 8 x 10 prints.  The shortcomings are a short battery life, exacerbated by a misleading battery life indicator that goes from full to near-dead in an instant, the lack of a viewfinder, and (at least compared with the D40) relative slowness to meter and shoot.Overall, this is an outstanding camera for someone who wants excellent pictures, the ability to program a wide range of settings, all in a compact format.  It is an excellent choice to for the SLR user who wants an alternative to lugging a bulky camera, but still wants some control in shooting and high quality images.

Reviews.Title: A gem of a pocket camera
Reviews.Author: Adrian "-ACB"
Reviews.Content: Replaced my old Powershot SD790IS which had horrible low light performance and I must say, this camera is wonderful. Low light pics are amazing for a camera in this size class -- and yet it's super fast and handles wonderfully. A few minor quibbles with the control layout but they are minor. The build quality is amazing too -- the camera is small yet is so solid and sturdy. Is ready to take a picture super quick and it can do almost 2fps in burst mode -- continuously.Biggest gripes:- Mode dial too hard to turn. It won't get accidentally changed but this is ridiculous.- Cannot assign Movie Record to the shortcut button (Which you can do on other Canons.)- Battery life is a bit short and the battery indicator is inaccurate. Goes from full charge to no power left very quickly.That's it -- otherwise the camera is a gem. I highly recommend this if you want to step up to something with more flexibility than your typical point and shoot. You won't regret it.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: Ron and Gail
Reviews.Content: I really like this camera and it's ability to use lower light.  Flash works much better than a lot of point and shoot cameras.  Only drawback for me is the location of the flash.  Since the camera is pretty small the pop up flash is right where I want to put a finger.

Reviews.Title: Fantastic Point & Shoot
Reviews.Author: MavJ
Reviews.Content: I needed a camera to take with me on my first trip to Australia. After a lot of research I decided on this camera and I have zero regrets. The pictures are amazing despite my lack of photographic skill. Even the videos this camera takes are quite spectacular. If you are looking for a camera you can pull from your pocket and take remarkable movies/pictures within a few seconds, then you should look no further.

Reviews.Title: Great camera for a girl who can't stand the weight of a DSLR
Reviews.Author: Alice
Reviews.Content: This is the best camera I can find now for myself. I like its portability. In my opinion, for a camera that I can take everywhere I want, it can't be bigger than S95. I also enjoy its design as soon as I opened the box, very simple and plain. It could be better if they had a white version like lx5 though.We can't expect it can actually replace your DSLR, but it does have many functions like DSLR and it's much better in low light than most of the other point and shoot cameras. The only shortcoming is that it can't refocus when shooting video. I have to say this is a huge problem for me but at the same time I like its stereo sound recording function. Also, the battery life seems to be much less than 200 shots to me right now. I am not sure about it yet.

Reviews.Title: Canon S95 Price Gouging
Reviews.Author: FiftyFathoms
Reviews.Content: Anyone considering purchasing the Canon S95, please be aware the suggested retail is 399.00. As of today 1/23/11, this camera is backordered thru Canon and the online dealers who have it in stock have raised the price way above retail. When in stock it is usually  available thu Amazon.com for around 389.00.

Reviews.Title: Beware of the fatal lens error
Reviews.Author: radonc777
Reviews.Content: My Canon S95 recently had lens error rendering the camera useless. Unfortunately, the camera is now out of warranty, and Canon wants to charge $149 for repair. If this was my first Canon camera with lens error, I might have gone ahead. But I had another Canon camera (older version) that basically died with the same error after which I purchased this S95. Therefore, I must conclude that Canon cameras tend to have lens error issues. 2 out of 2 for me. If I had dropped the camera, spilled something or did anything weird, I would understand, but this is simply unacceptable. I will move onto Nikon I think.

Reviews.Title: Amazing camera, just a few things to note
Reviews.Author: hm
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera because I was mostly intrigued by the amazing reviews and high price on a camera that is getting pretty old by now. I have to say, this camera lives up to all the hype. I'm not a camera expert but I'll laugh at anyone who says their phone takes better pics. The shots are clear and the super vibrant mode is probably my favorite. Low light is where this camera shines; I never have to use flash. This camera has made me despise flash, actually.Other reviews have much better information, but one thing I did want to mention: I see tons of people saying that they cannot zoom in video mode. I'm not sure if we have the same camera, but I can zoom when shooting a video just fine. It's actually pretty awesome, and I was not expecting it based on the reviews. Unless they're referring to a certain setting or mode where you can't zoom, it is simply not true. If you're looking for an amazing camera where you can zoom in during video mode, get this.

Reviews.Title: Lens error
Reviews.Author: Erik
Reviews.Content: Bought the S95 camera in April 2011 and was very happy with it. Until today....Yesterday the camera worked fine, good quality pictures, nice size. Today the dreaded "Lens Error, Will Shut down automatically, Restart Camera" showed up. There are a lot of messages and advice on the web but nothing works. Did not drop it, did not use it in sand, rain.Made me realize that in the last three years, I have had to take in three different Canon cameras for service. The second was still under warranty but was never happy with it afterwards.If they stick me with a huge repair bill, this will definitely be my last Canon.

Reviews.Title: Great Little Camera
Reviews.Author: Jesse K "Jesse K"
Reviews.Content: I'm not a tech geek (I'll save those reviews to the experts) but I will say I love this little camera. The manual features are intuitive and accurate. You can play with this thing for hours and get a lot of cool shots! I prefer to shoot on manual so it was great to find a small point and shoot I could take out and use without dragging around a big camera that costs a lot. The video it shoots is great too. Really my favorite point and shoot camera I've seen so far. Highly recommend!

Reviews.Title: One annoying flaw.
Reviews.Author: Gotham Observer "porkboy"
Reviews.Content: You read all the other rave reviews, I'm not going to debate them because they're all correct. Picture quality is A_MAY_ZING.One stand out flaw: I hold point and shoots of this size with my left hand mirroring my right hand. That is, holding the side of the camera in my palm with my pointer finger curling over the top left corner of the camera - which  is right where the flash pops out. Many times it's spooked me enough to cause me to almost drop the camera and every time I worry I'm going to break the little servo motor that pushes the flash up and down. Incorporate the flash into the body please, I'm willing to sacrifice size for that.One stand out feature: the manual ring function. AWESOME! I do a lot of depth of field adjustments, BOOOM! no stupid menus and bleeping and blooping, the aperture adjustment is just a satisfying click around the dial. I would love to see this expanded on a future model with multiple rings (or one ring and an A/B/C switch) so I can "click" adjust the aperture, "click" adjust the shutter speed and "click" adjust the white balance with three quick and easy twists of the dial.Firmware menus suck. Dials, toggles and switches rule!!!So close to perfect Canon, so close.....

Reviews.Title: I Love It!!!
Reviews.Author: I'M DONE WITH DARKNESS!!!
Reviews.Content: I'm not going to repeat all the technical aspects of this camera, as you can find all that stuff in other reviews here and elsewhere.  But I will say that I absolutely adore this camera.  I have had the following cameras in order from the beginning:  Panasonic DMC-FZ20, Panasonic DMC-LX3, Sony Nex-5.  I liked the FZ20, but didn't know how to use it well.  I sort of liked the Nex-5, but not really.  I loved the LX3 for sure.  But this camera tops them all.  Beautiful crisp images from a very user-friendly machine.  A definite keeper.

Reviews.Title: Great camera, but you'll want more
Reviews.Author: fenris
Reviews.Content: I must first start this review off by saying that this is an awesome camera.  However, this camera will make you want more.It's very conveniently sized and you can virtually take it anywhere.  Even though I own an SLR, I will still use this camera as an everyday carry item when an SLR is not feasible to tote around since they aren't exactly known for their small size.  The aperture stops down to f/2.0 which is great for taking pictures in dark areas, which is rare for a camera this small.Though it has many things going for it, it does have its shortcomings.  The manual controls are pretty limited.  Even the though the camera can stop down to f/2.0, it only goes up to f/8.0 on the other end which doesn't make much of a difference in the depth of field department.  Also, as with any camera this size, it handles higher ISO's fairly poorly.  Personally, I think that after you hit about 300~400 ISO, the pictures start to become hard to look at which will definitely limit your options.  I've also noticed that the front glass gets dirty very quickly, and because it's so small, it's damn near impossible to clean.  Another thing I've noticed is that this camera is kind of fragile.  Though the build quality is great and feels solid, don't expect it to take any kind of drop or rough treatment.  One random thing that I've noticed with it is that right out of the box, this camera smells really bad.  It airs out in about a week though.All in all, this camera is recommended, but if you're looking to buy it for its manual control, just use the $400 to get yourself an SLR.

Reviews.Title: So Far So Good
Reviews.Author: Davis
Reviews.Content: I just bought this camera for my Vegas trip last week. Was debating on whether to get the Nikon S8100 or this one, glad I chose the S95. It took outstanding pictures on Auto. I haven't used manual yet so I can't comment on that. Also brought my Canon PowerShot A590IS which is 8.0 megapixels. I found myself using the S95 alot more than my A590IS. We mostly took pictures at night with the S95 and they came out amazing! It definately takes great night shots or with dim lighting. My A590IS didn't even compare. I know they're different series but still i was impressed. So far i've only had experience with 4 digital cameras, 3 Canons and 1 Fuji and so far the S95 is my favorite! Had to get used to not having a view finder and also the flash that pops up but no biggie. I'm also used to the shot button on the far right hand side like my A590IS, on the S95 the shot button is to the left of dial. As far as battery life I have taken over 300 pictures and it still shows full battery. I was worried it would be a battery eater from some of the comments so I ended up getting another spare one. I'm sure it'll come in handy some day. This is definately a keeper so far.

Reviews.Title: Great full feature compact
Reviews.Author: J. Hartman
Reviews.Content: I bought this to replace my aging S50, which was built like a tank.  I like the Canon S series because I can access manual controls if needed and since I sold my SLR years ago, I really don't feel like I'm missing anything.The S95 is about half the thickness of the old S50 and a fraction of the weight. The outer case has a texture to the finish that helps with grip and prevents fingerprints.  I don't know if it is metal like the old S50, but it sure seems like it.The first thing I noticed is that it starts up in a snap.  That was really important.  Also, it performs very well in low light.  You can turn off the flash during performances and get excellent low light shots.  You can also turn off the sounds and the red-eye lamp to not be so obvious.  My only gripe is that I wish you could turn off the flash and it would stay off when you turn the camera back on.  The controls are pretty intuitive so it isn't that big of a deal.  Oh, and it seems to handle jitter well in low light.  I've got great shots of a school musical that are colorful, clear and crisp. No grain. No blurs.For the most part, I use the SCN mode and select Kids and Pets.  That takes care of motion well.  There are some nice effects that you can do including a fisheye effect which could keep you busy for hours on end.I'm not used to the pop-up flash on the left side. I usually have my finger on it which it doesn't like when it wants to pop up.  You have to get use to a different left hand position.  I'm working on it.I used the HD video to film my daughter figure skating and it is like watching TV when you download it to the PC. Amazing quality and easy to figure out. Just make sure that you let the camera focus before you start filming. If not it seems to be a little out of focus. That could be because I shoot through the protective glass at the ice rink.The software for the PC has been updated.  It is pretty easy to use. There are some differences as compared to the old software. It is faster and has more options. Still figuring all of them out.As far as cases go, I purchased a Lowepro Ridge 10 which was a hair too small.  I returned it for the Ridge 30 which has plenty of room.  I think the Ridge 20 might have been a better fit, but I'll stick with the 30.I'm very happy with this camera.

Reviews.Title: Is All That Is Said
Reviews.Author: Richard Lyons "Paper Tiger"
Reviews.Content: The Canon S95 is everything you have ever read about it.  Best feature for me is that it is truely pocketable. Many cameras deemed pocketable are not, at least not in a shirt pocket. You can read all about the technical aspects of the camera in the technical reviews; I am telling you everything good you ever read about it is true.  A couple of slightly bad things too:  It has a shorter battery life than desireable, and I find the shutter release just a bit off center. I keep pushing the mode dial instead; others have said the S90 was this way, and it was corrected on the S95 but I still afind it that way for me.  And the camera looks cool too.

Reviews.Title: Awesome photos and video but ....
Reviews.Author: Samsudin B. Kamis "sambog"
Reviews.Content: My first point and shoot digital camera was Sony back in 2001 and then we decided to switch to Canon in 2003. We had several Canon P&S; Digital camera but I was not happy with Canon picture quality so we switched to Panasonic with Carl Zeiss lens. I was amazed with Panasonic camera but was not happy with the durability and the video performance. Finally in 2010, after so much research and waiting, we found Canon Powershot S95 which is almost perfect according to my requirements. Here are the plus points- Small and compact- Very good quality build- Photo quality is amazing even in low light- Video is very bright and sharp (720p).I hope they could support HD 1080P but 720P is ok for the web. I bought the first Canon Powershot in November for a vacation in Las Vegas and on the last day, the camera died on me. I switch on the camera and it display "lens error" and even after I restarted or removed the battery, the error did not go away. Most camera reset the error after you removed the battery but not this one. I contacted Canon and they told me to send it back for repair but too much hassle so I have to return back to Amazon and order new one again from Amazon. I My other complain is about the On/Off button. It is too small and hard to switch it on if you have "fat" finger. Overall, it is still a 5 stars for me because the image quality is so awesome.

Reviews.Title: PERFECT BALANCE
Reviews.Author: Liam H Dooley
Reviews.Content: I have had 7 digital cameras in 8 years. I have changed all of my cameras, except for my poor photo quality Casio, due due damage or breakage. So, it may be only a matter of time before this Cannon S95 breaks, but in the meantime I find it amazing, and without a doubt everything i wanted and well worth the 400 dollars.Pros:-Amazing colors! The clarity, sharpness, and color balance are amazing.-Size: for the features and photo quality, the size is perfect. If possibly a bit larger than some compacts, the large size enables a better sensor (which means better photos).-Lens dial; the lens dial at first is a bit odd, but one gets used to it and it quickly is quite convenient.-Wide angle lens. The wide angle photos are not distorted, and quite useful for taking photos of large buildings, groups of people who are close, etc.-Solid build: hard to tell, but it seems heavy and solid.-No touch screen. I have never had a touch screen, but if you are wearing gloves, these are not convenient; and it seems like it would be too easy to touch the screen and change functions by error.-Great indoor photos. Canon was a bit behind Sony in the quality of indoor photos, but the candlelight mode on this camera is amazing! Images are clear and bright, without a tripod.Cons:-Flash pops out automatically, and in auto mode you cannot set the flash to "on" - only auto. The flash pops out mechanically in the place where most people put there finger, resulting in possible damage.-Limited auto modes. Some cameras have two dozen "scene" modes. this has half of the average. One mode, HDR, is nice.... but requires a tripod. But my iphone does not!-Limited zoom.I take on average 10000 photos per year, due to fairly intense traveling and tourism. I have only used the S95 for one trip, but the photos and the functions were amazing!I only wish I had bought the S90 a year ago, instead of having had a second-rate digital camera that broke after 11 months.

Reviews.Title: Fisrt impressions - Alternative Review
Reviews.Author: Martin Belizan "Martin Belizan"
Reviews.Content: OK here its my review for the canon s95,I've read all the reviews i could find of this camera until 09/29/2010 and many other similar cameras like, of course the LX3 and LX5 to the samsung TL500, so my bought was based merely based on reviews like this, I'm not going to compare it to other cameras nor write any obvious specs, just some quick pro-cons and impressions.Pros:-Absolutely pocketable-Smartest auto mode I've seen on a p'n's-Excellent quality of  lens, amazing macros and bright f2.0 aperture-Front and back ring are a delight to use in manual mode, that alone is worth half  the camera-Tracking AF is nice. Just center your subject, press half way, move your camera for the angle your looking for, and voilàCons:-Half the time colours seem a bit  artificially processed, especially at high ISO, makes me wonder how much the digic 4 does, but personally i don't like canon colours-Battery dies fast, so you'll need a couple more this is not so bad because their are small and light and you don't need the camera to recharge them.-Needs a little more grip, i would sacrifice some size for it,  almost drop the thing a few times, now I wear a neck strap all the time!The camera will not perform miracles and make you look like you got 5000 dollars in your hands, but if what you're looking for is a kick ass point and shoot camera and want to do some night photography just click BUY-IT, you'll get a very well designed product that is made in japan.-Do not buy the s90- I was about to buy s90, luckily amazon recomended the s95. A week later after my s95 arrived I had a chance to compare the s90 in retail store, and for some bucks the s95 gives you HDR, the click stop back wheel, fun fish eye and miniature effect and the IS is a key difference for less blurry picturesOther stuff: I bought the maximal power battery for 8 bucks, it lasts little less than the included canon battery, try another brand. Also I bought the caselogic TBC-302 bag that amazon recommended and I'm very unhappy with it; I'm giving it away, it offers no impact protection on the front, the cloth inside seem rough for protecting a 400 dollar camera and even took an unfortunate spill at a dinner table and guess what... THE CAMERA GOT WET!!..

Reviews.Title: S95 review
Reviews.Author: S. Matscherz
Reviews.Content: I purchased this camera with the expectations that low light performance and RAW image capability are what I'm expecting to be improved over all previous cameras.  And I'm not disappointed at all. This is by far the best camera purchase I've ever made.  It takes great pictures without the use of the flash and high ISO pictures that were unusable over 800ISO on other cameras look great on this one even zoomed in.  The RAW edits are great and with the software you can reduce your noise in the pictures even.  A very nice addition as I like to make them look as good as possible for printing.  And this camera exceeds all those expectations.  I am also a owner of the original Digital rebel and it takes great pictures still due to RAW capabilities but this camera is actually better on the picture side so far.  I've used the Macro feature once down to about 3 inches and had to use the manual focus capability and it is a nice feature and works great.  They've really put some amazing features into these little power shot designs.  Manual adjust-ability is great too.  And it's all about the low light usefulness.  That's the real feature along with RAW that brought me out to purchase again.  Otherwise I was staying on the sidelines till they improved them.  Congrats Canon.  It's a fine camera.Steve Matscherz (Pittsburgh, Pa)

Reviews.Title: Canon PowerShot S95 Review
Reviews.Author: Wayne H. Morioka
Reviews.Content: Great camera . . . . BUT I didn't realize that Adobe Photoshop CS5 cannot (yet) read an S95 Raw file. Hopefully, Adobe will release an upgraded version of Adobe Camera Raw (ACR) soon.

Reviews.Title: Excellent image quality
Reviews.Author: Older London academic
Reviews.Content: Good in low light and excellent image quality with considerable colour depth.  While not the cheapest, it is well made and easy to use.  It didn't come with a card for storage which was a nuisance as the camera was a present and didn't work out of the box (a small capacity card would surely not have added much to cost).  A reliable product with the image quality of a much bigger more expensive camera.

Reviews.Title: Canon just announced the S100
Reviews.Author: Mr AMZ
Reviews.Content: Hey guys,Hold off buying the S95 for now.  Canon just announced the S100Specs:Canon PowerShot S100 - key features:  High-sensitivity 12.1 Megapixel Canon CMOS (1/1.7 type)  HS System with powerful DIGIC 5  Ultra-wide 24mm, f/2.0, 5x zoom lens. Intelligent IS  Lens Control Ring, NR Control & RAW  GPS  Full HD, HDMI  Large 7.5 cm (3.0') LCD  High-speed Burst HQ  Smart Auto, Multi-area WB  Optional Waterproof CaseUPDATE 9/22/2011:S100 is now available for Pre-Order[...]

Reviews.Title: Very poorly assembled
Reviews.Author: Carandell
Reviews.Content: I have purchased this camera twice. The first one had a problem with the LCD glass. Two corners of the glass were not glued to the body, the glass moved at my finger touch. This was a very visible defect since the glass was protruding at the corners not properly glued. Looked to me like the glass may fall loose anytime. This camera was returned.I have ordered another camera from a different store and this one still have the one corner of the LCD glass unglued and loose like the first camera. This second camera had also another issue: there is a big gap on the side join of the front and back panels. This gap was around 0.3 mm, which is way too much for this kind of equipment, since there should be no gap at all.Overall, the S95 is a very well designed camera, but very poorly assembled. It is a shame  for a "Made in Japan" camera...

Reviews.Title: Still raving about this camera 3 years later!!
Reviews.Author: Amanda Garley
Reviews.Content: I have a confession, I am in love with my camera. It's been 3 years and my passion for it is unyielding.I STILL after 3 years rave mad about how in love with this camera I am, and I'm not the only one out there who shares in my passion for it. I bust it out like it's a Prada bag and people who recognize it flock towards me with big eyes and a smile, asking "Is that an S95? That is the BEST camera I've ever owned." Wow, I'm talking photographers and people of credulance, here. I kind of feel like I'm in a secret club when I connect with people about this camera. It's better than any of their newer models which I have talked to many people about and everyone seems to agree. S95 holds the candle, and really you don't need more than 10MP, it's incredible.You only live this life once. Just buy it. Seriously, you will not regret it.

Reviews.Title: Excellent Camera
Reviews.Author: Dan
Reviews.Content: I routinely take this camera everywhere I go for the wonderful low light pictures that it takes. I tell people it adds light to the picture and they somewhat agree. The flash doesn't seem to work very well, but the low light ability makes using a flash unnecessary most of the time.

Reviews.Title: I miss this amazing model.
Reviews.Author: FranciscoTraveler "Bruno"
Reviews.Content: I LOVE THIS camera.  I have owned the S100 but love this older model so much more.  Canon needs to stop trying to "improve" this model and just make it again.  It is obvious that anyone who has had the S95 would want to buy it again.  Sadly, I had two S95 stolen.  I still have the S100 but wish I could trade it for a S95!  I took over 25,000 pictures with this little camera and many times, friends believe the results were from my D7000.  Nikon.  Bring it back!  If you want more technical pros, just ready all the great reviews.

Reviews.Title: Awesome pocket camera
Reviews.Author: Mad For Mystery
Reviews.Content: It is almost 2014 and I still use this Canon PowerShot S95, which takes amazing photos - such that I have displayed in NY and NJ galleries. Some of the customers who have bought my prints can't get over the fact that the photos I took are with a pocket camera. I LOVE this little camera - what a terrific product Canon has made!

Reviews.Title: Excellent Pictures, Features, Price
Reviews.Author: Ryan D
Reviews.Content: I spent around 350 for this.  Apparently supplies are short, so the price has gone up.  Supply and demand I guess.I considered a range of options when looking for a new point-and-shoot.  I made my decision based upon reviews of point and shoots from professional camera websites, and from amazon as well.  The S95 from all reviews appeared to be a formidable competitor in this space.  I went with this over the S100 due to complaints over the sensor change from the S95.  There were some negative things said about general quality and low-light performance.  So, I went with the safe choice, money was not a factor.  The prices at the time of purchase were about identical.As it turns out, my research was correct.  The construction of the S95 is excellent.  Very well manufactured, and rugged.  This is a very 'finished' product if you will.  The manufacturing is at least as 'clean' as apple.  I toted this all around europe (spending much of its time in my pocket) and did not have any issues.  I've been using it plenty since, and no issues (maybe a few scratches - my fault).  So far, I've taken probably 3000 pictures with this!  It has seen heavy use.  I've used several brands of SD cards, none of which have given me any grief.As far as features and picture quality, it is hard to find any particular issues.  Picture quality is great (excellent sensor, and excellent optics).  I've framed and hung in my house several of the best pictures I've taken (printed of course not by me, used shutterfly).Features: they're great and easy to use.  I take everything in RAW so I can photoshop if needed with the full feature set.  It's easy to configure F-stop, white balance, ISO speed, exposure, etc.  I shoot everything in manual mode, and the features are so easy to use that it is trivial to do so (not terribly time consuming to change settings).  Props to Canon for making this simple to use in manual mode.The only gripe I have here is what appears to be a bug with the camera's firmware.  When I got up to about 1000 pictures or so on my camera, it wouldn't connect to my laptop I had used dozens of times to download pictures off of it before.  As it turns out, there is a bug where if there are 'too many' pictures for its liking, it won't talk to your desktop / laptop / etc.  Fortunately, I was able to delete a few unwanted pictures, and this fixed the problem.  This is my only issue really.The 1 bug aside, this truly a great camera in the point and shoot space.  The 'bang for the buck' factor is very high.

Reviews.Title: Great camera though battery life is kinda short
Reviews.Author: alex
Reviews.Content: This is really a great camera. I bought mine a year ago and it has worked just fine though i have only used it for like 2 weeks...i will be upgrading to a mirrorless camera. If anyone is interesting in buying a just like new S95, just contact me. I am including an extra battery, 8Gig memory SD card, a Canon leather cover case in addition to the battery charger and usb cable that comes with it. I also have a book on this camera that shows tips and tricks on how to use the camera..much better than the manual that comes with it. All of this for $260. Just let me know if you're interested. Thanks.

Reviews.Title: This is one AWSOME camera!
Reviews.Author: Filip Popov
Reviews.Content: Takes pictures you won't belive. Memories that will last you a lifetime. LOVE IT!!!Easy to use and its a no brainer.Highly recomend this camera to everyone!

Reviews.Title: Its a Canon!
Reviews.Author: E Soon
Reviews.Content: Works well, takes great pictures, can be set to auto for the photographer challenged. I have an SLR and also another full frame compact but everytime I travel, I reach for this one because its so compact and rides well in the trouser pocket. After a year's use, I decided to buy the waterproof casing and use it for scuba diving pictures.

Reviews.Title: Canon Power Shot Camera
Reviews.Author: John M. Peters
Reviews.Content: I like the style and design of this camera, plus it takes great photos. Easy to handle and very compact.

Reviews.Title: Fantastic!
Reviews.Author: ronaldo schwarz art
Reviews.Content: very compact but very very powerful camera. I bought for underwater photography but ended using for everything. You can adjust it for every kind of light, scene or whatever you want to take adjusting (or not) everything you want.Recommend for any photographer kind, professionals that want a light but powerful camera to play with and begginers who are willing to take good pictures.

Reviews.Title: Great photos and easy to use!  Does well in low light!
Reviews.Author: A.tupa
Reviews.Content: I have owned this camera for almost 2 years and love it!  I'm a professional photographer, and don't always want to carry around a huge camera.  This camera takes great photo's in low light, and is amazing outdoors.  I carry it almost every place I go.  The only con I have found is the zoom, it's not very long.. That's the only thing I miss.  This is by far the best point and shot camera I have found.  It's easy to use and would recommend to any skill level.Check around on prices for this camera.  There are some great deals out there for this camera.

Reviews.Title: Amazing low light pics
Reviews.Author: review4u
Reviews.Content: Took this camera to Washington D.C. on vacation.  Took amazing night shots of landmarks (regular daytime shots are beautiful too).  A fellow next to me taking pictures at the White House wanted to know why my pictures looked so much better than his when he was using a big professional type camera that cost eight thousand bucks!

Reviews.Title: Basically a pocket sized DSLR
Reviews.Author: J. Wang
Reviews.Content: This camera is fantastic. I own the Panasonic GF-1, GX-1, LX7 and will continue to use them, however the S95 has proven over and over to be a fantastic pocket sized competitor, even outshining it's 'upgrade' S100 as THE go to camera. Even what would be considered generations past its release date, the S95 continues to show that Canon has made a solid impact on the point and shoot division by showing that it's not only DSLR's that can take stunning photos.I have purchased this camera for my girlfriend, both my sisters own the S95, and we are going to purchase yet another S95 for my mom, who loves taking photos but has an old and again Cybershot.The camera takes extremely sharp photos, works well in low-lighting conditions (with a steady hand of course), has brilliant color reproduction and some of the best video I've seen from a point and shoot. Sometimes it takes better photos than my own cameras, despite the huge price difference. For anyone looking for a compact, high quality camera, get this. New, used, whatever, if you find a bargain deal you'll have found an amazing wingman to save your memories.

Reviews.Title: This.  Camera.  Rocks.
Reviews.Author: R. Shea
Reviews.Content: I have a geeky gadgety friend who especially loves cameras, and I asked him to help me pick out a camera.  He suggested this one, and I have to gush - I love it.  The picture quality is freakin' fantastic. I'm going to paste his extremely thoughtful response here:One of the primary things in a camera that affects image quality is the size of the sensor.  A larger sensor has more surface area to detect light.  Also, the larger the sensor the more your ability to take photos with a 'bokeh'-- that blurry background that makes the photos 'pop'.  You're never going to get the quality or the bokeh of a full SLR in a pocket camera, but there are a line of cameras they call the 'premium compact' category that have a larger sensor than their lesser counterparts.  To be in this category, they have a sensor that is 1/1.7" (0.59") diagonally across or larger (vs most compacts which have 1/2.5", 0.4").One of the other primary factors is how 'fast' the lens is-- that is, it's maximum aperture.  A larger aperture means a larger hole that light comes in through, which once again means more light hitting the sensor.  A larger aperture means you can take photos in lower light scenarios without the flash, and you're less likely to get motion blur.And lastly, higher end compacts have image stabilization, which also helps you take pictures in lower light and with less chance of motion blur.Get the theme here?  The biggest lacking in small cameras is usually that they suck in low light ... they all look great outside on a sunny day, but you go indoors and suddenly the flash wants to pop up in every picture or they come up blurry.The Canon S95 and S100 are the only cameras that are essentially as small as your previous camera.  The others are slightly chunkier, and would probably not fit into women pockets.My mom has the LX5 and it is a great camera as well-- it's essentially the smaller sibling of my camera (the Lumix GF1).  The LX7 is just a newer version of the LX5.  These are great cameras-- I read lots and lots of reviews back in the day comparing the S95 to the LX5 and they are very similar as far as quality ... Because the price is also similar, I would say go with the Canon's, because they're smaller and you're used to the controls.

Reviews.Title: F2 lens
Reviews.Author: ePk
Reviews.Content: This is a great little camera, emphasis on little. Hardly ever use a flash with the super sharp 28mm f2 lens. Super image quality. I've sold lots of stock images from this camera. It's so handy I keep it with me all the time.

Reviews.Title: A drop in the sand
Reviews.Author: donna
Reviews.Content: A friend reviewed this camera and highly recommended it.  I also did some checking, but seeing it and using is was fantastic.  My family use to make fun of my pictures.  Now they can't believe I took the picture.  We went to the beach and my daughter accidently dropped the camera in the water.  We were frantic!  Grabbed the camera and immediately dried it out took everything out, opened and shut the zoom many times (sand was in the zoom).  After repeatedly opening and shutting the zoom, we began not to hear grit.  The pictures are still amazing and we didn't have to have it repaired.  Looking to buy one for my daughter.  She has the $800.00 on that has repeatedly been in the shop and still doesn't work.

Reviews.Title: Great point and shoot
Reviews.Author: Tekme
Reviews.Content: This camera was recommended by a friend that does his research, bought it, loved it and had my first one stolen on vacation so I went right back and bought another. The incandescent shooting features are fantastic and the images are as crisp as a professional digital. Pick one up before they're gone from the market.

Reviews.Title: Best camera
Reviews.Author: jshelds
Reviews.Content: This is by far the best camera I have ever had.  There are so many great settings to get great pictures no matter what you are shooting, but the auto setting is perfect when you just want to point and shoot as it automatically adjusts itself to the correct setting.  If it senses low light, it will change to that setting; if it senses you are outside, it will change to that setting.  It is by far my favorite part of the camera.  But I would highly recommend this to anyone.

Reviews.Title: Amazing point and shoot for the SLR snob
Reviews.Author: emin "emin"
Reviews.Content: This is a fabulous little camera.  Unlike many people, I have not started using my phone as my general use camera.  I have tried several other point and shoots including the Lumix LX3 but none had the picture quality in low light which I was hoping for until I came across the S95.  In short, it takes clear pictures in normal indoor lighting, which is pretty much all I was looking for.  The only complaint I have is with the lack of viewfinder so you're reliant on the large display screen (distracting to people around you if you're trying to take pictures in a crowd situation) and the only wish I have is for more of an optical zoom.  Other than those niggles, I am absolutely satisfied with this purchase.

Reviews.Title: usa version all gone already, only euro model left?
Reviews.Author: jrm
Reviews.Content: Like the other recent reviewer, we got the "euro" version with long corded charger CB-2LYE (vs USA CB-2LY flip-out plug) ... someone removed the seal and opened the box to throw in the USA-style cord.  So we had to buy it separately for $13, as the corded model is really inconvenient for travel.  Otherwise, it seems like a great upgrade over our old SD450.  I guess none of this matters since S95 is about to be unavailable.

Reviews.Title: Excellent camera, even 2 years after purchase!
Reviews.Author: Nelson Prada "Nelson Prada"
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera 2 years ago and it still taking great photos, the colors a great and night shooting can give you excellent results if you adjust the flash to the right level. This is the great advantage of this camera, you can adjust pretty much everything, speed, flash, ISO & much more. But if you just want to take photos the easy way there is plenty of scene modes that will give you great images.

Reviews.Title: This is the best point and shoot
Reviews.Author: adg44
Reviews.Content: I purchased this as a gold box item in December 2011, and I have used the camera religiously since then. I actually find myself taking it to places where I would normally take my Nikon D70 SLR. The photo quality is just that good, it rivals the quality of older D-SLR models. As with all Canon point and shoots, they are easy to use and the menu and function layouts are logical and intuitive. The only bad thing about this camera is that it's not readily available anymore, and while the S100 which has some nice improvements in terms of grip, changed the sensor from a CCD to a CMOS, and as many of the reviews for that camera note, the pictures aren't quite as good. Purchase this camera quickly before there is no more leftover stock.

Reviews.Title: Overexposure fixed!!
Reviews.Author: Califej
Reviews.Content: I had(well still do) a 35mm Canon, and always loved the quality of the photos it's taken. I bought this Canon S95 one year and a half ago, thinking it'll also take great pics as well. But I noticed right away that all the Auto mode pictures all seem a little overexposed. I really thought I've wasted my $$. I then played with different modes and settings, and found the "safest" way for me to take good photos with this camera is to use Program mode and set ISO to 100.I'm still not familiar with all the settings and the combinations, but at least now I'm happy how the photos turn out. And I love to bring this camera everywhere I go!

Reviews.Title: First Canon Point & Shoot and used in Iceland - Amazing images
Reviews.Author: Andy S "Wolfpack 4 Life"
