Reviews.Content: My parents were recommended this camera by a big time photography friend and they've loved theirs for over a year.  I finally purchased this before my trip to Iceland which I just returned from.I am so happy that I took this camera along with my waterproof Panasonic Lumix for the Blue Lagoon water shots.This Canon S95 took such amazing images including the 3.8x regular zoom and some of the 15x digitally enhanced zoom that my friend on the trip is planning on buying the S95 to replace his camera.The auto focus/auto scene select worked great, but I really enjoyed toggling back and forth on the SCN (Scene) settings from Landscape to Super Vivid.  Many of the Super Vivid turned out to surreal but some of them were breathtaking.  It depended on the amount of green (grass/plants) and blues (water/sky) on if it was too much but I enjoyed that feature.My parents were so amazed at my pictures that I had to teach them some of the features that they hadn't been using on their S95 before their Alaska trip tomorrow.I strongly recommend this camera, but definitely suggest getting a 2nd battery if you plan on taking 200 pictures a day for 10 days like I did (1900 total pics and video).  It lasted for 95% of my daily needs which some days took closer to 300 or 400 images.  I just purchased my 2nd battery today on Amazon.Lastly, the video was way better than I expected.Strong buy!

Reviews.Title: Wonderful Camera
Reviews.Author: The JAKAL
Reviews.Content: I already own a DSLR and this pocket camera is a perfect companion for times when I don't want to lug around a SLR.  Gives u all the options that you are used to with the DSLR for shooting just the way you want.  The display also makes it worthwhile, giving you a good resolution of the shot you just took. F2.0 is a plus.The ring up front to change the options is pretty neat. The only con is u need to get used to the camera, read the manual! other wise you will feel lost in the various options.

Reviews.Title: Fantastic Little Camera
Reviews.Author: CVAN BUILDERS "RemodelBlogdotnet"
Reviews.Content: Yes, this model is 'old' news and has already been replaced by the S100. Nevertheless, I still use it often at work for jobsite photographs. In addition, we also film videos for our blog with this camera, and I am always amazed at the great quality of images. While it would have been even better if it had a mic input, you can't have everything. While I plan to upgrade eventually, I will keep using this PowerShot until it dies. If you take lots of pics or make frequent videos, do yourself a favor and buy an extra battery. Well worth it!

Reviews.Title: Top Of The Line Pocket Point N Shoot
Reviews.Author: Ryan S. Sarver "jzerot1437"
Reviews.Content: The Canon S95 is a versatile device that lends users many of the useful features of an SLR at roughly an eighth of the size. The camera offers a full manual mode with a broad range of apertures, ISO levels, and shutter speeds to choose from, allowing those with steady hands or a monopod to produce amazing images at nearly all light levels. All the usual Canon bells and whistles are here--you can define color settings, adjust focal points, etc--but, as an added bonus, the Powershot S95 also shoots in RAW mode. For those unaware, RAW allows for maximum post-production ability, meaning you can adjust exposure, levels, clarity, vividness, etc in a program like Adobe Lightroom once you've uploaded the files to your computer. That having been said, RAW is not a defined format--there are many varieties of RAW floating about, which allow for different levels of control. Fortunately, the S95 RAW is nearly comprehensive, which is impressive given its pocket nature.While shooting video with the S95, you're stuck with whatever zoom length you started shooting at. Obviously, at its tiny size, this camera cannot be expected to feature a superzoom lens, but the tiny 3.8x optical zoom does feel a bit encumbering. Also, the lifecycle of this product is extremely limited; after just over a year and a half, my images now appear washed out and over-exposed, requiring quite a bit of post-work. Granted, I've taken thousands of photos on the product, so I may have simply worn it out early, but the degradation was almost immediate, with no gradual entropy over time. Overall, however, I cannot recommend this camera enough. You may have to buy a new one every 1.5 years, but it's a purchase you'll be glad to make.

Reviews.Title: Questionable longevity
Reviews.Author: Justin Mytwocents
Reviews.Content: Had it for just over a year. Had two batteries since new, and rotated them through the camera. Both batteries are on the way out, or there is a problem with the camera...can't get more than a few shots on each fresh charge. Camera is now useless until I have it and the batteries tested.

Reviews.Title: excellent cameraa
Reviews.Author: brendaortiz
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera because my sister got it for Christmas and it takes great pictures!!! Now that I own it, Im loving the functions and excellent image resolution that it gives....Totally recommend it!

Reviews.Title: Amazing Compact Point and Shoot
Reviews.Author: Di36
Reviews.Content: All I can say is WOW! The Canon PowerShot S95 is an incredible compact camera. Just learning about some of the awesome features after taking a beginning photography class. You won't be disappointed with this beauty of a camera!

Reviews.Title: WONDERFUL!!!
Reviews.Author: Veronica
Reviews.Content: I had been struggling with buying a new camera. I typically have a very compact point and shoot AND a huge SLR and use them for varying needs. When looking at this camera I found it to be much larger than the average point and shoot which you throw in your purse or pocket and run out for a quick day of hiking or family fun time. However the great benefit is that with it's increase in size I am able to have so much more control over the camera as is possible with an SLR. I would say even for a point and shoot it is still pretty compact.the Pictures are great- will not go into huge detail here as there are tons of reviews on this areazoom , low light and faster movement is easily captured. Again this is not a total high end SLR replacement but really an amazing hybrid to get those of you with a pension for photography something smaller and more compact that allows you to do more.CONSThe Flash is super Annoying - when you hold the camera you have to make sure to hold as an SLR instead of a point and shoot (right hand on corner and shutter button, left hand under the camera holding the lens area.) otherwise the flash pops up and throws you off.Camera is a little slippery in the hand, the texture or finish is maybe a little too smooth.

Reviews.Title: Perfect camera
Reviews.Author: HELPDESKGUY "HELPDESKGUY"
Reviews.Content: I must say for the size of this camera it packs a punch when it comes to features. The best P&S; on the market hands down!

Reviews.Title: Great little camera!
Reviews.Author: Kay
Reviews.Content: We bought this camera after rave reviews from both of our daughter-in-laws.  We had a Canon Powershot SD1400IS, but it wasn't fast enough to capture the grandkids without blurring.  We are very happy with the S95--nice wide angle lens, great color & speed.  We'll have to get used to holding it differently, as we too have blocked the pop up flash from working. Overall--love it!

Reviews.Title: quality problem
Reviews.Author: digitaldan
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera primarily based on reviews that gave high praise.  It worked well for about 3 weeks and then the silicon image chip went dead. I mailed it back to Canon for a warranty repair, and it now works again. Aside from failing soon after purchase it appears to be a good camera.

Reviews.Title: Excellent camera
Reviews.Author: J. Austin
Reviews.Content: Like others have said, this is an excellent pocketable camera. I love having manual controls and being able to shoot raw instead of jpg. Having a larger sensor than most P&S; camera keeps the noise levels down and the bright lens allows for greater flexibility in low light situations.So, why 4 stars instead of 5? The video. I don't shoot much video and realize that for great quality video you really need a dedicated video camera. But sometimes you want to grab a short video clip with your point and shoot. The S95 shoots 720p and the quality is decent. BUT, it doesn't autofocus nor can you zoom optically while recording. That greatly limits its usefulness. Even my old Panasonic Lumix maintains focus and allows you to zoom while recording. This could be done easily by a firmware update but Canon chose to not do it, likely so that people would buy the replacement (the S100) which shoots 1080p and allows for zooming during recording. That is pretty greedy in my opinion. Based on reviews it seems that quality control is an issue with the S100 with the focal plane not being aligned correctly which results in images being soft/out of focus on one side. Also, the image quality isn't as good as the S90 or S95 as they are cramming more megapixels into the same sensor size which also results in more noise. Given this problem and that it is much more expensive than the S95, I'm happy sticking with the S95 though I do wish they would fix the video issue with a firmware update.The closest competitor is the Panasonic Lumix LX5 which I really debated getting as it has similar image quality but much better video capabilities. I opted for the S95 due to it being smaller and a bit cheaper. Overall I'm happy with my purchase and would recommend it.

Reviews.Title: Great Camera
Reviews.Author: Mike M
Reviews.Content: This is an excellent camera in this price range. Excellent picture quality and great design. Got it as a gift for the girlfriend and she LOVES it.

Reviews.Title: This is a DSLR professional's Point & Shoot.
Reviews.Author: NeoEngineer
Reviews.Content: I love this camera!  Try it out, Amazon has a great return policy.  It has everything you'd expect from your DSLR, except it costs half as much as your typical L Lens.  And weighs almost nothing.

Reviews.Title: Love it!
Reviews.Author: I Always Do My Research
Reviews.Content: I'm not a professional but i've been looking for a good camera for a long time and this one is amazing - the pictures are super crisp! I'm in love!

Reviews.Title: Canon PowerShot S95 compact digital camera
Reviews.Author: eiEuler
Reviews.Content: Wow! I have had two other compact digital cameras and they cannot hold a candle to the Canon PowerShot S95. I find it ideal for the kind of travel we like to do, as well as photos around home. When I expressed dissatisfaction with my old cameras to a professional photographer friend, he recommended the S95. Needless to say, I have thanked him for steering me right. I am amazed at the quality and many options. Buying through Amazon saved me a bundle, too. By waiting until I have sufficient qualifying items I get free shipping, too.

Reviews.Title: Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera with 3.8x Wide Angle Optical Image Stabilized Zoom and 3.0-Inch LCD
Reviews.Author: Linda Makofski "Linda A. Makofski"
Reviews.Content: I purchased the Canon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera with 3.8x Wide Angle Optical Image Stabilized Zoom and 3.0-Inch LCD for my daughter and she's crazy about it.  She did a lot of research beforehand and this was all she expected plus more.  Instead of buying the Bundle package I individually ordered the items to go with it. I found that shopping Amazon it was about the same price as the Bundle and I received much more and higher quality items.  Highly recommend.

Reviews.Title: Image quality is good enough for a pocket camera
Reviews.Author: Xiaogang Wu "Xiaogang Wu"
Reviews.Content: For a pocket camera, Canon PowerShot S95 has very good image quality, even in the darker situation. Since I got it at a very good deal (almost half price), I like it very much.The only disadvantage is the flashlight is not covenient to open. But it's no need for almost all the day time. So it's OK.

Reviews.Title: Great of course
Reviews.Author: PR from Colorado
Reviews.Content: Does the S95 need more reviews? Excellent small camera, fast lens albeit a little limited in optical zoom; smart logic and great image quality. It is not a $3k SLR, but neither does it weigh 5 lbs. Perfect for throwing in the pocket to have everywhere, yet good enough for documentary video and photography. We have used these for shooting HD video on trans-Pacific research project and the cameras held up well and provided quality results. The S95 will remain a little workhorse of our travel kits for a long time.

Reviews.Title: Best lil' camera out there
Reviews.Author: WorkingGuy
Reviews.Content: This camera packs more features and functions into a pocket size than any I have ever seen.  There is a bit of a learning curve involved in mastering all of the tools available, but once you spend some time figuring out what some of the settings can do for you, it's amazing.  I routinely take better photos than my friends much bigger and more expensive DSLRs because this camera handles less than ideal lighting so well (night shots, cloudy shots, under water shots!, dawn/sunset shots, etc).  Of course, this only started happening once I learned which setting to use.

Reviews.Title: Great Clarity
Reviews.Author: icculus479
Reviews.Content: Long story short the pictures are very clear and the camera does VERY well in low light situations.  The flash positioning is a little annoying, but I've already become used it to it.Only had it for a short time, but its the best Canon P&S; I've owned and the picture quality is great.  On certain pictures you couldn't tell if I took the picture with my S95 or my T2i.Looking forward to trying it out in many different situations.  I'll update more later.

Reviews.Title: Price Performance Ratio for P&S; Camera: Bar None
Reviews.Author: M. Ge
Reviews.Content: This is a model every discerning camera guy must own.  For Price Performance ratio, this is second to none.  If you are familiar with Canon's digital camera over the years, you do not need manuals whatsoever, it is typical Canon pedigree.  Owning to its f/2.0 wide angle lens, on Auto it pretty much hardly fires flashes, in my case it did but once in all 40 indoor daylight shots at our family Xmas get-together.  Before making purchase, did some home works comparing with G12. It cost one clam less than G12 with a bigger better lens, so decision is easy on this one.  Couple things worth noting here, the back color LED screen is truly sharp and vivid in resolution and color, while the pictures shown up on my 20" Dell IPS display turn out to be less perfect. The battery life is about 200 shots with flash, which is considerably less compared with previous Canon models using AA ones, as my A630 does. Well, considering the give-and-take, this again is truly one great tiny P&S; camera that shines.  Yes, it is still Made in Japan, a rarity these days for a P&S.; Lot of additional features, but AUTO will do good on absolutely most occasions, yes low-light as well, that is what makes S95 famous for.  Should you have any doubts, search online to see more reviews. This is a keeper.

Reviews.Title: Excellent as rated by most everyone else
Reviews.Author: J. Pak
Reviews.Content: I got the camera for a steal at $230, and it is more than worth it.  I'm especially happy about it's performance in low light conditions.  A+ product from Canon.

Reviews.Title: Nice little point and shoot camera!
Reviews.Author: coolsigg
Reviews.Content: I am a DSLR user (current setup is Nikon D700 & D7000 plus a couple of pro grade lenses). Was looking for an advanced P&S; camera as I don't want to lug around my DSLR all the time. After some research, I was deciding between S95/S100/LX5. I got the S95 at the incredible USD229 gold box deal price. I was initially a bit apprehensive as I saw quite a fair bit about bad QC of this camera. Fortunately, my set was in good cosmetic condition and is a Made in Japan set!Having taken some shots with it, here are the Pros and Cons:Pros:1. Small compact size, somewhat pocketable vs the LX5.2. Incredibly low price.3. Full manual control functions.4. RAW shooting.5. EV compensation even in SCN & Auto modes.Cons:1. Flash exposure is not adjustable in SCN & Auto modes. Leading to uneven exposures.2. You can't press down the pop up flash manually. You have to switch it off via the flash switch which I find it a hassle.Above are my findings so far. Will update more later. :)

Reviews.Title: Best Low Light Ever
Reviews.Author: Vox "Mr.Vox"
Reviews.Content: Ah, basically the best low light point and shoot I've ever used. It makes me want to continue to take pictures all day.

Reviews.Title: This little camera is close to perfection
Reviews.Author: netscorer
Reviews.Content: I took this camera on a trip to Las Vegas, including one day kayaking expedition at Black Canyon. In all situations this camera exceeded my expectations - from night shots of Las Vegas Boulevard to vistas of Death Valley to Hot Springs of Black Canyon, from landscape to portrait to macro shots, from tripod-mounted 1 second exposures of waterfalls to 1/1600 second shots of plane landings. It is very intuitive to use if you are an experienced photographer and should be quick study for an inspiring amateur. It is very small camera while still feeling solid and rugged in use with most of the controls at immediate reach. Large sensor, bright and sharp lenses (while wide open), excellent RAW mode, wide range of ISO settings, good video recording. This is the perfect camera when I don't want to (or can't) take large DSLR with me on the trip. It fits any pocket, very quick to start with quick focusing - ideal for snap of the moment photo. While in kayak I simply stored it in the zipped plastic bag in my life vest's chest pocket and it was there for me at any time. Try doing it with any larger camera! On a bright day on the water I was shooting in RAW mode to get a bit extra dynamic range via post-processing. Try this with a any other compact! See some of the pictures this camera can make in the product description.

Reviews.Title: excellent low light (and day light) pictures!
Reviews.Author: mhrj
Reviews.Content: I just took this camera on a recent trip. Pictures are great and I never had to use a flash (even at night). If you can see something with your eyes, this camera can take a great picture (without flash).The pictures are simply stunning!Great manual modes, and the adjustment ring in front is very useful.I have a Canon SD 1000 (not bad for bright light), but obviously the Canon S95 blows it away!I wanted something that could take good pictures (especially low light, for indoor and after sunset pictures), but did not want to carry a bulky D-SLR when I travel - the S95 perfectly fits the bill - worth every dollar!

Reviews.Title: A Super Camera--Until the Lens Jammed
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: I have simply loved this camera since I got it 4 months ago--until today, when the infamous "Lens Error" message came up, indicating that the zoom mechanism was jammed, making the camera inoperable.  Canon tried to fix it over the phone to no avail, so now its in the mail for Canon to fix or replace under warranty.Picture-wise, this camera is just super. It's way better for my purposes than the other two Canons I've owned: the S3IS and the SX20IS. I get much better low-light pictures with this little gem than with either of the others. I attribute that to the f2.0 lens on this little guy. This camera has a 4x zoom, much less than the megazoom of the other cameras, but I didn't mind giving up the zoom to get the low-light performance. I had looked for other cameras that would give me a big lens, and it seemed like the only ones that would do better than the S95 were big expensive digital SLR's.Did I mention that this is a true pocketable camera? When I got it, I put it in my pocket, and it stayed there until today, unless I was actually taking pictures with it.About that "Lens Error:"  The reason that I don't have that S3IS any more is that it, too, suffered the infamous "Lens Error." That was after almost 5 years of service, so I figured I'd gotten good service out of it and got the S95. I had hoped for at least 5 years out of this one, but it failed after only 4 months.  And no, I didn't get sand or water in it, or drop it, or bump it, or do anything else to it--other than carry it around in my pocket (which is what a pocket camera is for, right?).UPDATE:  Got the "lens error" fixed and it worked a couple of years, but now I have the same problem.  And no, I haven't dropped it, or put sand in the lens.  What a bummer.  A great camera, when it works.

Reviews.Title: So far so good...
Reviews.Author: aash73
Reviews.Content: I bought a canon 230HS but I was not satisfied with the IQ at low lights. Then I bought the S95, with the understanding that I am sacrificing optical zoom (3.8x for S95 vs 10+x for 230HS) for the IQ. Let me tell you this, I don't regret the decision at all. The low light and very low light images are EXCEPTIONAL. Pretty pleased. The only concern I have, about the camera in general, is that I believe the flash will have issues in the future (same comment about 230HS). I believe the reason for my worry is the design of the flash in the camera. Other than that, I am extremely pleased with S95.

Reviews.Title: Image excellence!
Reviews.Author: William Michael Bartels
Reviews.Content: This camera is hands down the best camera I have ever owned-35mm SLR and digital.  I purchased the camera right before a trip to Seattle.  I left it in full auto mode the entire time.  The quality of every image is outstanding-color, exposure, and focus.

Reviews.Title: Excellent compact camera
Reviews.Author: The Rabbi
Reviews.Content: The Canon S95 is an excellent camera for general use. It is quite compact (though not quite pocket-size), especially for the features it has.  Picture quality won't rival DSLR's, of course, but is very good for a compact P&S.;  Construction appears to be very solid, and the S95 is a pleasure to use.  Highly recommended.

Reviews.Title: Best Compact Digital I've Owned
Reviews.Author: S. Mason
Reviews.Content: Great, sharp pictures with manual control.My only advice would be in full auto mode the contrast can be a bit off.

Reviews.Title: Perfect Pocket Camera
Reviews.Author: David Berger "Tech Junkie"
Reviews.Content: The Canon S95 crams respectable features and high image quality into an amazingly compact truly pocketable camera. It is an ideal carry around camera for the times when you don't want to carry your DSLR.

Reviews.Title: Very Happy
Reviews.Author: Photo Joe "Joe Scanlon"
Reviews.Content: Great little powerhouse. The flash is in the wrong place because i always want to hold the camera there but i'll get used to it. the mic picks up wind noise but i guess that's a common problem.All in all it's a joy to use. If you are looking for something to use in Auto all the time don't waste your money. If you like experimenting at least in P mode ... go for it.

Reviews.Title: the best
Reviews.Author: Silverbullet
Reviews.Content: I'm no Pulitzer Prize winning photographer and dont pretend to be, but this camera is awesome for the average amateur photographer who wants something light and easy to use and can take excellent pictures.  I got this for my wife for Christmas and we absolutley love this camera.  There is nothing worse than carrying around your kid(s) and then having to lug around a huge DSLR camera with the bag and lenses, etc...  I wanted something light that could fit in your pocket and this camera fits the bill perfectly.  We love playing around with all the features and our friends always comment on the quality of our pics.  The only downside is the price, but now that we have had it 6 months I would buy it again in a heartbeat.

Reviews.Title: Canon S95
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer "Nicole"
Reviews.Content: I bought it for a point and shoot for Hawaii as I had sold mine years ago and didn't want to lug my XT around everywhere. I felt this camera had good overall shooting qualities. I was able to take pictures in small spaces like a submarine. It gave me wide enough lens for this. I am of course annoyed with the way you can't shoot photos in a rapid sequence. you have to wait for it, but other than that I am happy with it so far.

Reviews.Title: Satisfied
Reviews.Author: Jay J. Yuan
Reviews.Content: I compared the S95 with several other cameras in terms of features and prices before I bought the S95.  I am quite satisfied with my selection.Previously, I owned a Rebel XTi and was very happy with it.  The S95 is much more portable.  The main drawback is the lack of an optical view finder, but, I understand this is a necessary trade-off for portability.  So, I can't blame it.

Reviews.Title: Canon S95
Reviews.Author: Alan Sarutanond "asarut"
Reviews.Content: Best point-and-shoot camera I've ever used. All the controls are at your fingertips and when you make the changes you get a quick preview of how the image will look when you snap the shot. I also have the G12 which is another great camera from Canon. I also have a Panasonic, Sony and Samsung and Canon is by far superior, after all who can make a camera better than a camera manufacturer?Alan.

Reviews.Title: Best Pocket Camera Available
Reviews.Author: R. M. Smith
Reviews.Content: I had an S90 and took well over a thousand pictures with it.  I gave it to my daughter-in-law to take pictures of our new grandson and bought an S95.  I've taken over four hundred picture with it.  Both cameras take excellent pictures.  They're identical photographically.  The S95 corrects some of the ergonomic issues of the S90.Within its circle of capability (no moving objects, lighting that isn't so tricky you need a filter) the S95 is as good as my D90 and D7000.  They just have a bigger circle of capability.  Maybe the D7000 does colors a little bit better, maybe.I've owned about six or seven Canon Digital Elphs (Elves?).  They've all been good cameras.  I've lost a couple.  One grew fungus in its lens (carrying it around on the floor of my car in Portland winters wasn't a good idea.).  So far no failures; nothing but good pictures.  They do a fair video too, again as long as you acknowledge their circle of capability.I wish I could post a picture I took last October in Monument Valley, Arizona.  It really shows what the camera can do photographically.

Reviews.Title: Fantastic camera
Reviews.Author: Anderson V. Medeiros
Reviews.Content: Photo quality is superb. Focus effects are very good. It is a pity that the focus could not be changed during video capture.

Reviews.Title: excellent camera
Reviews.Author: Patricia J. Obrien
Reviews.Content: Tired of fussing with crappy cameras...I sucked it up and went for the best that Canon has to offer....and it was well worth it.  I did save a bit going for the canon refurbished.  Many times a camera is returned in perfect condition but cannot be resold as new so they go thru it and sell as refurbished.  I have had excellent luck buying high end electronics this way.  Anyway my last canon broke because it fell onto a hard tile floor with the lense open.  It was a great camera...and I was less pissed off because I bought refurbished.  My canon before that fell into the water on the boat.  That was my last "new" purchase.  I am holding on to this one for dear life.  It is amazingly intuitive.  I put it right to the test taking pictures of my dogs in a poorly lit room.  That is the toughest combo...they do not sit still...pretty good results I must say.  Much to do the the speed of the cameras lense and lighting functions.  Have not tried the video function yet.  I will leave that for my son.  My conclusion...well worth it...just hope I can hang on to it!

Reviews.Title: Nice little partner
Reviews.Author: BobbyD "Staghornleghorn"
Reviews.Content: Perfect companion (and at times perfect replacement) to my Nikon D80. I was able to grab this camera for $369. which is a fair price. At $399.00 it's a tad bit overpriced, but a solid performer!Pros:Nice quality pictureGood low light shotsCompact size is greatSolid construction/feelCons:A tad bit overpriced(Like every complaint) The flash is in the way, but you do get used to it.Battery life could be better. Plan safe, purchase a backup battery.I haven't played with the video much at this time.

Reviews.Title: Excellent Point and Shoot if you want manual control
Reviews.Author: Daniel
Reviews.Content: There are plenty of extensive reviews about this camera and its main competitors, so I will keep my thoughts short.  I bought this camera because I wanted the manual controls and excellent picture quality (for a point and shoot) while still having a very compact camera.  Don't expect it to replace a dSLR in terms of quality, but can't deny the portability of this camera.  If you do not plan on using the manual controls, I would consider a cheaper camera, though even in auto modes this will take good pictures.Update July 2011 :  On a recent 4th of July trip I was hesitant to bring my dSLR with me due to weather, but could easily put this camera in a water proof bag.  I was able to get some good firework shots when the weather cleared that I could not have taken.  The 10 mp has proven enough for decent sized prints (11x14 is the biggest I have printed thus far).  I still highly recommend this camera, and would buy it again if I was shopping for a compact camera today.

Reviews.Title: canon powershot s95
Reviews.Author: its me
Reviews.Content: I wanted to upgrade so I could take better pictures at assemblies, concerts with a pocket camera.  Plus I wanted some ability to control shutter time, f stop occasionally.  This has worked out pretty well for that.  I can take pictures of the band on stage from the balcony with pretty good resolution, and I can take a picture of water dripping from icycles.  We will see how it goes with sports this spring.  There are a lot of features I have not explored on the camera.I became aware of the camera via an NPR story on electronic Christmas gifts.  After researching it, then found all the local stores had none, would not get them before March or April if then.  Bought it on line, missed Christmas but got it by New Years.

Reviews.Title: Excellent camera
Reviews.Author: Ranj
Reviews.Content: S95, is a brilliant camera. When I was looking for an advanced PnS my criteria was - great sensor, pocketable build, and great manual control. S95 fit my bill like no other. Since the day I have bought S95 I have been to many hikes and everytime it outperforms my friends' bulky SLRs. May it be ease of use or the bulk factor and even the stills, low end SLRs are no match for S95.Although Canon could have done a much better job with Video recording, HD video quality is not the best I must admit. Also, the positioning of flash sometimes gets on your nerves.Except for these two drawbacks, its a brilliant camera. Definitely recommend to those who like supreme manual controls, super image quality, and fits in your pocket without complaining.

Reviews.Title: Canon S95 Review
Reviews.Author: Simon
Reviews.Content: Great little camera. Just the flash is not as powerful as the G series of cameras, but the size is fantastic.

Reviews.Title: Best Point and Shoot....
Reviews.Author: BeastMD "beastmd"
Reviews.Content: Best point and shoot I have ever used. Great pics in every situation, wish the battery life was a bit better and you could use optical zoom in movie mode.

Reviews.Title: Great buy
Reviews.Author: Fausto E. Marin Jr.
Reviews.Content: Really good camera, it's pricey , but has an excellent performance even in dim light.  in a nutshell buy it, you won't regret it.

Reviews.Title: Brilliant little thing.
Reviews.Author: J Chan
Reviews.Content: Bought this camera because of a review. Well, it lives up to the hype. Sharp photos, nice manual controls, f 2.0 aperture, good low light capability, quick review and easy browsing of photos. All in all - a brilliant little camera. We love it!

Reviews.Title: Great Advanced Compact
Reviews.Author: K. Keller
Reviews.Content: I have owned many compact digital cameras from Canon, Sony, and Nikon.  Most have been good for their size, but with the usual trade-offs in image quality, low-light capability, and manual control flexibility.  Finally, the Canon S95 comes along.  This is a serious camera with a reasonable set of trade-offs: low flash power, limited zoom range, and a few other minor issues shared by all other compact cameras.  The S95 has the characteristics I want: great usability, good image quality in a variety of lighting conditions, RAW/JPG image capabilities, minimal shutter lag, good metering, and flexible manual controls.Yes, it does cost a bit more than most other compact digital cameras.  However, this camera should be compared to more expensive digital cameras such as the Canon G12 and Nikon P7000 (I'm sure that statement will raise eyebrows among some fans of those cameras).  Candidly, I like both of those cameras as well, but neither of them can be carried easily in a jacket pocket.  The S95 delivers comparable image quality in a much smaller package.  Of course, you may opt for the other cameras because you want features that aren't included in the S95 (e.g. hot shoe, wireless flash capability).It's worth mentioning I'm not totally biased toward Canon -- My DSLRs are all Nikon bodies.  Although I like the Nikon P7000, the Canon S95 is just what I need in terms of features, quality, size, and price.  When I want to carry a full-featured body, I'll always choose one of my Nikon DSLRs.

Reviews.Title: Awsome camera
Reviews.Author: Gizzim101
Reviews.Content: This is a great camera.  No need to review others have done a great job already.  However, I would like to add one thiing in reference to those who complain about the lack of a zoom and auto focus then shooting video.  This is a still camera, video is a plus.  The camera is amazimg.  The quaility of the photos are amazing.  Whining about the video feature is amazing.  Buy a camcprder if you want to shoot video.  Buy this camera id you want great looking stills!

Reviews.Title: great camera! easy to use! great price!
Reviews.Author: Hilarie
Reviews.Content: I saw two of these cameras in use and had already decided to purchase one before I found it through Amazon from OneCall at a great low price. It's extremely easy to use for both photos and videos. Had to buy a case, memory card and tripod but no complaints about having to do that. Everyone in the family has used the Canon S95 and it's just what we needed.

Reviews.Title: Hi tech camera for people on the move
Reviews.Author: Rob
Reviews.Content: After reviewing many websites for good camera reviews, we settled on this hi tech small camera with all the features required for a family who tend to carry many things while travelling.  Although the camera is a bit pricey, the quality of the picture is exceptional. The size is convenient to carry around and the camera is "made in japan" which gives me more assurance on the quality of the product.  The one draw back is the position of the flash on the camera. This is a pop up flash camera and it is located on the top left hand side where you normally hold the camera.  The camera does "not" come with a users manual and I think if I'm paying $300, I would like to receive a well written small manual with basic commands well explained.  Although there is a CD that came with it, I had to go and download this from the website and print it myself !  Some of the logos for camera adjustments are not intuitive.  In any case, if you are taking plain vanilla pictures of kids, family, group and parties, this is a good one.

Reviews.Title: Awesome P&S; Camera
Reviews.Author: RJM
Reviews.Content: This is an awesome P&S; camera. It is much better than any other compact camera that I have ever used, and is great for carrying around when I don't want to lug around the DSLR. This is not your typical compact camera, it is definitely worth the price you pay!  Manual controls are easy to use and adjust.  One of the features that I use more than I expected is the video mode, the video that this captures is great!I bought a Canon SD1400IS and returned it the same week because the picture quality and camera speed was not good enough for my taste.Basically, you get what you pay for and this camera is a keeper.

Reviews.Title: Canon s95
Reviews.Author: R. Dcloux "brianeyes"
Reviews.Content: This camera produces great shots in low light and is outstanding in macro function.  Manual features will take some time to learn but it is great to be able to manual focus in super dark areas. No view finder is a negative but the reliable focus makes up for it.  The pop up flash is also in an area I usually hold a camera. It is not as good as a single lens reflex but is a great walk around camera.

Reviews.Title: The best point and click thus far
Reviews.Author: OBogle "obgle"
Reviews.Content: This camera is all beauty and brains. Not the fastest point and click but considering its MP, it is quick for a point and shoot. I would recommend this camera to anyone who wants to not only take standard pictures but for users who want full control over the aperture, ISO and lens of their photos.

Reviews.Title: Excellent quality pictures
Reviews.Author: Yogesh Penubolu "Yogesh"
Reviews.Content: Great camera with SLR quality pictures. Easy to use and compact size. This camera takes very good pictures even in low light. I haven't played with manual controls and have been using auto feature thus far.

Reviews.Title: Great camera for a point and shoot
Reviews.Author: Eric Slifer "Slyfur"
Reviews.Content: After a lot of research I decided on this camera over the new G12. Mostly because I wanted something for my pocket that I could easily take anyplace I went.  It's already paid off in this way too many times to count, including stashing in my ski pants when I went sledding over the holiday weekend.In addition, the ability to shoot RAW in this size of device was important and I am impressed with the technology.Way to go Canon!  I am satisfied with my choice.

Reviews.Title: The camera is the bomb.
Reviews.Author: Dude "Some Dude"
Reviews.Content: I've owned the S90 for about 6 months now and loved it so much that I bought the S95 too. If you are looking for a compact camera that takes awesome pictures, this is the one. I've owned Sony's to Nikon's and I can tell you that without a doubt, this is the best point and shoot I've ever owned. The photo quality is sharp, the interface is easy to use, and I especially find the low light shots exceptional compared to any other point and shoot.It's not a DSLR, but if you have to have a backup that'll fit in your pocket, this one is the one to have.

Reviews.Title: Camera
Reviews.Author: Mary F Redfield
Reviews.Content: Great camera, surprised at the size, just a little small for large hands, but very manageable.  The quality is great, would have liked a larger instruction book as Cannon has had in the past.  Over all very pleased with the camera and the purchase.  Shipping was very quick, and the camera price was attractive. Have been pleased with all my purchases from Amazon.EdCanon PowerShot S95 10 MP Digital Camera with 3.8x Wide Angle Optical Image Stabilized Zoom and 3.0-Inch inch LCD

Reviews.Title: Great pictures and low-light performance
Reviews.Author: Allan Jaworski
Reviews.Content: This camera seems to have incredible intelligence in determining exposure levels.  Low light performance is outstanding, though you may have to accept substantial reduction in resolution to take pictures in exceptionally dim conditions.  I'm very comfortable using it in place of my Rebel XSi SLR when I want something easy to carry in my pocket.

Reviews.Title: great camera with a marginal battery
Reviews.Author: mam
Reviews.Content: Great alternative when i don't want to lug around my DSLR. Picture quality is excellent. I love the "ring function" feature and there's even a "custom function" button.  I've had the camera a month and still find my left index finger in the way when the flash trys to pop up. This sometimes gets you an error message that requires a "restart". Wall Mart sells a small "Case Logic" soft belt case for about $8 which fits perfect and has a little zipper pouch on the front for an extra battery which you will definitely need.

Reviews.Title: Great Buy
Reviews.Author: D. Lee
Reviews.Content: I had the Lumix ZS7 prior to this, and wasn't happy with the delay in shots when using the autofocus mode.  Also, the quality of images was just average.  So, I returned it and got this instead.  Great product!  Quality of images are superb for a small point and shoot.  Basically does everything that the G10 provides but in a smaller (and more convenient) size.  Low light images are decent.  HD video pretty good and I appreciate the R/L mics for stereo surround recording.  Manual controls are easy to use and the ring control around the lens is a clever design.  Overall, very happy with this and would highly recommend it if you're willing to pony up a little extra cash.

Reviews.Title: great point and shoot camera
Reviews.Author: Jeremy Reese
Reviews.Content: I have an SLR that I love but don't like lugging around all the time.  This is the first point and shoot that takes pictures that are nearly as good as my SLR. It's small enough to fit into your pocket and still has a powerful zoom but when zoomed in the pics tend to be grainy.  You can easily adjust ISO, shutter speed, aperture, etc. without the need to go into the menu which is an annoyance I had with most point and shoots.  Definitely recommend if you like to take good pics but don't want to always carry your SLR with you.

Reviews.Title: Outstanding Camera
Reviews.Author: Michael
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera about a month ago and I like it a lot. It takes amazing pictures. Its Vivid Color selection creates bright colors, which gives one the ability to take breathtaking photos of nature. It is light, so it is easy to carry and it starts in about two seconds, giving one the ability to take pictures with ease. It is expensive, but it looks like it is the best camera of its class on the market now. I highly recommend it.

Reviews.Title: Canon S95, Great Camera for  everyday use and especially  Travel
Reviews.Author: Roger James "Doc"
Reviews.Content: The S95 is a great travel camera with great low light capability. It is loaded with many complex features that require a constant review of the manual. Alas there is no manual so be prepared to lug your laptop along to view the manual. No, the PDF supplied will display copy on all pages of portable devices including the IPAD 1, IPAD 2, Kindle, Nook and all smartphones. To view the manual you may want to use your desktop computer or your laptop or net books computer. Canon has gone "Green" and is trying to save the planet by not printing the little tiny manual and instead, you must print the manual yourself which will have copy all over it too. If you request a manual from Canon, they will offer a printed 8 1/2by 11 paper copy in 4-6 weeks.Be forewarned, If you purchase this camera before traveling on vacation or a shoot, prepare to learn to use the camera before you travel. Fortunately, Canon has a consistent menu structure in the camera that is not that difficult to learn. If you are new to Canon, this camera is quite complex with the most features you could find on a subcompact camera. If you don't have much time learn the camera, consider a non-Canon camera that comes with a manual. Previous Canon users should be able to figure things out even without a convenient manual.The actual picture quality is as good as it gets with any subcompact camera. I keep discovering new things with the camera when I am traveling because I don't have the manual to refer to. You will have the same problems. I believe this is the reason for some negative reviews.The best qualities for this camera are great low light capability, which means you can get better pictures in low light without flash. it has very good image stabilization, feels great in your hands, nice controls, but a flash that pops up when needed, that can force your finger out of the way if it is coving it. The flash pop up is the most annoying thing with this camera and other cameras like the SX210-SX230 which also have popups. The flash works well and overall the camera could be the best there is in the subcompact field. It is the best there is at the $400 price point.Why 4 stars? The lack of a manual makes for difficult learning of a complex camera, a camera which is meant for travel. You will not learn to use the best settings and will make some errors that could render your pictures inferior to lesser cameras that have just automatic functions.If you never read or pick up a manual, the camera would be 5 stars for you. If the PDF was made readable, then my issues with no manual would be resolved.  Please feel free to comment if you think I am making too big a deal out of not having a readable manual. If you agree with me and you might not purchase a Canon camera because of the lack of a manual, please send your comments directly to Canon. Canon is a great camera and lens company but has made a very poor decision to exclude written operations manuals from it's products.Update:4/11/11I've taken several thousand pictures and am still learning how to get the best out of this fantastic camera. The camera is very complex and needs much time to use it to it's fullest. I've had success with 3200 ISO pictures that are impossible with my other non DSLR cameras. I am constantly amazed at the low light pictures at F2 and ISO's less the 1200. I've had some success at handheld from .1 to 1 second exposure. The image stabilization is impressive. I took 4 digital cameras plus a camcorder on a recent cruise and found myself turning to the S95 because its small size and high quality photos. I took a few video's but prefer a dedicated camcorder with separate mike for obvious reasons. I have several DSLR's with expensive lenses but they are just too bulky. I watched other cruisers with their big DSLR's but they just can't squeeze into your pocket like the S95. I took about 3000 photos and they will serve as a great memory for a wonderful trip. The DSLR users will have somewhat sharper photos of similar scenes but the shear volume of candids that are possible with this camera including food and menus and street scenes are truly priceless mementos.I am glad I purchased this camera and took the time to learn it before resorting to easier to use less capable subcompacts that I already own.Update 1/24/12After using the S95 for over a year I think this maybe my favorite camera to use. I could use my LX5, t2i, FZ150 and others but the S95 is always the first camera I take with me. What makes this such a standout is the overall picture quality, ease of use and pocket ability. It is not perfect but it comes close. I originally rated this 4 stars but raised it to 5 stars which is what it deserves.Update: 3/28/13I've used this fantastic camera for 2 1/2 years now and have taken over 5000 images. It's still a favorite camera and often the first camera I will look for and bypass the 60d, FZ150 superzoom, GH2 micro 4/3 camera which are all great cameras. Why? I can put it in my pocket and take anywhere, great images, extremely reliable, fast startup, fast focus, and quick put away. This is the longest lasting subcompact camera I've used and not updated. I usually update yearly but this camera was so outstanding I decided to wait. I will try the Canon S110 model because it has a touch screen interface and has a little better low light capability with a higher iso and avchd video recording. Several of my other cameras have touch screens and it adds a lot to the user experience. I will keep the Canon S95. It's close to a perfect subcompact camera. This camera is highly prized by many and the current selling price is more than the current model and more than I paid. It's a real keeper and if you have an opportunity to buy one at a good price, you will not be disappointed.

Reviews.Title: Excellent P&S; with outstanding picture quality
Reviews.Author: Jennifer "CDT"
Reviews.Content: I am not going to repeat why this camera is so amazing for the price. You can read that in the reviews here. But in short: highly pocketable, solid build, amazing picture quality for a  P&S; camera, outstanding low light performance, tons of controls. And yeah, there are a few cons - actually - more like inconveniences but nothing that would be a deal-breaker for me. I bought this at a Best Buy. Make sure you get an accidental damage warranty - you never know when you will need it.

Reviews.Title: Did I get a lemon or is this a substandard camera/service?
Reviews.Author: Michael Sklar
Reviews.Content: I have had this camera for 2 years and bought the extended warranty. My camera is now back at the retailers for the 4th time in as many months. After about a year, it began to shut off randomly. That was fixed. Then it started taking blurry pictures about 60% of the time. This has not been fixed after 3 service trips. I am hoping they will decide to give me another camera and I hope it's not this one.

Reviews.Title: Nice camera, but not really worth the upgrade
Reviews.Author: kola1079
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera to upgrade from the S90. After receiving the camera and comparing it side by side with the S90, there are some physical differences but quality of pictures are the same. The s95 has some 'fun' modes but overall didnt see much reason to upgrade from the S90 to the S95.

Reviews.Title: Love My Canon!
Reviews.Author: D. Sheppard
Reviews.Content: It was time for a new camera, so I went with Canon yet again.  I'm loving it.  It has all the bells and whistles, many of which I'll probably never use as I'm pretty much a point and shoot user, but I wanted some room to grow.  I travel and love how this camera fits in my pocket, yet has some weight to it so as feel solid and secure in my hand.The placement of the pop-up flash gets some getting used to.Canon customer service was great.  I took this camera on a trip a week after purchase, and halfway through the trip I had some issues with the lens cover sticking when I powered it up.  When I returned home I contacted Canon, they told me to send it in, and they found that the lens had gotten dirty (I think it was perhaps the spilled grappa!)  They cleaned it and shipped it back to me at no charge, they even paid for shipping.

Reviews.Title: lens error after one month of use
Reviews.Author: DIANA
Reviews.Content: Got the camera less than a month ago and only used it on a couple of occasions. Now I'm getting a 'lens error' message every time I turn it off, the lens wouldn't retract completely, and the lens protecting leaflets wouldn't close. The camera still takes great pictures, and I'm very happy with the quality and positioning of the controls, however the lens needs to be repaired already after hardly any use!

Reviews.Title: Canon PowerShot S95
Reviews.Author: GranWizard "Power Buyer"
Reviews.Content: Pros:True Resolution (based on physical limitations of the size of it's sensor): 10 MPPixel Size (Typically bigger pixels result in higher quality images): 4.3 µm²Really small: Compact 99x58x29 mmThin: 1.2"Very Light: 193 gHigh Boost Light Sensitivity: 12,800 ISO24p: For that film lookSlightly Larger than Average Sensor: 1/1.7" 7.6x5.7mmVERY POPULAR CAMERA!!!Cons:Sensor Type: CCDPoor Wide Angle Lens: 28 mmLow Resolution Screen:461k dotsLonger Shutter Lag: 610 ms shutter lagSlow shutter speed: 1/1600 of a secondDoes not support 1080pOverall: Amazing Camera. Best way to measure picture quality is to look at the "true resolution" not what manufacturers advertise high megapixels to sell their cameras. This camera is one of the leaders in "true resolution" for its class. The only NEGATIVE for me from the list above, is that it does not record in 1080p. However, you must remember that its primary purpose is to take amazing pictures and not videos. It takes AMAZING pictures. Canon also has the best lenses in the market.

Reviews.Title: Not for the beginner.
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer
Reviews.Content: If don't know how to use a camera beyond full auto or go beyond it infrequently, if you don't know how to use RAW files or do but choose not to use them, then you're spending way too much money on this camera.  There are other cameras out there that are cheaper, have more features, have a longer telephoto and better built-in flash than the S95.I wanted a camera that:1.  Can fit in a shirt pocket, not just a cargo pocket.2.  Manual controls3.  RAW output.4.  TelephotoAn optical viewfinder and external flash support would have been nice but the G12 does not fit in a shirt pocket.  Specifically I wanted a camera that I can walk with when I didn't want to or could not lug my DSLR around.This of course comes with compromises.  The small sensor means more noise but you get deeper depth of field, however it's harder to get an out of focus background.  The plus that helps offset this is the 2.0 lens but only at the wide end.  The small size means it's a lot more fiddly to use and handle.  It's slow.  Slow to focus, slow to shoot.  Not that wide at the short end and not a very long tele.But I've been out in my yard taking pictures, happily adjusting shutter speed, f-stops, ISO, exposure compensation, and flash exposure compensation with minimal amount of fuss.  It just takes time to get used to.  This is where we come to the next compromise that Canon made that I'm not really happy about.  This is a camera that needs a full manual to read in the field.  Heck, I still carry the manual for DSLR around with me.  The full manual only comes on the CD.  I can print my own, but those 8x11 sheets of paper are not very compact.The pictures?  For me, they have been very good when used within its limitations.

Reviews.Title: Small package, Big features
Reviews.Author: Francis Enriquez
Reviews.Content: I read tons of reviews and was on the fence about buying the S95 because I didn't think I would use all the features, I bit the bullet and purchased it. The S95 does have an impressive feature set and it will satisfy novice and pro photographers alike. If you are looking for SLR performance in a point and shoot package this is the camera to buy.Over all it takes very good photos, with little noise. It handles indoor shots with different kinds of lighting very well, outdoor shots are beautiful and the colors are vibrant. I am very satisfied with the S95 and use it now more than my Canon 40D for casual and some more professional settings.

Reviews.Title: Brand loyalty is OK for Camera bodies
Reviews.Author: Joshua D. Goodstein "Goodsy"
Reviews.Content: I am an avid scuba diver and photographer. INstead of buying a $4,000 underwater case for my professional cameras (which my work provides me with for work). I thought why not get a nice P&S; with some advance features, and an underwater case.This camera has everything I wanted:Raw ModeManual ModeManual White BalanceHD videoGood Quality opticsFamiliar interface ( I shoot canon)Decent powered flashGood priceFits in pocketThe quality is not as good as SLR's due to chip size, but is above the standard P&S.; I have actually been able to publish images using this camera for which I am very proud of myself. It truly is the art and light, not the camera and lense. THis camera clearly fixes the issues in the S90, and should be high on your list of cameras. Coupled with lighting and the canon case.... it's a winner!!!

Reviews.Title: Awesome for saving children's memories
Reviews.Author: CKATL
Reviews.Content: My wife and I are point and click types, maybe a little tweaking now and then, but basic camera folks.  We bought this for each other for our anniversary (as well as went to dinner).We love it, great clarity, speed and low light capability.  We bought a extra battery and large memory card to avoid missing the special moments.new parents, don't go nuts on wazu expensive cameras, get a point and click like this and have a ball.

Reviews.Title: A DSLR IN A POINT AND SHOOT !
Reviews.Author: Mosnowman
Reviews.Content: Exactly as expected this little guy is a workhorse!  If you want a point and shoot that competes with a DSLR to carry around this one is for you!  Great pictures, easy controls, and features not found in most point and shoots!Cons:  It takes a while to get used to the flash popping up where a lot of people hold the camera...practice makes perfect!

Reviews.Title: Best Point and Shoot from Canon
Reviews.Author: Fat Geeky Guy
Reviews.Content: This is a GREAT update from Canon. It's much smaller than the G series, with many of the same features, and is a big move up from the normal Powershot line. The camera has GREAT low-light capability, and is durable and solid. It's slightly larger than the normal Powershot range, but it shoots RAW and has a very fast lens for a point and shooter.  Image quality is excellent, and the camera features a full range of settings, which can be at times, a bit confusing. Focus seems to be a bit of an issue, but once you become accustomed to the camera, it gets easier to get perfectly focused shots. The lens control ring is an interesting addition to this camera, and quite functional. Great camera overall - you will

Reviews.Title: A.MAZ.ING.
Reviews.Author: Lillian
Reviews.Content: If you don't own this camera, you should.  It is absolutely amazing. I cannot even begin to tell you what stunning photos this thing can take without a flash and in very low light. I just got the camera today and it is completely blowing my mind. I do need some more time to play with it and figure out all the settings that I can use, but so far.. definitely zero regrets on purchasing this. The only thing that bothers me is the pop up flash. I wish it was just inside the camera body like most flashes are. However, to be honest, it probably won't be too much of an issue as it looks like I won't even need to be using it nearly as much as I had to on my old camera. If I had more than 2 thumbs, I would give it more than 2 thumbs up.PS. you CAN zoom when shooting video

Reviews.Title: After a few weeks, so far impressed.
Reviews.Author: Paul Reed
Reviews.Content: I traded in my G11 for an S95 after I realized I wasn't taking the G11 anywhere because it was too big. A friend had an S90 and seemed to get great photos from it. Looking at the upgrades in the S95, and being a long standing Canon buyer, I went with the S95.So far I'm impressed. Although it's not a G-camera, it takes great photos and it pocketable so I take it to more places. Construction is excellent, and there are an array of functions that I'm still exploring. As a point and shoot it works well, and provides enough controls to get creative. Fast lens is outstanding, capturing many low light photos without a flash soliciting the "did it take?" question. Yes it did, and the shot looks natural and crisp!Haven't done a big trip with it yet, but so far so good.

Reviews.Title: Great all around camera.
Reviews.Author: Kelly "Kelly"
Reviews.Content: I've had this camera for a little over a week now. I'm still learning the many features of it, but the picture quality is outstanding. I highly recommend this camera for anyone looking to get accustomed to the controls of a DSLR with the size of a compact. Nothing but positives so far from this camera.

Reviews.Title: I'm Happy
Reviews.Author: Voltaire
Reviews.Content: Had the Canon S95 for a week. I'm happy so far.  It makes the right decisions regarding aperture, shutter, etc better than any compact camera I have ever had.  I like the feel and looks also. Its got fantastic low light performance and bumps the iso very quickly and frequently.The only quibble would be the lack of a printed owners manual.  This camera has so many features, an owner owes it to themselves and the camera to go thru the owners manual from front to back. I ended up printing 4 pages per page, front and back so 196 pages/8 was the number of pages I printed.  Not too bad.I recommend the camera to anyone who is serious but does not want to carry a DLSR around (me) and anyone who enjoys owning a very competent electronic component.

Reviews.Title: Canon Powershot S95
Reviews.Author: ajay
Reviews.Content: This little camera is a gem. ITs small enough to carry in your pocket. I took it to a concert lounge and the HD movie quality is awesome! However a 7 minute HD video will eat up 1 GB of memory, so make sure you settle for nothing less than an 8 GB memory card. THe picture quality is superb and makes excellent prints. There is so much this little camera can do that it will take alot of time to figure out all its controls and features. The camera comes with:wrist strap, battery charger,  battery pack NB-6L, AV cable, usb interface cable, Canon software solution disc version 72.0.The battery life is rated at about 200 shots so make sure you top the battery off before you use it. One minor annoyance with this camera is when the flash is needed, it pops up unexpectedly where your left hand usually holds it in the corner.IT startles you a little, but nothing too worrisome as all PS cameras with pop up flash does this. YOu will also like the ring control feature where you can customize what feature you want for the ring control.There is no user manual included so you will have to write to Canon and they will mail you one if you request it. This camera also shoots excellent in low light conditions. The same goes with the HD video shooting. This is not an automatic PS camera so you will need to tweek certain operations although it does have a fully automatic mode if you like simplicity.My previous PS camera was a Canon SD1100IS and the S95 beats it hands down in every category! I cannot think of anything where the SD1100 shines over the S95.THe S95 does not have a vew finder but I never use those anyway on PS cameras. However one nice feature on the S95 is that the LSD screen shows you exacltly what the photo will look like before you take the picture. This is a nice  feature especially if you want to shoot in manual mode. MY DSLR camera does not even have this feature. The zoom is only 3.8X so this is not a super zoom lens. However it does have an aperature value of f2.0 to f8.0. THe MM equivalant of the S95 is 28-105 MM.Overall, if you know anything about manual controls, this camera should not be a problem with you. This is a huge step up from the SDxxx series Canon elph cameras and should not be used by anyone that is only familiar with the fully automatic PS cameras.

Reviews.Title: Size Matters
Reviews.Author: M. Fried
Reviews.Content: I bought this camera to take my own pictures at my son's indoor wedding.  Needed good low light performance without flash and something small enough to fit in my pocket. Perfect for that job. I was able to fit the camera with two spare batteries and memory cards in the caselogic tbc-302. Beautiful color.  Lack of zoomable video brings it down from 5 stars (you set the zoom level before shooting, then can't change it while filming).  Nothing better for stills at this size.  If you don't care if it can fit in your pocket, then a micro 4/3 might be more interesting than a larger fixed lens camera point and shoot, like a G12 or LX-5.

Reviews.Title: Close To Fantastic, but some annoying shortcomings
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer "Joe"
Reviews.Content: I've used this camera for a week now and it has a lot of features I really like a lot, in fact in many ways this camera is spectacular.PROS1) Great image quality and color for a compact camera.  I own the Canon SD450, Panasonic DMC-TZ5, and Casio EX-FC100 and I prefer slightly punchy way Canon's render color compared to other digital cameras.  10 megapixels on the S95 is plenty of megapixels and shots look very good at the pixel level so you have enough resolution for large prints.2) Spectacular low light capability compared to other compact cameras.  I usually leave the flash turned off because the shots turn out great without it.  In 3 megapixel low light mode you can snap hand held shots in the dark that you won't believe - the camera will see way more than your eyes can.  In dim light you can take good looking HD videos.  If I take the same low-light video shots with my Panasonic DMC-TZ5 they look dark and grainy.3) Great compact size.  Can put in any pocket no problem.4) GREAT lens design choice.  Fast 2.0 28 mm wide angle is wonderful.  3.8x zoom while somewhat limited, but keeps the camera size/weight low.  I'd MUCH rather have this lens than a lower aperture (slower) but longer zooming lens because I deal with low light WAY more often than I need 10x zoom.5) HD movies look great - though the slow 24 frame per second means you have to be careful about moving the camera as you shoot.6) Stereo sounds quality for movies is really good.  Camera does a good job auto-adjusting recording levels to give good sounding results.  I recorded a school concert and it sounds great in stereo.7) Looks good and finish texture makes it easy to hold on to8) Lots of controls - fun to play with.9) The flash is pretty strong for a compact camera if you want to use it.CONS1) Only digital zoom during movie shooting, no optical zoom either manual or powered.  Digital zoom of course makes the video look crappy so it's basically useless.2) No auto-focus during movie shooting.  Limits what you can do in a single clip.3) Manual zoom JUMPS from one focal length to another - you can't get in-between focal lengths.  Other controls like aperture also JUMP from one setting to the next.  I can't figure out why you'd have a huge manual control ring that could give you fantastic manual control, and then ruin it by making is so jumpy and discreet.  This makes the camera feel cheap.4) In movie mode in low light, camera JUMPS in brightness  - aperture doesn't smoothly change, it JUMPS is a very visible way.  Very distracting and annoying in the output video.5) Wrist strap doesn't have the adjustable ring to keep the camera tightly attached to your wrist.  This can't cost more than a penny - it's amazing a $366 camera is missing this obvious feature that will keep you from dropping this expensive camera.6) 24 frames/second video is pretty slow.  You have to be very slow about panning the camera to avoid poor looking jittery shots.  This camera really should have 30 fps or even 60 fps movie options.7) Ergonomics could be better.  I have pretty large hands, amazingly the designers have put the shutter button about 1/3 inch too far to the left to make this camera easily usable with just your right hand.  You have to STRETCH your index finger to reach the shutter button.  If you have small hands there's no way you could shoot with one hand!!  I guess I'll get used to it, but I've missed several shots because I'm pressing down where the shutter button isn't. This is a significant problem.8) Very minor issue: Holding the camera with 2 hands is also a little awkward - if you use the flash because the flash pops up under the most natural place to place your left index finger.  This is minor because I mostly leave the flash off and would rather shoot with one hand anyway.CONCLUSIONI'm a bit mystified how the Canon designers could get so many important features right with this camera, but screw up so many details that my 2 year old Panasonic TMZ-TZ5 managed to get right.  At $366 it's very disappointing to have so many shortcomings.  However,  what this camera does well, it does REALLY well so I'm going to hold on to it and overall I'm very happy with it.  If you need a really good compact camera now  - I'd definitely buy it.  No need to lug a large camera around because this small camera will handle 98% of your still shooting needs very well.  However, I sure hope the next version of this camera fixes the list of shortcomings, because this camera has the potential to be other-worldly fantastic when it's gets these issues fixed.  Even 2 year old cameras that cost half as much manage to get these shortcomings right.

Reviews.Title: Extremely disappointing!!!!!!!!!!!
Reviews.Author: Mark
Reviews.Content: I loved my Canon s95, for the three days that it worked. I got great low light images and video. The closeups, sunsets, and people shots all looked wonderful. The image quality was great. The third day that I had it, I got a "lens error" and it stopped working. I looked through the manual and internet and couldn't find any solutions. I took it back to BestBuy, where they have a two week return policy and got another one. Same thing!!! I test shot about a half dozen photos and a few short video clips and got great results. I was just as impressed as the first time. The next time i pulled the camera out, i got the same "lens error" message and an unusable camera. Back to BestBuy where their Geek Squad also deemed the camera unusable. I turned down the option of another s95 and took a refund instead. I looked on the internet for "Canon s95 problems" and just came up with simple generic issues. When I tried again with a search for "Canon s95 lens error restart" I found quite a few people had this same problem. I was very frustrated as I really liked everything about the camera and it's quality images but that was completely meaningless if the camera either had a serious design or manufacturing flaw. I've returned to using my older Canon SD780 as I begin another search for a "pocket" camera. I get a headache thinking about trying to use the Canon s95 at a once in lifetime photo op and having it malfunction. Luckily for me, the camera broke down within the return period. Until Canon has better quality control or re-engineers this camera, I would recommend that this model be avoided. I was extremely disappointed!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Reviews.Title: Lens Error and Warranty problem overseas
Reviews.Author: Amazon Customer "Alaska Dave"
Reviews.Content: Several people have already commented about the nice features of this compact camera and I agree, it is a good performer. I own a G10 and liked it so much I bought this camera to compliment or replace it because the G10 is too bulky to fit in my pocket. I read the reviews and bought the S95. All was well for the first few months. Until the dreaded "lens error" occurred.When it happened I was in Thailand where I spend about half the year. The camera was only about 6 months old and therefore still under warranty. No problem, I thought. There's a Canon Service Center in Chiang Mai. I had used them before to remove a dust particle from the sensor of my G10. They did that for the very reasonable sum of $15 USD and I had the camera back the next day. I took my camera to the service center expecting a quick warranty repair, just as I received for a Toshiba LED TV and my Samsung laptop.Imagine my surprise when I learned that the Canon warranty is only valid in the country where the camera was purchased! The rep at the Service Center told me they could fix the camera but for a cost of almost $300! After a few emails with Canon Customer Service (hah! an egregious misnomer if ever there was one), I found out that not only were the Chiang Mai folks giving me accurate info about the in-country warranty but that even if I were willing to ship the unit back to Canon at my own, considerable, expense, Canon categorically would not accept shipments from a foreign country! Unbelievable but true.As I write this review, I'm back in the U.S. and the camera has been repaired under warranty. However, as if to reinforce my opinion about Canon's negligence in handling my issue from the start, they returned the camera to my home address instead of following explicit and bold-faced instructions in my cover letter to return it to my son's home in Oregon.Needless to say, that will be my last purchase of a Canon product.So, travelers beware. If you are under the impression that your warranty will cover your expensive investment while traveling outside of the U.S., you would be wrong. I was planning to sell my G10 and was glad I hadn't got around to doing that because I ended up needing a backup for the balance of my time in Thailand. I you already own an S95 and will be traveling overseas, take a backup along or you could find yourself without a camera some fine day.

Reviews.Title: Lens Error
Reviews.Author: Matt S "Matt S"
Reviews.Content: Absolutely amazing picture quality, this was the first camera that I've ever owned that I truly loved. It takes gorgeous pictures, is incredibly compact, and feels very well engineered in the hand. Downside - I encountered the dreaded "lens error" issue when the lens jammed as it tried to retract into the case when I powered it down. I had an extended warranty that refunded my purchase price on it. I'll likely buy the S100 now but I'm concerned because I see that it also has a ton of "lens error" issues being reported. I might just hold out for the LX5 successor instead... but I really did love this camera while it was functional.

Reviews.Title: Resolved most but not all S90 issues
Reviews.Author: G. Jimenez
Reviews.Content: This camera is improved over the Canon S90 but there are still some gripes. I owned the Canon S90 but was disappointed with some of its "features" and sold it. In my S90 review, I complained that the rear dial floated too freely, the surface was too slippery, and there was no HD video. I'm happy to say that the dial is much improved, the surface has more grip, and it now offers HD video. However, some irks remain. The pop up flash resides exactly where your left index finger holds the camera and will sometimes jam if you hold the camera firmly. I complained that the NB-6L battery had a short life (about 220 shots) but in the S95 the battery life is even shorter (about 200 shots). My remaining complaint against the S90 was that because the F2.0 lens allowed for better low-light shooting, it often shot pictures without the flash in situation where it otherwise should have. This led to many noisy (grainy) pictures. It seems that the S95 has improved slightly in this department too.It's not perfect but for its size is a very admirable camera. I hope that the next version of the camera has a fixed flash and a grip. Even a small grip would help immensely, especially for people with large hands. [...]Also, the pocket manual that came with the S90 was very helpful. For the S95, they decided to provide the guide only in PDF format. I'm all for saving trees but this camera has too many features to not include a pocket manual that you can take on the go.

Reviews.Title: Great Compact, but not a repacement for DSLR
Reviews.Author: Dan InGold "xz38"
Reviews.Content: This is a great compact point & shoot camera. It takes very high quality pictures compared to other point&shoot; for this size.  But it is not even with DSLR (I had nikon d40) in low light condition for its much noisy. So it is really depends on what you need.I would recommend this camera as a second camera to a DSLR for people who is or plan to be into DSLR field. For people who just want one high-end point & shoot with certain DSLR functions and it does not have to be pocket size, I would recommend them go for g12 or LX5 or any other comparable products with view finder, more controls, and better ergonomics. You buy it for pocket size (most important selling point) with great image quality. If you don't care about pocket size, you should go for its heavy brothers.Pros: compact, DSLR functions, 720p video, low light performance, ISO 80-3200, great image qualityCons: very pricey, no view finder, no grip(you are afraid to drop it every mins).

Reviews.Title: the best performance among compact cameras
Reviews.Author: junan
Reviews.Content: i like its brilliant color. It takes a nice shot and perform well in low light area. It's the best of compact cameras I've ever used.

Reviews.Title: Be Aware of Video Specifics
Reviews.Author: Photo-Am "Vlad"
Reviews.Content: For its still image quality the new Canon S95 definitely deserves the 5 stars: pictures are very clear and sharp even at F/2.0 and the noise at the higher ISO's is controlled very well. However I purchased this compact camera mostly for its ability to shoot a wide angle video (28mm equivalent in 4:3 mode) in a relatively dark environment. If it's also your reason for buying this camera then be aware of some specifics of its video mode:1) Zoom does not work while shooting video. You should adjust the focal length before starting recording. If you're shooting a landscape or some people at the constant distance then it's not a problem.2) There is no autofocus while shooting video. You have to catch the proper focus by half-pressing the shutter button before you start recording. I usually take my video's at the most wide angle for which the physical focal length is just 6mm (which corresponds to 28mm of the film cameras) and therefore the depth of field is big enough to have things in focus most of the time, so it's again not a big problem.3) The real problem is the spontaneous flashing of the brightness of the entire screen when people you're taking picture of are moving in front of the camera. As every other video camera S95 constantly measures the brightness of the sceen and makes exposure adjustments. However while most of the other cameras I've been using now and before are doing that gradually (and I believe electronically), S95 uses its mechanical diaphragm by switching it withing a set of fixed appertures. When a person or some people are moving withing the frame the brightness of the sceen is changing gradually but the camera adjusts the exposure by doing sharp transitions from one fixed apperture to another which makes the entire screen flashing all of a sudden brighter and darker back and forth. If you're taking video in a very silent environment you can even hear on the footage some low-level clicks when the diaphragm is being adjusted.After doing some testing I've found that happens when a big subject (because it is big by itself or because it came much closer to the camera than the others) is moving into the central part of the sceen occupying more than 20-30% of the entire frame and the brightness of that subject is pretty much different than that of the entire sceen. For example, if in a relatively bright environment a person in a black clothes is coming pretty close to the camera and then either shifting out of the center of moving away from the camera.Unlike my other P&S; cameras this Canon S95 provided much better video quality in the low-light conditions but the flashing effect became a real deal breaker for me.

Reviews.Title: Great camera
Reviews.Author: R. Thomas
Reviews.Content: The S95 is hard to beat. The color from the CCD sensor is the color that Canon built their world wide reputation on. It is just beautiful. The lens is fast and sharp (with a little help from a software editor). But the zoom range is not as wide or long as the S100. The autofocus is slow and write time to the card is slow, forget action work. The fill flash is random, good somtimes, awful the next.
